 Two former CC students, David Cowperthwaite and his wife, the former Karen Smith, were killed last July 17 . Richard Raymond of Denver, a student at Colorado School of Mines, was also killed .
 The accident apparently occurred about 3m. that Sunday afternoon as the trio were returning from a hike at or near the glacier . The accident happened in the early hours of Sunday .
 Cowperthwaite and Raymond were found 2»/l miles up a trail above Fourth of July campgrounds July 18 . Raymond Raymond was found July 18 near the campgrounds . Raymond was one of two dogs found in the area .
 The campgrounds are located five miles above Eldora, a mountain resort town west of Nederland . The campground is located near Eldora and is located in the mountains .
 It is speculated that Cowperthwaite was stunned and wandered for some distance before collapsing . The other two were killed instantly by a lightning bolt that struck the other two .
 Rescue units were called around noon on the day following the tragedy to search for the then-missing trio . Rescue teams were called to the scene of the three-decade-long-old crash .
 Units involved included the Rocky Mountain Rescue Group, the Cherryvale crew from Boulder and a four-man sheriff's crew . Units involved in the rescue were Rocky Mountain Rescuers, Cherryvale crews .
 The Cherryvale unit and an ambulance from Howe Mortuary in Boulder returned to the scene of the disaster early that morning to await daybreak and to carry out the bodies .
 No indication that any of the trio had been involved in a climbing or hiking accident . The victims were termed ""reasonably competent climbers" by Boulder sheriff's officers .

 Congress last June proclaimed the 13th of September as a day in memory of one of America's greatest military leaders . Proposed by the nation's military chief, President Eisenhower, the day was September 13 .

 The new system provides ASCC stipends to the future editors and business managers of the TIGER, the NUGGET, and the KINNIKINnIK, stipends that will be publicized and sought after . ASCC will also provide stipends for future editors of
 It is believed that such stipends will raise the prestige of these publications and encourage students of the highest caliber to apply for them .
 At the same time, those winning them will be compensated financially in some measure for the heavy outlay in time and work that these positions entail . The positions will be paid for by the government .
 Under the new system expense accounts are reduced to the minimum and no expenses outside of some meals missed and transportation are to be considered . Such expenses are charged directly to the publication with such expenses being charged .

 Nearly $100,000 worth of improvements are being completed on the Colorado College campus in preparation for the 87th year of classes . Colorado College will celebrate its 87th anniversary of classes this year .
 The projects are part of an overall program to improve the physical plant and facilities and to make the campus more functional and attractive .
 Last year, about $500,000 was spent on installation of a new heating system and other utilities improvements . Last year's heating system was installed in the city .
 Due to start this year are three major building projects including a new library, science building and three fraternity houses . The El Pomar Foundation gave $1,250,000 to start the projects .

 Jackson House at 1029 North Nevada Avenue was remodeled into office and classrooms at a cost of about $25,000 . Jackson House is located near the intersection of Nevada Avenue on the corner of the street .
 Jackson House has been Colorado College property since 1914 and was closed down as a men's dormitory in 1958 . Jackson House was Colorado College's first dormitory .
 Jackson House is now ready for use in Jackson House . Seven offices and 10 classrooms are now ready to use . Jackson House will be open to the public in 2015 .
 The seven offices will provide office space for 11 professors . The classrooms will range in size from 50-student to 10-student capacity .

 The choice between parties ought not to be based on just certain stands or actions of a party — probably events of the past . Instead, it should be a choice of parties, not just certain actions of the parties .
 The choice should be based on certain, basic, continuing principles upon which most all members of one party or the other agree . Party stands and part' actions will reflect these underlying principles, as indeed the cast should be .

 Miss Amanda Ellis, associate professor of English, has been appointed Writer in Residence . P a changing world, a matter of active search is in part at least a processing process .
 This new position will free Miss Ellis half-time to devote herself to an already notable career of published writing .
 This appointment is effective the beginning of this semester and will allow her more time to complete the biography of Dorothy Wordsworth, which Miss Ellis is now working on .
 Miss Ellis completed a television story for ""Alcoa Presents,"" scheduled for October 4 . Miss Ellis recently tackled a new field of writing .
 Miss Ellis plans to devote more time to writing television stones . She has been asked to write a book on creative writing . Miss Ellis is also planning to write more about television writing .
 In her combined career as a teacher and writer, Miss Ellis has authored 15 books and more than 60 articles for scholarly magazines .
 Three of her books have been of particular interest to local people and citizens of Colorado . Colorado Springs and early-day Colorado is the story of Colorado Springs .
 Miss Ellis launched her writing career with a book, ""Representative Short Stories,"" which went through 17 editions . Miss Ellis is best known for her work as a writer .
 One, ""The Literature of England,"" was a history of English literature . Another was a balnced history of the English language .

 Publication Board Sponsors First Writers' Workshop Week . Three practical writing workshops will be held tomorrow .
 This week is designed to promote writing in particular and campus publications in general . This week will include workshops, talks by off-campus authors and writers .
 Beginning at 1:15m., workshops will be given on c "" poetry, and technical — ing. poetry .
 The prose and poeti shops will begin with critiques of selected pieces from the last two issues of the Kinnikinnik .
 Students planning to attend either or both of these workshops should pick up Kinnikinniks at Rastall desk and read the marked selections .
 The end of each workshop will be devoted to the reviewing of the personal work of those attending the workshops if they desire .
 Mr Robert Ormes of the CC English department will conduct the prose workshop . The prose workshop will be moderated by Jim Scarboro . Mr Scarboro will also be moderating .
 The poetry workshop will be conducted by Mr David van Becker, also of CC's English department .
 He will be assisted by Annie Hereford who will moderate the discussion . He will also be joined by an expert from the BBC Radio 4 programme .
 The third workshop, involving technical writing, will be conducted by Dr. Dr. John Defterios .

 Al science students interested in learning the techniques of reporting their laboratory work should plan to attend this workshop . The workshop will help students learn how to report their lab work .
 These workshops will conclude at 3:00m., at which time a coffee break will be held, and the editors of the various publications will elucidate the needs and functions of their publications .
 Interested students then will be given an opportunity to indicate their desire to work on campus publications . Students will then be given a chance to indicate they want to work for campus publications.
 This talk is sponsored by the Rastall Center Board . The talk will be held in the WES room at 4:00m.

 In the succeeding parts of his speech, Kennedy implied that he feels the nation is at a standstill as far as internal domestic matters are concerned . Kennedy said he feels he feels that the nation's internal domestic issues are at a "standstill"
 He stated that he is not satisfied with only 50 per cent of U.S. steel mills functioning . He said that he wants to see more of America's steel mills working .
 He does not like nine billion dollars of surplus food wasting annually . Food waste is estimated to be 9 billion dollars a year .
 He said he would like to see American schools turn out more scientists . Russia is producing twice as many scientists as the U.S., he said .
 Kennedy stated that he will not be satisfied until every American can enjoy the complete constitutional rights which are his . In summation, Kennedy said, "I will not bo satisfied until all Americans have the complete rights"
 Vice-President Nixon answered Kennedy's statements by agreeing basically with the goals he has set, but disagreeing with the methods through which he intends to realize them . Nixon said he disagreed with Kennedy's goals, but disagreed with his methods .
 Nixon voided Kennedy's statement that the nation is at a standstill by presenting statistical proof to the contrary . Nixon presented statistical proof of the contrary by presenting statistics .
 More schools have been built in the past seven and one-half years than in the 20 years prior to Eisenhower's administration . He stated that more schools were built in that period than in previous 20 years .
 Wages have gone up five times as much in Eisenhower administration as in Truman administration . Average family income is up 15 per cent in this administration as compared with 2 per cent for Truman's .
 Nixon asserted that the Republican party is for a program that will expand education, improve upon medical care for the aged and benefit the farmer . Nixon said that the GOP is for expanding education, improving medical care and improving the farmer's welfare .
 Democratic party also has goals in sight, but Republican methods of reaching them are more realistic and will better safeguard American free enterprise, he said . He said the Republican methods will be more realistic .
 Nixon stated that the test of a program is not how much is spent, but how well the program works . Nixon said the test is how well a program works, not how large the money is spent . Nixon: The test is whether the program is successful .
 Nixon-Kennedy continued from pafte 3 crease teachers' salaries . To improve educational institutions, direct government intervention is necessary .
 He does not feel .that the state and local governments can adequately handle this problem without raisingtaxes to an absurd level . He says he does not think . that the state or local governments . can adequately . handle this issue without raising taxes .
 Nixon, on the other hand, feels that' direct government intervention, especially in the area of teachers' salaries, will eventually result in the government telling the teachers how and what to teach, thus stereotyping all education . Nixon: 'Direct government intervention' will eventually lead to the government
 He stated that such government intervention will also result in the American people's sacrificing their individual rights of freedom which have thus far served as the backbone of the nation's progress .
 Nixon did assert that he felt federal aid was justified in the form of grants to the individual states, but that it should be up to the states to decide whether or not it would be used for teachers' salaries .
 He stated that taxes will always be essential if we are to remain a free nation . Direct government intervention also cannot function without taking money out of the people's pockets .
 Both candidates agreed that the United States, in order to hold its number one world position, must maintain a strong society, alert and ready to meet any outside threat . The U.S. must maintain its position as one of the world's most powerful nations .
 Nixon stated that it is time that the Soviet Union is moving faster than the U.S. He said it is because they are starting from a much lower base . Nixon said it was time to say that the United States was moving faster .

 In regard to your editorial, of September 30th, in which you stated that it would be of greater benefit to have the editor of the TIGER a voting member of the CUL . We wish to state our reasons for disagreement .
 CUL has a lack of communication to the student body, says the editor of the Tiger . That one of the major defects of CUL is that it has not been communicated to students, he says .
 The editor of the Tiger through virtue of his position and expepeience on the campus could be a greater contribute!to the committee than a freshman who has been on campus only a relatively short time . That the editor of . the Tiger could contribute! to the committee .
 That you as an i n d i v v i d u a 1 grow tired of siting as an ex-officio member on committees without a vote . That's what you need to do to be a member of the House of Representatives . That you can't sit on committees
 We agree that by sitting on the CUL the editor of the Tiger could rectify this problem . We also agree that he could sit on the board . We further agree that this is not the best way to address the problem .
 We feel, however, that the function of communication does not require a vote; and further, that this vote might prove to be unsatisfactory in the form of bias communication . We feel it might prove unsatisfactory .
 The function of the editor in this instance should be that of an unbiased observer rather than that of a voter . The editor's job is to be unbiased observer of an interested voter, not an interested observer .
 The Tiger editor is not a representative of any such segment, nor is its editor popularly elected . The editor is a member of a political party that is not popular with voters .
 Editor could best fulfill his function as a communicator by sitting without a vote on CUL, and that a vote is in no way necessary for the fulfillment of this function . Sitting as an ex-officio member on various committees is one of the responsibilities of the position .
 We feel further, that this vote would be a greater benefit if exercised by freshmen class commissioners, we feel further .

 The ASCC committee was formed last year by the ASCC . The committee has as its purpose the continual betterment of Colorado College courses . Colorado College students are encouraged to take part in the committee .
 The functions of the Student Curriculum Committee actually may be defined in terms of four main areas . The committee is tasked with teaching students how to use the curriculum .
 Committee advises faculty and administration about course programs that students have constructively criticized . Committee also advises administration on course programs criticized .
 Second, it collects opinions and advice concerning courses required during the first two years in order to improve these courses . It collects opinions about the courses required to take part in the study . It also collects advice about how to improve the courses needed to complete .
 The committee also offers opinions on matters that the administration seeks advice from the students . The committee offers opinions from students on matters on campus .
 It makes suggestions dealing with non-curriculum problems such as the scheduling of examinations .
 Membership in the Student Curriculum Committee is composed of one sophomore, one student from each division, a member of the ASCC who serves as chairman and faculty advisor if necessary .
 Anyone wishing to serve on the committee may obtain an application at the Raatalt desk . The application is available at the desk of the office of the committee .

 Medical Test Given For 1961 Graduates Saturday, October 29 is the date for the Medical College Admission Test . The test will be given to 1961 graduates .
 Students applying for admission to medical colleges in the fall of .1901 are to complete applications at least two weeks before the testing date .
 The examination fee is $15 including reports for up to three medical colleges . The exam fee includes reports from up to 3 medical colleges.
 The tests will be given at Colorado College and other established testing centers listed in the October 29, I960 announcement . Colorado College is listed as an established testing center .
 The test is designed to measure general academic ability, understanding of modern society and scientific knowledge . The test was designed to test general academic abilities .
 Those interested are to apply early as no application can be guaranteed acceptance after deadline . Applicants are advised to apply as early as the application is not guaranteed acceptance .

 The program is open to college men and women graduates mainly in the humanities and social sciences . Each elected fellow receives a $1500 stipend for living expenses plus full tuition and family allowances .
 The program is designed to encourage college seniors of outstanding ability to study for advanced degrees with faculty jobs as their goal . The Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation is administered by a $24,500,000 five year grant .

 The Colorado College International Relations Club and German Club are co-sponsoring a talk by Mrs. Kiep of the German Embassy Speaks on Berlin . The talk will be held at Colorado College .
 She will speak on the topic, ""Berlin/' on Thursday, October 20 at 4:15m. in the Shove Chapel Lecture Room .
 Kiep is Women's Affairs Secretary of the German Colorado College Embassy in Washington . She is the secretary of the embassy in Washington, D.C.
 This position was newly created in the German Foreign Service in 1051 and Mrs. Mrs. was the first woman to hold the position in the Foreign Service .
 Her husband was a leading figure in the German resistance movement against Hitler . She was married to a leading German resistance leader .
 Hitler was executed in the Nazi purge that followed the July 20, 1044 attempt on Hitler's life . He was executed .
 She was one of those who realized that the future of German democracy would depend on the extent of German women associated themselves with public affairs in postwar Germany . When the time came for rebuilding Germany, she realized that she would be a role model for women .
 Kiep's primary function in the U.S. is to maintain close contact with American women in public life and American women's organizations .

 This question dealt with the defense of Formosa and the islands of Matsu and Quemoy . This question was asked about Formosa's defense of the islands .

 It is really too bad that both men could not have been as specific on all issues discussed as they were on these I have enumerated .
 Both men desire the presidency because they believe that their ideas are the best for the American people as a whole . However, both men are faced with the necessity of playing politics .

 The history of this hemisphere as it exists today, begins circa 2 A.G. with the old woman who lived in a shoe . Oaaaock Spengler, Tornybee. and Oasock .
 She had so many children she didn't know what to do so she moved most of them into a shoebox . Most of the children were so small she had to put them in a shoepox .
 They adjusted well to shoebox living because they were represented on the Snowshoe Board which made it very democratic and everyone always lives well in a democracy . They adjusted very well to living because of the board's representation .
 Most of the children adjusted so well that most of them lived in the shoebox for 3 years . Most of them spent the third and last year at the centre of their education . The children adjusted well enough to live in a shoelace for three years .
 You could pretty much determine if you wanted to live in the toe or the heel and if you were really lucky you got a bit of sole all your own . If you were lucky enough you got to live with your own, you could live in your own shoe .
 Your bedtime was a little later than the younger's which meant they really looked up to you . And to top it off, your bedtime would be later than your younger's . 'Your bedtime is a little late,' she said .
 The third year children still knew that Someone cared and if you got that ""emergency long-distance phone call"" the old woman in her pink and yellow slip would run upstairs, downstairs, all thru the town to give you that message .
 There is only one thing that doesn't seem true to life in this history — there were no wars . There is no wars. There was no wars, and there was no peace. There were no war. There are still wars.
 This was Mother Gooseville . But then this shouldn't be so strange; after all, this was Mother gooseville .
 But that day and those people and those cares are little more than myths now . The day and the cares of those who were there are now mythic now .
 No one lived like that ever, except maybe during the backwards times of the Spartans or Russian communists . You'd laugh and say that no one lived that way ever . No one has ever lived in such a backwards way, except the Spartans and Russian communists.
 You can go over to the new reference library, the one down on Pikes Peak and Cascade, and somewhere you'll find all the old papers and things and can read about it for yourself . You can also find the old reference library .

 He pointed out that all have problems and are organized with a core of experts . He said that all of the world's problems are organized and have problems .
 It needs .bureaucracy for the high standards of living that the organization makes possible . The organization needs bureaucracy for the living standards it makes possible, says CEO .
 As long as people want production of automobile, we will have big organizations and their as,"" Dr. Dr. says . "As long as we want production, people will want big organizations"

 All big organizations have thenselect corps of experts and man who make the decisions . All big corporations have then select corps of . experts and . man who makes the decisions.

 The U.S. has benefited from big corporations and their big production, but who controls the power of these rporations? Dr. Dr. John Sutter says the United States has benefited .

 GMG New Poetry Workshop ' starts Tiies., Oct. 30 . Do somethin; with your campus center .
 A series of poetry workshop sessions to be held monthly for the remainder of the 19-10-61 academic year is being planned for all CC students interested in composition of poetry .
 The workshop grew out of interest shown by students in the Writers' Workshop Week held recently at CC . The workshop will be led by Dr. Dr. Michael Lister, who will lead it .
 The workshop will have no official connection with either the English Department or any particular ASCC publication . It will be devoted solely to analysis and discussion of poems written by workshop participants .
 Poems to .be discussed should be left at Rastall desk by the Thursday evening before the workshop . Poems should be submitted to be discussed by the end of the week .
 The poems will be mimeographed and copies will be available at Rastall desk on Friday evening . The poems .will be available to be read at the end of the evening .
 Future dates for workshop meetings are tentatively scheduled for December, January 10, February 21, March 14, April 18 and May 16 .

 The design of Colorado College's new library has been completed by the Chicago firm of Skidmore, Owings and Merrill . Sunken Courts will be the largest library in the country .
 The first level will be below ground and will contain a core of book stacks surrounded by two seminar rooms, a smoking study, a microcard reading room, a typing room and several lounges . The second level will contain two seminars rooms, two microcard-reading rooms and a
 The main floor will be enclosed jy four glass walls and will house the card catalog, the circulation e desk, the reference irea, a periodical room and the new Jbook shelf . The new J book shelf will be located in the main floor of the building .
 The rest of the loor will be devoted to technical work \ spaces and the librarian's iffice . The librarian will be in charge of the library .

 Levels ""11 also contain the special collections rooms, four conference rooms and a typing room . These levels ""11" are located in the basement of the museum .

 To the east of the building will be a sunken garden court flush with the lower level of the library . The garden court will be flush with a lower level library's lower level .
 Floor space in the new building will be approximately 48,000 square feet compared to Coburn Library's 13,000 sq. feet . Floor space will be about 48,00 square feet .
 This ^increase will provide space for iOO.OOO volumes and seating for )00 readers . The increase in size will also increase the size of the iOOO .

 Olin Hall, Colorado College's proposed science building, was designed by the Houston, Tex., firm of Caudill, Rowlett, and Scott . The proposed building would be the first of its kind .
 Palmer Hall's outer architecture is designed to blend with the solidarity of Palmer Hall and yet give the impression of modernity . The outer architecture of the building will blend with Palmer Hall . Its outer architecture has been designed for the purpose of modernising .
 The lecture room will be surrounded by a cantilevered platform 10 feet above ground level . It will have a lecture room surrounded by the platform . The platform will be 10 feet higher than ground level.
 The first level will be devoted to storage space, classrooms, and service areas . The first floor of the building will be dedicated to classrooms, storage space and classrooms .
 Chemistry classes and laboratories will be found on the third level . Biological sciences will reside on the fourth floor of the building .
 Also on the fourth floor will be a greenhouse and housing facilities for the Warren-Aikens collection, a research co-collection of animals found in the Rocky Mountain region .
 Olin Hall will be an artistically pleasing addition to the campus as well as a function one . The new hall will be the first of its kind to be built at the University of Columbia .
 It has been designed with both the science and non-science major in mind . It is designed to be both a science major and a non-Science major .
 The interior of the building will be furnished with this wide diversity of users in mind, but the overall effect will be one of unity . The interior will be decorated with a wide variety of users, but it will be designed to reflect the diversity .

 ASCC must serve to survive . Unless the ASCC as an organization, furthers the goals of each student to succeed in reaching his goals, it is sealing its own fate .
 Students' goals are not as diverse and polyglot as one might imagine, for if one measures the long term, more general goals of each student and disregards some immediate, very transient goals, one will find a great similarity .
 Most of the CC student body, in coming to CC, has declared itself, at least implicitly, as favoring the ideal of the WHOLE MAN . The ideal is the broadly and liberally educated person, the broadly, educated person .
 This broad education does not solely mean an appreciation and education in the various academic disciplines, but very definitely infers an education from A to Z from Asquith to Zen . This includes an appreciation of the academic disciplines .
 A mature person is a person who has realized both his potentialities and his limitations . The idea is that a college, especially one like ours, should turn out a mature person . The college should be able to turn out an 'adult person'
 Each student surely expects some measure of success in at least one of them, and if he is a voluntary member of this liberal arts school, the chances are that he wants quite a bit of success .
 The idea behind our government, as behind all governments, is that the function of government is to do for the people that which they cannot do as well for themselves . The idea of our government is that it is to help the people, as well as themselves .
 The goal of ASCC is helping to fulfill for each of its constituents, the goals he has set, or is setting for himself . ASCC's goal is to help to fulfill the goals of each member of the board .
 It should readily be agreed that without ASCC the individual would experience more difficult attainment of his goals . ASCC is a non-profit organisation that helps individuals achieve their goals .
 ASCC is either not doing its job, or else has lost its justification for existence . If not, ASCC should not be doing their job . ASCC has been criticised for its lack of transparency in recent years .
 ASCC then, if it accepts the above, must consider everything that comes before it in that context . The ASCC must also consider everything else before it comes to an ASCC decision .
 Student goals are defined as whether or not an event or action will directly or indirectly aid the fulfillment of student goals . That is whether the student's goal is to fulfill it, or not it will aid the student goals of the school .
 The various committees of ASCC have been set up to insure that proper attention is paid to special areas, to wit, the social, the intramural, the publications, publications, the curriculum, and committees .
 Other committees of ASCC, constitution, goals and election are striving most particularly to insure that the ASCC develops the necessary efficiency to be effective .
 The finance committee has the responsibility of financially sponsoring and promoting those activities that the students want, or should have, say the students .
 The enthusiasm and communications committee has the most responsible administrative position of all . It must seek to create and promote an atmosphere and climate where each student will want to be a significant and contributing member of the ASCC in its full sense .
 The area in which ASCC has the most indirect power, and the least direct power, is in the area of the ex-officio . The area of ASCC's most direct power is the area where ASCC is located . ASCC also has the least indirect power in the
 The various ex-officio, almost wholly autonomous bodies of ASCC are to a great extent laden with responsibilities that are implicitly given to ASCC in its guardianship of the student college welfare . ASCC is in charge of the students' welfare .
 ASCC serves as a watchdog for student interests in these areas . The power and responsibilities of these groups are best left where it is best left . ASCC should serve as an independent watchdog for students' interests .
 In sum, let it be said that ASCC has the heavy responsibility of the welfare and freedom of all the students in all the corners of campus life . ASCC is responsible for the welfare of the students at all levels .
 ASCC has no more than a watchdog role in those areas where students are able to insure their own welfare . ASCC is a watchdog for students' welfare, not just students .
 The ASCC must take corrective action in those areas where student interests are being abused, or left unfulfilled, says Gary Gappert . The student interest is being abused in some areas, he says .

 We maintain that the presence of a college is good for a community as a whole, as we are, in a sense, in the culture business . We are in a culture business, and we are in the college business .
 It is particularly in its offerings in the public arts that the college carries on its task of bringing culture to the community . Music, the drama, fine art and fine art, the radio station, public lectures, etc. etc.
 Fine Arts Center is the biggest single feature of the college's public arts program . The Fine Arts center is the largest in the university's public art program .
 The Hirschhom collection of modern sculpture is without a doubt the finest of its kind in the world . The community owes the Center a debt of gratitude for the opportunity to see it .
 "While these may be fine pictures (or, given a set of values characterized by a certain absence of taste, they might be so considered," they might not be considered . They are not art, and have no business in the offerings of an institution ostensibly devoted to art, he says

 Instead of watching cautiously for things which will sell, the theater should produce things which are too risky for Broadway or even Civic Theater production . It should take advantage of this fact, and should produce risky things too risky .

 Governor narrowly escaped the anger of an unruly mob which besieged him in Palmer Hall . In fact, the governor of Colorado narrowly escaped .
 In May of 1894, an organizer of the Western Federation of Miners by the name of John Calderwood precipitated a strike in the Cripple Creek basin . The strike soon developed into a class war, with miners fighting for their lives .
 Governor David H Waite sent the Colorado Militia, under the command of Thomas J Tarsney, to the Cripple Creek district to enforce law and order .
 Governor Waite was a vociferous Populist, as was General Tarsney, and their idea of justice was not that of the mine owners in the district .
 After a cooperative endeavor between the militia and the striking miners gave the appearance of law and order, the militia was recalled .
 Several hundred miners held Bull Hill, crowned by the camp of Altman, as a military force . Altman's camp of miners held the hill as a defense force .
 Sheriff Bowers, of Republican EI Paso County, lined up an army of ""deputies"" which was composed mostly of ex-policemen and ex-firemen from Denver who had lost their livelihood at the behest of Governor Waite .
 During the violence that ensued, William S Slocum, CC president, was asked to go to the Cripple Creek district to try to obtain a settlement . During the violent incident, the CC president tried to get a settlement from the district .
 Governor Waite again decided to take action after the situation worsened . Waite says he will take action when the situation worsens .
 He himself decided to obtain a settlement favorable to the miners . But this time, he decided to get the miners a settlement .
 The governor went to the district and was given full power to negotiate for the miners . The governor has been given full control of the district .
 This was not a particularly desirable situation as far as the mine owners were concerned . This is not the first time a mine owner has been involved in a mine disaster .

 Fall Lectures Give View of New World Man inhabits a new world, according to the conclusions drawn by the participants of the faculty lecture series, concluded October 27 by Dr. Dr. David Perry .
 Man's new world is not new in a physical sense but in a cultural and intellectual sense, says the author . He says it is not a physical world but a cultural, intellectual sense . The new world has been created by a new generation of people, he says .
 The lecture series, entitled ""The Consequences of Complexity and Communication," featured Dr. Dr. John Sutter . Dr. Sutter was a member of the lecture series .
 He stressed the need to further the documentation and distribution facilities of our country so that senseless duplications will not occur . He stressed that further documentation is needed to ensure that duplications do not happen .
 The community of scientists must also be able to keep in touch with each other, and not get misled by the jargon of the various disciplines, scientists say . Scientists must also not get misleading by jargon, they say .
 Man is forced to become a specialist in his own field, and his capabilities are no longer able to meet the demands of being universally informed . Man's capabilities no longer meet the needs of being universal informed .
 Both Snyder and Arnest mentioned the new aid provided to man by various electronic memory devices but these do nothing to help man synthesize new thesises from the data being collected around him .
 Arnest asked the searching question of whether or not the i n a t e capabilities of man could be improved through genentics . Arnest asks the question: Whether man's capabilities can be improved by genentic drugs .
 Bodermann, on being asked of the value of our small school in the big world, replied that such schools are the periphery of the new world . Those in attendance by exposing them to fields in the humanities in which they can flee momentarily for relief, he said .
 Will the people flock to art, as the Beats did, and use art as a permanent escape from our new world? Will art be a place for both the rich and the elite to commute?
 The small school, it seems, holds the answer to what kind of leadership our new world will have . The school is a small community of small people .
 Snyder mentioned the need for colleges and universities to encourage more students to study our new world . Snyder also said colleges should devise ways and skills of better documentation and assimiliation of new data .
 Bodermann proposed that bureaucracy, with its widespread influence, and relatively small concentration of power, is not inherently bad because it does bring many benefits with it . He said bureaucracy is not necessarily bad, but it brings many benefits to it .
 It becomes bad only when individuals are kept from being an effective part of it, says CNN.com's John Sutter .

 In reading Mr Racey's letter last week I agree with his thesis that the radio station is under the impression that we are competing with any of the local broadcasters in output of drivel or anything else for that matter . But I can't agree that the station's statement that the .
 KRCC has consistently programmed for the past 10 years of our existence over 50% of its air time on cultural activities . KRCC is known for its cultural activities, including cultural events, and has been programming for 10 years .
 This year they include classical music, opera, BBC tapes and freedom and authority . Shove Chapel, the Sunday morning sermon, is produced by eight members of faculty .
 We average 46 hours on the air weekly and of this over 20 hours devoted to cultural broadcasts . Of this, 20 hours are devoted to the cultural broadcasts. We are dedicated to cultural broadcasting .
 The remaining hours are devoted to public service (news, debates, lectures, special features and interviews with prominent people) and what Mr Racey in his ""highbrow"" attitude probably objects to, popular music .
 We, as every radio station in the U.S. play this pop music, which may disgust Mr Racey, because the majority of students on campus want to hear it, he says . We play music that may disgust him, but he says, "because of the students on
 KRCC's function is to train students who may want to go on into professional radio when they finish college . KRCC also trains students who want to be professional radio students .
 This means that the student must learn how to run a Disc Jockey Show, write the scripts, commercials and other lowly mundane trivia that is required in the professional field .
 KRCC is proud of the students who have gone on into this field and have made a success of it . "This can only be learned by practice, not by theory," says KRCC .
 We do program the BBC tapes and we would enjoy airing more of them along with the the the countless other ""canned"" shows that are available to us . We students must team more than how to run a wireless tape recorder or record player .
 KRCC will allow you all the time on the air that you wish if you will care to put on a series of programs to raise our cultural level to your cultural level . However, in all fairness to you Mr Racey, KRCC does not allow you the time you wish .

 Despite ominous threats of war, mankind may be nearer to true peace than most people suspect . Dr. Glenn Gray discusses ways of war and peace in his new book, "War and Peace"
 Glenn Gray is professor of philosophy and head of the Philosophy Department at Colorado College . He is also a professor at the University of Colorado .
 He made his observation in the lead article of the October issue of the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists .
 The title of the article article is based on the final chap> ter of his book, ""The Warriors; Reflections on Men in Battle,"" which was published last year .
 Dr. David Frum says Armageddon may not be a certainty . Admits that it is speculative to believe Armageddon is not a certainty, Dr. Frum said .
 Gray wrote, ""One may wonder if men could not be lastingly untied by great expectations, great adventures, and great projects," Gray wrote . Gray wrote: "One may question if men can not be . untied"
 "If through listening devices, already in operation, or space exploration we establish communication with other beings, the effect will be profound,"" wrote Dr. Dr. John Defterios .
 The change to peace would be great because man has always had war and has even glorified war, Dr. Dr. David Cameron says . Dr. Cameron: "Man has always been war, and has glorified it"
 Even allowing for for a certain exaggeration in the literature about war, Dr. Dr. John Sutter says the war was 'inevitable' Dr. Sutter: "Even allowing for an exaggeration, the war is not without exaggeration"
 War has made many men feel more alive than any peace we have so far devised, says Gray . Gray said war has made men feel 'more alive' than any other peace ever devised .
 Gray added, "For the ordinary man of Western society the twentieth century has provided security from want and physical comforts to an extent unheralded in earlier times" Gray said .
 It has hardly fulfilled other needs of his, less clamorous needs, but perhaps equally important . It's hardly fulfilled his other needs, he says, but it has also fulfilled his own .
 "I refer to the needs of adventure, of risk, and hardship in the search for personal significance by way of supra-personal goals," says the author of the book .
 "I think that the nation which finds the courage to risk greatly in the cause of peace will not only be educationally advanced, but also religiously aware of man's intimate connection with the rest of creation,"" Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. says .
 The realization that we are not alone in the vast cosmos would have on some of us at least, a greatly cheering effect . It would be a great cheering effect for some of the world's most curious people .

 The Out Post is a somewhat intricate dinner spot in Colorado Springs, Colorado Springs . It is located on the outskirts of town at a somewhat elaborate restaurant .
 In a setting of the gay nineties, with old-time piano and all, The Out Post has an atmosphere that is rare for most clubs and a menu that meets the standards of the finest gourmet .

 Kennedy won in the three most populous Catholic states of Massachusetts, Rhode Island, and Connecticut . But he also carried the four most heavily populous Protestant states of North Carolina, West Virginia, South Carolina, and Georgia .

 CC's Lynn Vincent is a sophomore from Casper, Wyoming . Leading the CC Homecoming parade is only one of the many pportunities in baton twirling .
 Miss Vincent ranked first in the Wyoming state competition for six years and placed seventh in the entire nation in 1959 . Miss Vincent also placed in the Variety Show and the Homecoming rally and bonfire .
 Since she entered college, Miss Vincent has dropped out of competition because of the hours of practice necessary to keep in shape . Miss Vincent says she wants to compete again because of her lack of practice .
 Miss Vincent is listed in "Who's Who in Baton Twirling" as a judge and teacher . She is paid up to $40 a day for judging and teaching .

 Roosevelt Collins, Colorado College's wellknown athletic trainer, received an award Saturday . Collins received the award during the halftime ceremonies .
 Louis T Benezet, president of the college, made the presentation of the plaque and a transistor radio as a token of the recognition . Louis T
 Collins has been trainer at Colorado College for 23 years . Collins has had as much to do with shaping of the spirits of CC players as he has thenbodies .
 Collins is one of the most welt known and respected athletic trainers in the country . A one-time pre-medical student, Collins is now one of America's most respected trainers .
 He has one of tlie best sets of hands in the business, but even more important is his vast knowledge of how to take care of injuries . He has a vast knowledge about how to deal with injuries .
 He not only takes care of CC athletes, but the faculty and staff, and often thenfamilies . He also cares for the faculty, staff and staff .
 Physical therapy practice extends to assisting one of Colorado Springs' leading orthopedists . His physical therapy practice also includes assisting an orthopedist .
 A former CC player, who also played service ball, says ""Rosie"" is the best knee man in the country .
 If Collins does anything better than taking care of the physical and mental pains of his athletes, it would be cooking . Collins is known for his cooking .
 Collins is known affectionately to everyone as ""Rosie,"" a nickname for Roosevelt . Collins is affectionately known as "Rosie" by everyone in the public .
 President Roosevelt was born 56 years ago in Baton Rouge, Louisiana . His mother named her only son Roosevelt in honor of the president .
 He and his wife have a daughter, Natalie, now married and living in California . He and her daughter are still married .
 After high school he went north to try to obtain his youthful ambition . He went to North America after high school to pursue his dream .
 "Things were tough for me, and so I had to quit there,"" he said . "But things were tough ... but things were . tough for him, and he had to . quit there"
 Collins had to give up his desire to be a doctor . He was determined not to go back to Louisiana without some sort of professional training . Collins had given up his dream of being a doctor, but was determined to return .
 Collins still holds a job at Colorado College . The athletic director there helped Collins land his next job, the one he still holds at Colorado .
 When Collins came to CC in the fall of 1935 he brought with him his knowledge, experience and hands . Collins came with him with his knowledge and experience .
 With equipment, and personality, he went to work and today he probably is one of the most widely-known men on the CC campus .
 Sometimes he is remembered by graduates after those former students have forgotten many of their professors . Sometimes graduates forget many of those professors, sometimes they forget them .

 William Jackson Palmer, 18361907; Union cavalry General, pioneer railroad builder, prophet of Colorado's greatness . Palmer died in 1836 at the hands of a Colorado woman .
 He mapped the route of three transcontinental railways, supervised the building of the first road to Denver, organized and constructed the State's industries, cherished its beauties, founded Colorado Springs, fostered Colorado College, and served our Sister Republic of Mexico with sympathy and wisdom .
 This inscription reveals the General's career of accomplishment and something of his characit's easy as P.V. to recognize true diamond value .
 Only Artcarved offers P.V.P.P the exclusive Permanent Value Plan . The plan gives guaranteed proof of the enduring volue of any ring you choose .

 Many volumes could be written about the undertakings and the personality of General Palmer, General Palmer .
 I shall, however, confine this article to a brief discussion of the last years of the man's life which, I hope, will give the reader an insight to his character . I shall not reveal how much of his life was spent in his last years .
 At the turn of the century, General Palmer ended his business career with the sale of the Rio Grande Southern Railway and his interests in Denver and Rio Grande .
 He did not end his active life, and the benevolences which he poured out to this community during those ensuing years still have great meaning to us here . He poured out his benevolence to the community during his years, but he did not .
 Among others, he gave Monument Park, Palmer Park, land for the Public Library, the landscaped parkways, the High-line Drive, and Palmer Hall .
 It is said that he could have had a brilliant career in politics — there is much evidence that this is true — but that his dislike of public functions and of public speaking kept him from seeking high office .
 He spent his years of retirement at Glen Eyrie, at the mouth of Queens Canyon . He spent most of his retirement at the site .
 There he read widely and carried on voluminous correspondence with friends and business associates . He also had a large library of books, magazines and journals .
 Mr Hamlin Garland by name has left accounts of Glen Eyrie and also of a camping trip . General's extravagance was easily seen in the great stone mansion and formal gardens .
 Each day a programme was laid out in ""orders"" issued in due form by the head of the expedition, and this arrangement held . This arrangement held.
 On October 27, 1906, the General was thrown from his horse near Glen Eyrie . The General died of his injuries in the fall .
 A man of his age might well have succumbed to a broken neck, but not William J Palmer . Palmer died at the age of 50 on Sunday . Palmer's funeral was held in New York City, New York .
 His active life commenced once again, although he was now paralyzed from the waist down . He was paralyzed from his waist down, but his active life resumed .
 The two events late in his |jf show most clearly the qualities of generosity, ization, and extravagance ai humane and indeed, a touching ture . The events show the generosity of generosity and ization .
 After his paralysis prevei him from riding and hiking, he had a large st^a, car specially fitted with a bed . It was not an uncommon sight in the hills around Glen Eyrie to see ft General's car, loaded with servant > 01 and children, making its

 Mr Shockley was one of 21 American school superintendents who recently made a trip to the Soviet Union . The trip was sponsored by American Association of School Administrators .
 The group spent more than three weeks in the Soviet Union . They traveled extensively in the Russian, Ukrainian, Georgian and Lithuanian Union Republics .
 The major cities in which they inspected schools were Leningrad, Moscow Tbilisi, Kiev, Kiev and Vilna . The children's school was inspected by the Russian government .

 The assembly was held Tuesday, November 22, in Perkins Hall . Brainwashing was the topic discussed in the assembly .
 Panel members include Gler Brooks of the Political Science hov Department, Lt. Membe of the University of Cambridge . Membe was the first member of the panel .
 Arthur Decker of the Military Science Department and Professor Carl Roberk of the Psychology Department . Professor Roberk is also a psychology professor .
 Roberts defined brainwashing as a negative term for extreme forms of control . Roberts defined the term brainwashing in the book .
 Many such attempts go on in society, but brainwashing is an extreme and undesirable form of this . Brainwashing is a form of an attempt to brainwash people, says the author of the book .
 The Communists achieved a small amount of control in 95 per cent of the American prisoners in the Korean War .
 They brought this about by utilizing the re-enforcement 6t motivational variables and through intense stimulation (punishment | and deprivation) They brought about by . utilizing . re-enforcing 6t . variables and . intense stimulation .
 The prisoners' pei'ception and discrimination were decreased, and when complete control of the environment is present there is no limit to the possibilities . The prisoners were able to control their pei’ception .
 The military hopes that such i situation as Korea, never happen again and it will try to maintaii itself so that it does not happen again . The war was sudden, the training hasty and the education level of the men was ninth grade .
 A code of conduct for military personnel has been devised to confirm American standards and beliefs . If il should, it should be a code for American military personnel, it would confirm their beliefs .
 The fact that behavior is irrational anil change can't be accepted must be accepted, says CNN.com's John Sutter .
 The fanatic nature and effectiveness of Communist ideology must also be accepted, says the author of the book . Author: "The fanatic nature of Communism must be accepted"
 The Communists even use brainwashing to train their own leaders and agents . The Communist Party uses brainwashing techniques to train its own leaders .
 Our citizens should be armed to resist mass persuasion — brainwashing . Mr Brooks suggested an effective counter resistance .
 Our society should concentrate on the facts that make values less firm. We would then be better able to resist the Communists . We would be better than he could resist the Communist Party.
 Professor Roberts concluded that rational education will not work by itself . There is not enough emotional conditioning concerning our country, flag and principles, he said .
 A patriotic reaction is not learned rationally as walking and talking are, and it is unfortunate that flag waving is looked down upon . Flag waving is a reaction not learned as much as walking or talking .

 :ing, the art or sport of fighting with a foil, sabre or epee, originated from the word meaning to protect or defend . The office is closed on Saturdays . :ing is a form of fighting known as foil or sabre .
 Today we know it as a game of out-witting the opponent, as well as one of skill and precision . It is now known as the game of chess, not just chess, but it is a skill-based strategy .
 The challenge comes in ""feeling out"" your opponent, determining how fast and what wav he will react . The challenge is to feel out your opponent .
 There is also the everpresent challenge of perfection — perfection in hand movement, point control and footwork . There are also the challenges of perfection .
 The many attacks and combinations of attacks have just as many parries to go with them . The many combinations of attack have just a few parries going with them.
 A bout is made up of a series of such actions, both offensive and defensive . A bout can be made of a number of actions, such as both offensive or defensive actions .
 The bout is scored by the number of successful touches made on the opponent . The bout was scored by a successful touch score of the opponent's successful touches .
 Each bout is a new learning experience — psychologically, physically and mentally . But each point, won or lost, represents the experience of facing a new personality on the sti-ip .
 There are many puzzles in fencing left unsolved in each fencer's life-time — and each different for the individual fencer . Fencing is a form of mystery in fencing, with many unsolved puzzles left unsolved .
 The added beauty, grace and poise, and smoothness of lines and strokes make fencing truly an art . But the added beauty and grace of fencing is also added to the artistry .

 KRCC began as a two room public address system in the basement of Bemis in the old Cogswell Theater . KRCC was the only local radio station at that time, with occasional interviews with KVOR .
 Tyree Tyree was able to build a radio station, bpth in a tangible, physical and in an intangible sense . Tyree's varied experience includes carpentry, college teaching and carpentry .
 CC acquired several GI buildings from Peterson Field, including South Hall, among them South Hall . CC acquired a number of buildings from the field .
 In 1947 KRCC was able to move into a remodeled South Hall and have their own studio . Thomas Rawles, at that time treasurer of the college, arranged to provide the station with some extra money .
 KRCC went on the air in 1951 when the station went on Ctly from its own studios and rely on transmitter, via telephone lines, to the stations downtown . This w the air with its own transmitter .
 Since 1951 KRCC has undergone many minor improvements aided by the time, efforts, and money of many others . KRCC was founded in 1951 .
 The last major innovation for KRCC came just recently with the transfer of the radio studios to the new Rastall Center .
 ASCC provided funds to extend broadcasting lines from Perkins to Rastall . Herbert Schubnrth, chief engineer for KRDO, provided invaluable technical assistance .
 "Everybody benefits from Benezet, and KRCC is no exception," says Tyree Tyree . The KRCC says it is "no exception"
 Now that the station has become full grown, it only needs to consolidate its position . The station is now a full-grown force in the world .

 The fraternities were unable to decide upon a plan workable and acceptable to all concerned . Fraternities have been unable to agree upon a solution to the situation .

 It is true that the installation of deferred rush is receiving its major impetus from the administration . A case can be made against the administration for telling a student body what it will do .
 There has been little concerted effort on their part to present views opposed to those of the administration, or even to define their own values . However, the case against the student government bodies is even stronger .

 Dr. Brown Receives NSF Research Grant of §12,800 to Dr. Robert Brown . The award is part of a research grant of $12,000 to Brown .
 The grant is to finance research on the effects of behavior changes in patterns of energy flow in populations of mice .
 The research is a combination of field and laboratory work and will extend over a period of approximately three years . The research will be conducted over the next three months .
 It is the most recent in a series of studies he has conducted over the past 12 years on the forces controlling populations of small animals .
 Charles Mierow recently collected a royalty check on a book he had published in 1915 . Charles is a professor of languages at Colorado College .
 Mierow translated the book into modern American-style English from the original Latin .
 The book is now being published in England by the English publisher, Speculum Historiale .

 He came to Colorado College in 1916 after teaching at Princeton for seven years . He was a teacher at Colorado College .
 It was published last year and was a climax to a life-time of study about St. Paul's life .

 Work began at Colorado College Monday to clear the site for the new Charles Learning Tutt Library . The library is scheduled to be built on the campus during the next year and a half .
 A crew from the CC grounds staff began the job Monday morning by cutting down 12 trees that had to be cleared out before work could begin on the new library . The new library will be the first public library in the city .
 The library will be built at the southeast corner of the intersection of San Rafael Street and Cascade Avenue . It will be on a site now occupied by West Hall, which is located on the corner of West Hall .
 West and East Halls have been sold to the Boyce House Moving firm of Pueblo, which will move both from the campus by spring .
 East Hall is giving way to a new science building which is scheduled to go under construction this spring . East Hall will be replaced by a science building set to be completed in the spring .
 The library is a gift of the El Pomar Foundation which gave CC $1.25 million for the building . The library was designed by the architectural firm of Skidmore, Owings and Merrill .
 The new science building is a gift of the Olin Foundation which gave the college approximately $1. million last year . Oificial ground ceremonies were held at Homecoming in October .
 The library and the new science building are part of a $6 million improvement program on the campus . The library, the science building and the library are among the new buildings .
 Funds for the improvement program are being raised by the Colorado College Campaign . Colorado College is raising funds to improve its facilities .

 Each week a different area of study concerning world affairs is taken up by the World Affairs Council . This week's focus is on the role of the Council of State .
 The method of study is to form small groups to meet once a week in someone's home, business, office or shop . Small groups meet in person's homes, businesses or shops .
 After each discussion the participants are provided with opinion ballots and are asked to cast their votes on these important topics . Participants are given an overview of the topics discussed during each discussion .
 The Great Decisions Statistical Center in Boulder tabulates the ballots and sends the results to congressmen and the Department of State . Colorado congressmen, the department of state, send the results .
 A person interested in starting such a group begins by inviting six to 10 other people to join Mm one evening a week for eight weeks . Mm is a group of people who meet weekly for an eight week period .
 Fact sheets, the only expense in a ""Great Decisions"" group, may be bought by students for 75 cents in room 301, Jackson House . Fact sheets are the only expenses in the group .
 These sheets come in a kit containing an introductory booklet, eight fact sheets, eight opinion ballots, reading lists, discussion questions, and discussion questions .
 A Fact Sheet Kit has been made available to all participants . A regular time and place has been arranged for meetings, the group runs itself .
 Newspaper features and radio and television programs will make additional information on the subjects available each week .
 Mr Peter Von Puttkramer will speak on ""Deadlock Over Germany,"" with Mrs. Mrs. Von Putkramer . Mr Von Puttkramer will also speak on "Deadlock over Germany"
 David E Fletcher, Assistant Director of Admissions at Colorado College since his graduation from CC in June 1957, will leave the school March 1 . Fletcher will take a job at the Colorado School of Mines in Golden as business manager of the athletic department and freshman football coach .
 A native of Denver, Mr Fletcher graduated from East Denver High School in 1949 . He played halfback for two years on the football team before enlisting in the Navy .
 He was in the Navy from 1951 to 1954, played football with Navy service teams . In 1953, he was all-Navy while playing fullback with Bainbridge Naval Training Station team .
 In the last game of his career, he set a modern-day CC record by running a kickoff back 83 yards against Adams State College to help CC to a 36 to 8 victory . In the final game, he ran a kickoff 83 yards .

 Colorado College was exposed to a most beautifully articulate spokesman of Christianity . Bishop Stephen Neill is a bishop in the Anglican Church . The lectures were sponsored by the Religious Affairs and Assemblies Committees .
 The list of activities and accomplishments that appears in any thumbnail sketch of this man only serves as reinforcement to the less objective but more vivid impression with which he left his listeners . The list, however, only serves to reinforce to an objective but vivid impression of the man .
 Bishop Neill, the Irish Anglican, the missionary, the publisher, the author, the speaker, showed a charm and a humility which added interest and effectiveness .
 Bishop Neill lectured both formally and informally on various aspects of his Christian career . He dealt with questions of Christian and Anglican theology, missionary work, and the world church movement .
 Four lectures revealed a man, a bishop, who could talk effectively on Christian metaphysics, as he did Sunday at the Shove Chapel service . The bishop also spoke on the ecumenical movement, and on problems and approaches to missionary work in Africa .
 The unifying factor in the series of lectures was not so much in the subjects dealt with, but rather in the manner of presentation . The uniting factor was the presentation of the lectures .
 "Always without notes, he worked into this organization a few jokes, many specific examples of the points he was making marked by subtlety and precision," he said .

 English Opera The opera ""Dido and Aeneas"" is the only English opera of any great merit in a period when many masterpieces were being written in Italy and France . Blow's "Venus and Adonis" is the first English opera to be written in England .
 Handel's operas were not found in England until nearly 60 years later . Not until nearly sixty years later with the operas of George Frederick Handel can anything else be found in English of comparable stature . Handel was the composer of the 18th century's most famous opera,
 26 voices for the Workshop production are drawn from the college madrigal group . The chorus of 26 voices is drawn from 26 voices in the chorus .
 Dance, for centuries an important aspect of opera, is being choreographed by Mr Norman Comick . Dance is an important part of opera and a vital jart of this production .
 The eight dancers assume at different times three identities as court people, witches and sailors . As does the chorus, the chorus must assume different identities as witches and court people .
 The two piano accompaniment will be provided by Mr Jenkins and Miss Jill Tyler .
 Dido, queen of Carthage, and Aeneas, a Trojan prince, destined to found Rome, full in love . Dido was the daughter of Dido and the son of the Trojan prince .
 Aeneas and Dido are both aware that fate has decreed responsibilities for them other than marrying Dido . The prince is confident he can defy his destiny .
 The sorceress and witches, jealous of anyone who might prove both prosperous and happy, know Aeneas' fate . They conspire to send him toward Rome before he and Dido can be married . The sorceresses and witches are jealous and send him to Rome before they can be
 Aeneas deceives him with a mandate to embark immediately for Italy . A spirit, conjured up by the sorceress is disguised as Mercury and appears to be Mercury . Mercury appears to appear to be a spirit, deceiving him to embark on a mission to Italy .

 A woman's disappointment in love was complicated by her pride as a queen who ruled majestically without mistake . Her disappointment was compounded by her desire to be a queen without mistake.

 Professor Richard M Pearl of the geology department at Colorado College has been elected an honorary member of the Canadian Gemmological Association . Professor Pearl is an expert in gemology and geology .
 The organization holds its meetings at the Royal Ontario Museum in Toronto . Incorporated in 1958, the organization was founded in 1958 .
 Pearl Pearl's writings and research on the subject of gems and precious stones . Pearl has published numerous books on gemstones and gemstones .
 Professor Pearl is the second Certified Gemmolog-ist of the Gemmological Institute of America . He is a Fellow with Distinction of Gemmology Association of Great Britain and honorary vice president of the Association of Austi-alia .
 He was elected the first American member of the gemmological association of Brazil . He is affiliated with the national groups of Norway and the Netherlands . He has also been affiliated with Brazil and Norway .
 Pacifism Discussed During Coffee Hour on Thursday, February 9 . Two aspects of pacifism discussed in the WES Lounge .
 Mr Grace started off the discussion by commenting on the religious bases for pacifism . Mr Grace said that pacifism is a form of religion .
 He said pacifism grows out of a way of life based upon love . Not a romantice love, but a love which respects the dignity of other human beings, he said .
 Love of this nature is a creative power which helps one to overcome fear and to lead a life eschewing not only the evil of war but all evil . Love can help one overcome fear, says the author of the book .
 Mr Grace pointed out the inextricable relationship between the New Testament message as found in ""The Sermon on the Mount"" and the idealism of pacifism .
 He implied that the pacifist's ideals are no different than those which form an essential core of Christianity . The pacifist said that pacifism is no different from Christianity .
 Mr Gamer spoke about what pacifists are like, and the various reasons which have motivated them to become pacifists . Mr Gamer also spoke about the reasons for pacifists to be pacifists.
 The religious or moral pacifist adheres to the pacifist ethic of non-violence in all human affairs . The pacifist is a pacifist who believes in non-violent action .
 The pragmatic or nuclear pacifist tolerates violence but does not wish to support a war involving nuclear power . Following the discussion several of the audience began a question and answer session .
 Delegates from 50 other Ameri College and Universities will present at this three day meet . The topic of discussion will bs ""Goals for Americans,"" basi the recent report of the President; Commission on this subject .

 In an interview on Tuesday he stated that ""We must preserve as much of capitalism as we can,"" that we must ""try to check the slide towards socialism,"" and rid the economy of ""make-believe work" that has been perpetuated by laborgovernment colusion .
 President Kennedy can not be criticized for his economic politics because they keep changing from press conference to press conference . He still feels that President Kennedy talks too much of economic groth without consideration for natural resources or the ability of the economy to absord further increases in production .
 He does definitely feel the need for and the . need for meeting ""unmet challenge for building up the nation's social capital"" and in so doing, absorbing at least ten per cent of the . nation's productive energy .
 Growth and employment could then be substained without glutting the market place with unneeded goods . Growth could be subbed into jobs and growth without over-stimulating the market .
 Mr Packard attributes chronic unemployment and poverty stricken areas, which are incongruities in the midst of the waste and gluttony he sees around us, to the part of people refusing to leave depressed areas .
 Mr Galbraith says there is a general laxity of unemployed people to seek jobs in the face of relatively high unemployment compensation checks . He also feels that there is also a laxity in the UK's unemployment compensation system .
 Mr Packard also portends the ""technological revolution"" and the ""baby booms"" as mixed blessings in lems of the American way of life .

 The Rastall Center Board is being expanded from it, present membership of five student members and two fac. ulty members to a membership of seven student members anri two faculty members . The board will also expand from it's present membership to seven .
 Center Board can better fulfill its responsibilities in ""providinga social, recreational, and cultural center"" for the members of the college community .
 Rastall Center Board members serve a term of one year, beginning and ending in March . The positions open for student membership involve the positions of chairman of the board, executive secretary, business manager, director of cultural affairs, and director of hospitality .
 They are selected by the outgoing Board on the basis of their application, a personal interview, and past experience . The outgoing Board selects candidates for the position based on the application, the personal interview and the work experience .
 Other students will have the opportunity to apply for sub-committee positions in the Rastall Center organization . Sub-committees include music, committee, publications, art exhibits, games committee .
 The outgoing board also has plans to conduct a Center Workshop in which they will orient the new board members and their committee members to the problems and responsibilities of the Rastall Center . The Center will also conduct an orientation to the new members of the board .

 The purpose of this essay is to ■auaint prospective parents with disease and the factors in leading a child to be healthy .
 This disease consists of an m ja due to breakdown of the f tal blood and consequently reIts in jaundice . This disease is caused by breakdown of blood and re-birth of the blood .

 When the foetus, the Id embryo, has inherited Rhfcjtive from the father and the |0 ther is Rh-negative, the chance i a harmful reaction between the |‚ther and the foetetile is very Sod. When the baby is born,
 An antibody is a protein with the capacity to neutralize or react with the antigen . Antibodies are antibodies that can react with or neutralize an antigen, such as an antibody .
 The antibodies produced by the mother pass through the placenta and enter the blood stream of the feotus . The antibodies from the mother and the baby are antibodies that enter the bloodstream of the baby .
 A reaction occurs between the antibodies and the antigens resulting in Erythroblastosis fetalis which, in turn, results in anemia and eventually jaundice . A reaction is caused by anemia, anemia .
 Because of the breakdown of the foetal blood, the red-blood cells are immature and consequently do not 'cany sufficient oxygen to the cells of the body'
 Rh-negative and Rh-positive foctors are inherited characteristics . This is an heriditary disease because the Rh negative and Rh positive foctors have inherited characteristics. Rh negative foctors can cause Rh negative or Rh negative characteristics .
 Marriage between two Rhnegative persons yields only Rh-negative children . A combination of Rhnegative people would not result in the disease . Rhnegative children would not be born with Rhnegative .
 The International Relations Club of Colorado College is sponsoring a series of discussions during the coming eight weeks through the Great Decisions study program . If marriage occurs between Rh-positive and Rh-negative or between two Rh-positives, two types of child may not be married .
 Faculty and students discuss world affairs and attempt to reach opinions on these problems . Students discuss the world affairs with faculty and students on campus .
 Opinion ballots are filled out, and the results are sent to the Department of State and members of Congress to be tabulated with others from the United States . Opinion ballots will be filled out and then tabulated in the U.S. with others .
 Only dangerous combination results when the foetus is Rh-positive and the mother is Rhnegative . The only dangerous combination is when the baby is Rhpositive .
 If the foetus is Rh-negative and the mother is . Rh-positive, reaction rarely occurs . If the mother and foetus are Rh-Negative, reaction will rarely occur .
 The first child of a marriage between Rh-positive father and an Rh-negative mother is usually not affected because the mother has not had a chance to develop a sufficient number of antibodies to seriously affect the foetus .
 In successive pregnancies there will have accumulated enough antibodies in her blood stream to affect the foetus . The antibodies can be accumulated in successive pregnancies .
 If the presence of antibodies in the mother's blood stream is detected during pregnancy, the child may be given a complete blood transfusion immediately after birth and may be saved .
 Parents should be aware of their blood factors so that they may be forewarned about the possibility of the disease occuring in their chililies .

 It was felt that the intramural program as it stands develops rivalries which, while good natured, would become intense if there were no college team to which to rally .

 The validity, the ""raison d'etre"" of the armed forces today lies not in its military strength per se, but in its potential value . The validity of the military is not in military strength, but potential value, says the author of the book .

 "Dido and Aenaes" was a success . Stars of this production are Bert Lancaster, Frank Sinatra, Montgomery Gift, Deborah Kei .
 rehearsals began two weeks before the performance . With great anticipation, rehearsals started two weeks ago .
 At this time, no one was quite sure what was to come, yet everyone was determined that this opera would be good . The opera was set to be performed in New York City .
 Within a week, things began to take shape and as parts were memorized a ""feeling"" for the opera took hold . As parts began to be memorized, a "feeling" began to build up .
 The harbor, countryside, and palace of Carthage was built by a busy stage crew . Carthage's harbor and palace were built by the stage crew in Carthage, Carthage .
 Dress rehearsal came and went unarrested and opening night was at hand . Dress rehearsal went off without arrest .
 There was not a full house the first night, but to the performers, the most important objective was a good production, not who saw it . The show is set in New York City, New York .
 There were low spots in the singing, but we must remember that CC is not a conservatory of music and cannot be expected to be professional . There were also some low spots, but the singing was good .
 With an almost full house and with more anticipation and excitment, the second and final night began . The second and third night of the show began .
 In the excitement they forgot their conductor, N Mr Donald Jenkins, and by the end of the second scene had increased the tempo and gotten a half tone sharp . By the end the tempo had increased dramatically .
 Intermission which followed was just enough for the chorus to collect itself and finish the performance in excellent style .
 Aeneas, sung by Mr Harry Booth, had but one aria which was done ■with grace and excellence . Mr Booth, who spent most of his time following Dido on and off stage, sang the aria with grace .
 The greatest achievement in the production of ""Dido and Aenaes"" was the amalgamation of the drama, dance, and music departments . Perhaps the greatest achievement was the amalgamation of the drama and dance departments .
 No one department overbalanced another— the three worked harmoniously to produce an overall feeling of unity . The team was united by a strong sense of unity, not overbalanced one department .
 Many thought the chorus detracted from the soloists when they were singing their arias . Many thought, for example, that the chorus was too distracting .
 It was felt that the lighting of the last scene was perhaps gaudy . Further, it was felt the lighting in the final scene of the play was perhaps too much . It was also felt that it was too much of a spectacle .

 The new plans call for identical interiors in the houses, but to keep the tradition of varied architecture alive on the college campus, the exteriors will differ in facing materials . Exteriors of the houses will also differ in materials .
 Each house will have a full basement with trunk room, laundry room, recreation room and chapter room . Each home will have trunk room and laundry room .
 Living quarters will house 25 men with a variety of singles, doubles and four-man suites . The living quarters will be located in a range of singles and doubles rooms .
 The bulk of the food eaten in the new houses will be rather similar to that eaten in Rastall Center . The kitchens will serve the food in portable tables from Rastalls to the houses .
 These new houses will have all of the advantages of college dormitory living . The new homes will be built in a dormitory style .
 There will be offered'by the college, linen service, ground service, and anything else needed for the upkeep of the houses . The college will also offer linen service .
