 CC Winter Concert Series will present chamber music performed by ensembles from the U.S. Air Force Academy Band . Beguiling next year the women chosen in recent elections will assume duties .
 The concert will be held in Perkins Hall at 4:00m. and will be free to the public . The concert is scheduled to take place at Perkins Hall in London .
 The program will open with the ""Duo in E Flat Major for Two Violas"" by Karl Stamitz, played by Werner Siepenkothen and Gregory Rodgers .
 Stamitz was one of the foremost composers of the Mannheim school of the classical period . Stamitz took a great interest in the viola . He was a leading violist in Mannheim .
 His viola concerto is one of the most renowned works for the viola . It was one of his most famous works for this instrument .
 Following the Stamitz will be a performance of the ""Sextet for Wind Instruments in G Major, Opus 71"" by Beethoven . The performance will be followed by the Sextet for the Wind Instruments .
 This work was published in 1810, during Beethoven's richest period (that of the fifth and sixth symphonies), but it was composed much earlier . This work is published in the 1810 edition of the symphony .
 Beethoven's works of the 1810 period were more serious than his other works . This explains the contrast between his spontaneous and lighthearted mood and the seriousness of his works .
 Performers in this composition will be Mr James Hamlin and Mr Gary Scott, clarinets; Mr Deimas Howe and Mr Samuel Mood, bassoons; Mr Richard Van Sice and Mr Presley Wood, horns . Performers will also be Mr Hamlin, Mr Scott
 The second half of the program, consisting of two modern works, will contrast greatly with the first half . The program includes works from modern composers .
 The first of these will be a work for a quartet of saxophones, an ensemble rarely, if ever, heard in this country . It will be the first work for the quartet, rarely heard in the UK .
 Pierre Dubois was one of the numerous and prolific early twentieth century French composers who were encouraged by the high standards of writing for wind instruments of all types and combinations set by the Paris Conservatory .
 The saxophone is almost completely associated with the jazz idiom in America, but in France the ""legitimate" use of this instrument is widespread .
 Performers in the ""Quatuor pour Saxophones"" by Dubois will be Mr Richard Hubbard, soprano; Mr Wes Adams, alto; Mr Gary Scott, tenor; and Mr Donald Anderson, baritone .
 The program will end with a rendition of the ""Octette for Wind Instruments"" by Igor Stravinsky . The program is scheduled to include a performance of the "octette for wind Instruments"
 This work was completed in 1923, during the composer's change to his so-called ""neo-classical"" style . This work is completed during composer's changes to his style .

 The last few years have seen the recurrence of venereal disease in this country . Jane Carolyn Hult: Venereal Disease has recurrence in recent years .
 For years the disease seemed to be on the decline due to the presence of penicillin and other wonder drugs . For years, the disease appeared to be going on decline .
 It now appears that the population is developing a resistance to drugs in combatting the infection. cause it works on the internal organs .
 If it can be detected in the first stages, the cure is relatively easy but the advanced stages are much more difficult to cure . The advanced stages of the disease are difficult to treat .
 Gonorrhea is equally as serious, causing arthritis, heart disease, liver and kidney problems, as well as arthritis and liver problems . It can also cause heart, liver, kidney problems and arthritis .
 Many people become sterile by this disease, many more than by syphilis . People become sterile more often by this type of disease .
 Evidence of this disease appears from one to several days after contact, according to experts .
 It moves internally in women and is difficult to detect until the woman is sterile . It is then difficult to find out if a woman has a baby . It can only be detected if she is sterile or not pregnant .
 Four-fifths of all women who have the disease are not aware of its existence . The disease is not uncommon in the United States, but is common in Europe .
 The frightening thing about these diseases is that they are not properly reported and treated properly . The scary thing is that these diseases are not being properly reported .
 Victims' contacts are not known, therefore preventing complete control of infection . In many cases the victims' contacts do not know, preventing control of the infection .
 The two most familiar venereal diseases are syphilis and gonorrhea, both of which are caused by bacteria which are transmitted directly from person to person . The only way to prevent wide spread venereals disease is to find CAUSES AND EFFECTS .
 Syphilis is not inherited but can be passed to the fetus in pregnant women who have the disease . Syphilis can also be passed on to the baby in the womb by pregnant women with the condition .
 Silver nitrate is usually put in a new-born baby's eyes to prevent blindness . It is usually used to be put in the eyes of a baby to prevent blindness .
 The primary syphilic leisons appear during the incubation period of six to ninety days . Primary syphilics leisons are incubated for six to 90 days .
 After this time the spirocites, bacteria, migrate into the body and the external infection disappears in about three weeks . The external infection appears in three weeks and the infection disappears .

 Ruth Snodgrass writes to editors of the TIGER . Myles Hopper's letter was published in the February 24 issue of the magazine .
 His criticism of the manner in which the election of the replacement of the freshman class commissioner was run was directed towards freshman class commissioners .
 We would like to say first that the freshman commissioners were in no way connected or responsible for the election . We would also say that the commissioners were not directly involved in the election themselves .
 All elections concerning ASCC are conducted by the ASCC Election Committee . ASCC chairman is fully responsible for the elections .
 Second, he was criticizing the fact that he could not nominate a candidate from the floor because of a restrictive clause in the ASCC constitution which states that no nominations are in order during an election for a vacancy of an office .
 There is all of the contacts and to cure them so that they will not be able to continue spreading the disease . We have no idea where he got this information, but there is all the contacts .
 When it appeared as though doctors had VD under control, many of the health measures were discontinued such as the health clinics devoted entirely to the cure of VD and its detection . The health clinics are now dedicated to curing the disease .
 It is now centered in the age group of 14 to twenty-24 . Most commonly in teenagers 17 and 18 years old .
 It has been predicted that there are more cases among people under twenty then ever before in history . More people under 20 are thought to be at risk than ever before before .
 Thousands of cases are never reported, health department says . Health officials say only the reported cases are only the cases reported .
 Due to the presence of VD clinics in Colorado, the rate in this state has decreased in the last ten years . VD rates have also decreased in Colorado .
 Ann Armstrong: There are 21 states that have shut down all VD clinics . However, there were 21 states where VD was illegal .
 There is an increasing break between "theory and practice" concerning moral standards we apply to sex in the U.S. today .
 ASCC has no such clause in the ASCC constitution in the constitution . This break is evidenced by the fact that ASCC does not have such a clause in its constitution . The ASCC is not the only club in the world to have a constitution .
 If election committee had asked for new nominations it would have been necessary to have had petitions followed by a period of campaigning and posters .
 A special class meeting would have been necessary for campaign speeches and elections . Also a special meeting would be necessary for campaigning speeches and election .
 We are not sayir.g that the election was held in the only possible manner. We are happy to clarify that we are not saying that we did not think that the elections were held in such a manner .
 Next year's elections are to be held in less than two months . The election committee felt that it was the most practical since next year's election is set to take place in just over two months.
 If Mr Hopper was so opposed to the way the election was held, he should have come to the election committee or freshman commissioners before the time of the election .
 He as well as the rest of the freshman class, received letters from the class commissioners explaining the procedure that would be followed in the election .
 They need the backing of the whole class and welcome constructive criticism and suggestions . They need to back them up and welcome criticism from the public .
 Criticism of the type that was in the TIGER, however, suggests motives other than being constructive or helpful . Criticism suggests motives for criticism are not constructive, but helpful .
 Now that we've both stated our thoughts in the TIGER, let's work together. Let's work with each other, we need to work together .
 CC students are more interested in our ability to act than in our writing ability . CC students say they want to be able to act more than write . Students say they are interested in their ability to write more than in writing .

 Last week the TIGER presented a format of three articles on sex . Last week on this page was a format for three articles about sex .
 This was done with somequalms on the part of the editors, not because we felt that there might be retribution, but rather because there might not be any response whatsoever . This is not the first time this has happened, but the last time we have seen this story .
 We did get response; granted most of it was vocal but a few did realize that a paper exists not on words spoken but on words printed . We did not get response to the comments .
 In going through the various letters, the following points seemed to predominate, so it is to these points we shall answer . The following points were the following: The point of the question: What do you think?
 The first and most important item was that our TIGER has not been representing the students, that is, providing full news coverage . The first thing is that the students have been represented is that they have not been represented .
 Second, that last week's paper showed up this lack in the most blatant manner in devoting most of page two to three articles on sex, to the privation of other newsworthy items .
 We would like to answer these three points by taking the last one first . We would rather focus on the first question: 'What do you think? Take it first'
 We feel that the TIGER has the potential to be the one campus institution which could provide full communication . We feel it has the ability to be one of the one institutions which could . provide . full communication, we said .
 By ""full communication"" we don't mean just reporting and pictures; we mean much more . By "full communication" we mean full communication, not just reporting .
 We feel that any student should be able to find himself and the issues in which he is interested within the TIGER each week . For example, any student can find himself in the magazine each week to discuss his interests .
 The TIGER should be a mirror of the whole individual, not just in "Greek News,"" or "Slocum Intra murals,"" not in anything specific but rather the whole . Not just in ""Greek News" or ""Three Little Words,""" or
 We firmly believe that each of these articles was legitimate, otherwise we would not have printed them all . We are happy to clarify that each article was legitimate .
 There were three articles, all in one week, all on one page . Rather it was the fact that there was three articles . All three articles were published in the same week .
 Last week's TIGER would seem to be overwhelmingly devoted to this specific subject . Second, that last week's cover story was about this topic .
 If the TIGER is to fulfill this potential of ""full communication"" and thus represent the student body, this must be done from the bottom up, that is from the students to the paper . As we said above above, we said, the Tiger must not be a fabric
 With a very few notable exceptions, the burden of the TIGER is carried by a staff of a dozen dependables . If this is not a faction in anyone's sense of the word, we don't know what is. We don't see what is .
 We do not think of the TIGER calendar as a run-of-the-mill, entertaining calendar . We think tliis is not in any way representative of the Colorado College Student .
 If the TIGER has been unbalanced, the responsibility is ours; but the cure is up to you . It's up to the people to decide if they want to change their attitude .

 Two important purposes of college or of a liberal arts education are clarity of thinking and articulate expression . Tejon MEIrose 2-0164 Cap & Gown by Betty Burgoon .
 These are obvious and are simply means, instruments in attaining higher goals, they often obscured . Since these are obvious, they are often obscured, they can be used to achieve higher goals . This is especially true in the United States .
 I am often stricken with how effectiveness and impact of communication are not always a function of the quality of ideas, but of the speaker's fluency . I'm often struck with how effective communication is often a result of fluency, not quality of the ideas .
 It becomes frightening to realize that even if one has a great wealth of knowledge he can still be ineffectual without the ability to articulate his ideas . It becomes somewhat frightening to . realize that . even if . one had a great . wealth of . knowledge, he said .
 Many people are unable to express their ideas clearly and precisely . This is extreme, of course, but no one is so poor of expression that he is completely incapable of communicating himself to others, he says .
 It could be said that this can often be attributed to foggy thinking, and that of logical and orderly thinking . This can be said to be the second point of logical thinking .
 Logical and orderly thinking is a skill that necessarily develops with practice . Logical thinking is one of the most important skills in the world .
 There are many academic practices which aid in developing academic skills, but I would like to confine myself to two specifically, writing papers and participating in discussions .

 Time permitting, discussion will follow. ideas and to communicate themselves to others. ideas .
 Students generally have to read somewhat hurriedly through many assignments and hence formulate vaguely the essence of the material and their evaluation of such . Students must also formulate their assessment of such assignments and evaluate them .
 When a more critical analysis becomes necessary, as in paper writing, the student organizes the material in a systematic and orderly fashion . The student begins to sharpen his critical abilities when analyzing material .
 For this reason, I feel papers are an excellent exercise, perhaps much more so than tests because of the time element involved . For example, papers are perhaps more so important than tests as they are time-consuming and therefore difficult to read .
 Tests can precipitate muddled expression when in an attempt to get all ideas down and all of the questions answered, the student scribbles the answers with little opportunity to consider the various possibilities of presentation and expression .
 Oral expression can be improved not only through classroom discussion, but through extracurricular discussion groups . Oral expression should be improved through discussion groups, many of which are organized on campus recently .
 The problem of communication becomes more acute when one has to express himself to people outside his discipline . In these discussion groups various disciplines are usually represented . Topics of discussion require integration and synthesis of ideas from several areas of study .
 The student can develop clarity of thinking and articulate expression through many means, but I have offered these two for particular consideration . The students are encouraged to use these two methods to develop clarity .
 Too often the value of writing papers is overlooked, says author . Too often, too often, discussions are underestimated, he says .
 If college students are to be influential members of society, they must be concerned with the development of these skills . College students must consider the various means of doing such .
 The girls on the third floor of Loomis Hall deserve recognition for a project which they undertook last November . Chow Yin Ling and Chow Yong Yin Ling are a foster child at the centre of the project .
 The girls decided to financially adopt a ten year old Chinese girl in Hong Kong . Through the efforts of the floor president, the girls adopted a ten-year-old Chinese girl .
 The Foster Parents' Plan, founded in 1937, has helped more than (500,000 young people . More than 500,000 people have been helped by the plan since then .
 This organization is non-profit, non-propaganda, non sectarian, providing financial aid for orphaned or distressed children .
 She receives $8 in cash and the rest goes into food, clothing packages, translations of letters, medical services and education . The rest of the money goes into clothing packages and medical services .
 Her family is one of the hundreds of thousands of refugee families living in extreme poverty in tiny huts in one of Hong Kong's areas . The refugees are living in poverty in a remote area surrounding Hong Kong .

 She is a bright student and deserves the help she is now receiving from the CC students . She is also receiving help from the students at the school .

 At the discussion concerning athletics at Star Ranch, we felt that the dissenting opinion was not adequately expressed . Charles E Puckett writes to the editors of the Star Ranch Review .
 In this letter, we would like to suggest some ideas and solutions to the athletic problem . In this article, we highlight some of the ideas we have received from the public .
 It was pointed out at the conference that spirit and winning teams are directly related . It was also pointed out that spirit is directly related to winning teams .
 What was not pointed out was the fact that winning teams take a great deal of money . Winning teams win a lot of money, but that's not always the case .
 "We question the validity of losing $50,000 alone, much less the cost of the entire athletic program," says the school . "The cost of losing the entire program is unknown," the school says .
 We condemn the solutions to this problem which we offered at the All College Conference . We condemn them as the solutions we offered to this issue .
 The only value we can see in this suggestion is the decrease in attendance taking . We can only see the value of this suggestion if attendance drops .

 Deadline for application is March 17 . All applicants will be interviewed by the Foreign Student Committee . A mid-April decision will be made .
 It was almost pointed out at the conference that spirit was more important than academics . The conference was held in New York City, New York, last week .
 It is important to realize that spirit is the sum total of many things of which football is just one . Spirit is a part of the spirit of life, not just football, but spirit is a whole thing .
 Spirit may also be achieved through plays, concerts, intramurals, and other such activities which cost far less than the intercollegiate program . Spirit can be achieved by playing, concerts and other activities .
 We feel that the $50,000 could be used in a more beneficial way by broadening of the intramural program and by creating a physical education program which would benefit the entire campus .
 It is our contention that if this happens it will only be due to a failure on the part of the stu.lent body to adjust to a new environment and to create new ideas .

 Fine Arts Center is now displaying the musical instruments of the Pueblos, Apaches, and Navajos of the Southwest .
 One rattle rattle is a large square of leather with pieces of hoof and tin bells placed along the bottom . Another is a leather square with bits of hooves and bells placed on the bottom of it .
 The drums are made of clay and wood; one is an enromous clay pot and another a tree trunk . One is a clay pot, another is a wooded clay trunk .
 Conch shells were imported from the west coast and trumpets were made of them, with clay mouthpieces . The trumpet was made of conch shells, with a clay mouthpiece .
 The musical bow was the first string instrument; next were wooden fiddles with deer sinew for strings . The instrument was made from wooded wooded fiddles made from deer sinews .

 Most important, it proved that this sort of thing can be done at CC and be well supported . Most important is that it proved it can't be done and is well supported by the community .
 Any criticism of this event must be taken in view of the fact that the program was somewhat of the nature of an experiment . Any criticism should be taken into account that the event was an experiment, he says .
 Many of the symposium's deficiencies were apparent through the audience . The symposium was held in New York City, New York .
 First, the audience, save a few who knew the symposium was coming, was not orientated to the problem . The audience did not seem to be interested in the symposia .
 During the five different sessions, most but not quite all of the audience seemed to ignore the subjects selected by the symposium committee and ask those it pleased . Also, during the five sessions, the audience ignored the subjects chosen by the committee .
 This resulted in harrying the speakers and making the whole schedule of the symposium seem disjointed . The symposium was held in New York City, New York .
 There was no opportunity to follow up any of the ideas raised during the week because of the scheduling of exams . Finally, there were no opportunities for follow-up to the ideas discussed .
 The program itself has been under more local fire than any one part of the symposium . The program has been criticized for its lack of transparency .
 Committee had to sacrifice ideas on personnel because of time being short . Fiedler were the best choices, and if time was short, they would be the best .
 Perhaps the best way to get speakers who would work out is to start selecting, interviewing if possible, and deciding early .
 It would seem more fruitful to find some way of informing the campus so as to create the issue chosen for the symposium before the outside speakers arrive . Also, it would seem that it would be more productive to find out what an issue is chosen before the speakers arrive.
 This should help the audience to cooperate with the committee as it plans the themes of each session . The audience will be able to help the committee plan the themes .
 A follow-up program, perhaps based on a synopsis of what was said, could be arranged for beforehand .
 The whole program should be put at a time of year when there is time for students to participate in this follow-up, the author says .
 The symposium is potentially a good thing, contributing more to the campus than any 'Vance Packard' of the past few years . It will be the first time the campus has hosted a symposium in a decade .
 The only way to accomplish even more for next year would be to start organizing now, say organizers . Organizing now would be the best way to get ahead of next year's events .
 Girls Dorm Positions open in girls dorms . Students receive very little recognition for the difficult job that they have .
 At this time of year, when new dorm presidents and counselors must be chosen, it seems necessary to inform the campus of the requirements and responsibilities of these positions . The position is required to be a dorm president .
 This GPA must be maintained throughout the term of office, one year, or the girl is replaced . The girl must maintain the GPA for one year or she will be replaced .
 If her grades fall below this mark at the semester she has until mid-semester to bring them back up . If she falls below the mark, she will be given until midsemesters .
 Usually the sophomores are counselors because they are not as busy as the upperclassmen and therefore have more time to devote to their office . Sophomores will be counselors at the school .
 The dorm presidents also have a 2.2. and are usually taken from the incoming junior class . dorm presidents are usually chosen from incoming freshmen class .
 Girls who are chosen to be counselors and dorm presidents have a very important job . They are counselors, dorm presidents and dorm leaders .
 "It is their duty to help the freshmen women get settled and feel at home here on this campus," says Loyoy .
 Many of the freshman women have never lived in a dormitory and it is a new and often bewildering experience . The dormitory is the largest dormitory dormitory in the U.S.
 In an address by Miss Russell at the conference for new counselors and dorm presidents, Miss Russell said the qualifications and requirements for these positions were stated .
 If a counselor has good study habits and conscientiously does her work, she will encourage her counselees to do likewise . If she has a good study habit, she can be a good counseller .
 A good example does much more toward gaining order out of a chaotic situation than many lectures given at wing meetings . A 'good example' does more to gain order than lectures given to wing meetings.
 By not placing an emphasis on expensive clothing or dating the counselor can relieve pressure in these areas . Don't put too much emphasis on dating or expensive clothing .
 The honor system, an important aspect in dorm life, must be upheld by the counselor . The counselor must also emphasize the honor system in a subtle way in her everyday life .
 The counselor must be able to convey a feeling of individual concern to each member of her wing . Each girl will feel that she has someone to go to when she has a problem . Counselor must convey a . feeling of . individual concern .
 A counselor must be able to give good advice; advice stemming from her own persona] experience . Counseling must be based on her own experience, she says . A counselor can't give advice based on previous experience .
 If her experience does not cover the situation she should direct the girl to someone who can help her, she should tell her to seek help .
 A GIRL MAY be NOMINATED by her resident, her wing, or the dorm council for the position of counselor .
 A girl may apply independently of these means by securing an application blank from one of the dorm presidents . Also a girl can obtain a blank from a dorm president . The application blank can be secured by the dorm president of a girl .

 The Science-Humanism controversy pointed up the problem which lies at the basis of a philosophy of liberal education, namely the reconciliation of an enormous mass of facts and a limited amount of time to understand them . Your cooperation with the above will assure you of your cooperation .
 Leading physicist proposed that an individual should study two subjects, far removed, gaining a deep knowledge in each of these two, as well as an acquaintance with other fields .
 A similar program would be advantageous to some students at CC, humanists as well as scientists . Perhaps a similar program could be beneficial to some of the students .
 One prevalent danger of a somewhat superficial knowledge in fields outside the major subject is the tendency to disbelieve the validity of the study o fthe other fields . One of the dangers of superficial knowledge is that it can be applied to other subjects .
 Some chemists dismiss sociologists as being too broad in their subject matter, while dramatists regard the mathematician as trifling, and so on, ad absurdum . Some socologists are too broad, some chemists are too trifling .
 This disbelief is certainly a closing of a young person's mind to the problemsi of the world, ""a mortal sin, in all the horrible connotations of the word,"" to quote Dr. Dr. John Sutter .
 A deep knowledge of widely diversified fields would help form a bridge for the communication of ideas between fields, for it is only through higher level courses that one finally begins to understand what a subject is really about, and learns to be proficient in its language and concepts .

 A humanist, then, strives to understand the human situation; to this end he may employ a variety of methods . Humanists may employ various methods to understand a human situation, such as understanding .
 In the movement toward this goal, the humanist employs the vigorous use of rationality, a faculty in which he has much faith . He recognizes its limitations in finite man .
 The humanist is much concerned with interpretations relative to the many problems with which Inworks is concerned . He attempts to make distinctions and sensitive, intelligent choices between good and evil, .
 The humanist cannot restrict himself to experimentation within the confines of a laboratory, he says . As a result of the multiplicity of humanistic problems and methods, the humanist is not limited to experimentation .
 Humanist is likely to he a mcliorist, rather than an optimist or a pessimist . Humanist attempts to ""report"" on man as he sees him .
 I suspect that most humanists believe that the goal of man is the attainment of "", . . continuous, supreme, and unending happiness;"" that realization of this goal muy well be beyond the reach of men is a tragedy humanists acknowledge .
 Humanists Ijelicve Unit says the goal is approachable through the seeking of diversified knowledge . The goal is to achieve the somewhat malleable relationship between oneself and one's world, he says .

 The political science department has recommended a series of three pamphlets on the problem of war in nuclear age .
 Not only are the pamphlets on a topic of current interest and controversy, but they are also briefer and more concise than the books on the subject .
 The first of the series, ""Community of Fear"" by Harrison Brown and James Real makes a prediction . The first series of "Fears of Fear" is a prediction of the future of the world .
 The continuation of the war system with its ""explosive technology"" and ""encrusted political and moral concepts"" will result in thermonuclear .catastrophe or fearful retreat at the expense of democratic values .
 The second, ""A World Without War"" by Walter Millis, states that, if the war system were abolished, we could find a pi-acticable international forder for the continued existence of a civilized world .
 The final pamphlet, ""Permanent Peace"" by Walter Millis attempts to examine the questions of power in order to formulate a better theory of national and international power .
 Such a theory might help us make the transition from the world of today to the desired warless world of the future, says the author .
 In this third pamphlet he suggests two solutions to the problem of transition . In this pamphlet he proposes two solutions for the future .
 The relations of the American states might be used as an example of how international power could be organized in the absence of an organized war system . First, the relations of U.S. states should be seen as a model for international power in absence of war .
 These states operate among themselves without war and without a ""world"" government . They operate among each other without war or without a "world" government .
 Second is the realization by the states of the world that the power struggle can be carried on by .means other than military force . The power struggle is carried out by means of other means .
 For example, there are economic pressures, ideological appeals, and subversion . For instance, subversion is a form of subversion in the U.S. and abroad .
 Millis is correct in saying that the Soviet Union really does want disarmament . The Soviet Union may be sincere in its proposals, Millis says .
 The U.S. is just as interested in preventing thermonuclear devastation of the world and redirecting the economic resources committed to the military structure to more productive uses .
 The Soviet Union is also better prepared than the United States for indirect aggression . The United States is better prepared to deal with indirect aggression than the U.S. The U.N. is also prepared for direct aggression .
 The vague concept of Russian ""control"" of the world or of any area needs clarification . He is also correct in saying that the concept of 'control' needs clarification.
 Religious Affairs Committee sponsoring work-camp over Spring Vacation in Gallup, New Mexico . Colorado College students and faculty will attend the work camp in Gallup .
 The group plans to leave on Saturday, April 1st and spend the week at the Gallup Indian Community Center .
 Participants will work with the Indians in a community project . Like most student work-camps, the participants will be involved in a project .
 Students will help the Indians at the community center build a patio and recreation area . Students will also possibly help with a project on the Navajo reservation .
 There will also be time to visit one or two of the other reservations in the area, as well as partake in the social activities .
 The first aspect is to allow the students to gain a better understanding and a first hand knowledge of the problems and livelihood of the Navajos .
 It is felt that by sharing physical work there can be more communication . It was felt by sharing work with each other to improve communication .
 The second thing is that such a project allows a person to actively express his social concerns in a simple yet rewarding way . Such a project can be a way of expressing your social concerns, says author .
 Miss Margaret Neuman, Miss Susan Holmes, Miss Hadley Taylor, Mr Paul Szilagyi, Mr John Stickney, Mr James Fox, Mr Henry English, Miss Kari Dunn, Mr Bruce Grace, Professor and Mrs. Bruce Grace are also going .
 All of this is fine as long as thermonuclear weapons neutralize military power . The existence and devastating power of nuclear weapons neutralizes military power is fine, but that's not true .
 Millis does not have the answers or does not feel that he can attack the problem . Here it would appear that Millis doesn't know what to do to fix the problems .

 Since The Articles of Confederation we have recognized the real need of at least a minimal central power . The need is not so strong that it jeopardizes individual rights, it must not be so strong .
 It seems to us that while unmistakably this form of government has aided the United States in offering the possibility of adaptation to growth and change . But rather in one sense it might now be construed as hindering. It has not been our representative government solely which has ""made"" the
 Until recently what was responsible for the direction and growth of our country was almost more natural than social . It seems that until recently what is responsible for our country's growth was almost natural rather than social. It seems to be that until until recently it was almost social .
 The individual American had available a ""frontier" from which he could gain a real sense of individuality, mentally and physically, where individual ""rights" could flourish . Individual rights could flourish, not at statues, but in the more rewarding manner of striving for and then protecting these rights with
 Since the diminishing of this frontier, wars, social crises, and economic lapses have offered clarion call for the individual to step forward and provide direction to his fellow-men . The individual must step forward to provide direction for the future .
 Recently here is an arbitrary term, meaning that many tendencies have grown to a proportion to show us a trend . Recently is a term used to show a trend, but here is a reflection of that trend .
 There has grown up a well-oiled bureaucracy, a horde of relatively ineffectual, uninterested nine-to-fivers . Possibly because of the natural fear of our citizens to entrust complete power to an individual, there has grown-up a well oiled bureaucracy .
 This ""government"" has, despite its cumbersome nature, rather well supplied the populace with its needed governmental services . This "government" has provided the people with needed services .

 After having observed ASCC meetings for three and a half years in one capacity or another, I feel compelled to make a few comments pertinent to the pending ASCC elections .
 The constitution was written five years ago by Carl Pitts, and has been revised in the interim by such people as Keith Argow, Sally Jameson, and now Jack Real .
 It now has become a quite efficient and quite well-ordered organization, performing many behind-the-scenes services for the students .
 ASCC in the future must create and initiate new activities to serve student interests . ASCC must create new activities that serve the student interests. ASCC will be in the forefront of its efforts to create and serve students .
 ASCC has the potential to be the most powerful group on campus, second only to the Board of Trustees . ASCC's constitution, both implicitly and explicitly, gives ASCC the power to be a powerful group .
 ASCC exists potentially as an effective student tool with which the student body could manipulate and influence Administration policy . ASCC is a tool that could be used by students to influence the Administration .
 ASCC has never availed itself of the opportunity it possesses to present the Administration with student opinions and desires . ASCC should have been given the opportunity to present student opinions to the Administration .
 The deferred rush mess and the girls dormitory situation are two examples of the situation in the dormitory . Witness the deferred rush situation as two examples .
 ASCC has never asked for and never ventured to volunteer student opinion and ideas . In these and other issues, ASCC does not ask for student opinions or opinions . ASCC is proud to support students in the community .
 Unless ASCC becomes an effective policy making and pressure group and exercises its potential 'student morale,' it will continue its decline into oblivion . ASCC's activities and services will be supplemented by a series of lesser organizations .
 The students' opportunity to have a ""union" working for them will be lost . The students will not be able to have the ""union' working for them," says the author of the book .
 ASCC must now assert the responsibility and power that it has been endowed with, and which it has never tried to use . If the students are interested in having their interests protected and furthered, ASCC should now assert its power . ASCC has never been able to use this power
 The effectiveness of ASCC as a student pressure group rests with the office of the president . ASCC's effectiveness of the organization rests with its president .
 Only he can use to full advantage the forces that ASCC has at its disposal . Only he must use the forces he has at his disposal .
 If the students with the ASCC wish to protect their interests and voice their opinions, they must elect an ASCC president that can and WILL use the full power of his office in such a role .
 All three candidates have served on ASCC this past year and have had a chance to display their ability . The candidates will be representing the ASCC in 2015 .
 His ability has been ably displayed and he also seems to have the personal qualities necessary for the job . His ability was ably shown and he has personal qualities needed to succeed .

 Griffiths is especially qualified to make ASCC and the office of the president more than just a rubber stamp . All three candidates could serve ably as ASCC president as the job exists now .

 Former full-time, present half-time member of the Department of English at Colorado College responds to Jane Hult's letter .
 Miss Hult is, I am afraid, making a confusion, which I thought had died out among young people. She is making a confused point, I thought she was making a mistake, I said .
 The study of literature should not be mixed up with high-school ""creative writing"" courses in which, each week, students turn in a ""theme"" on my pet dog or on what I did last vacation .
 A college student is supposed to have left this kind of juvenile exercise behind him, and most of our students surely have . A college college student should have left it behind him and most surely have.
 A college English department provides an opportunity to study literature; to write about it and to talk it over with teachers and fellow-students . English literature is a basis for thinking — and writing — for students .

 This variety of talent will be integrated with spot announcements, station breaks and musical hacking by the Scene combo . The Scene combo will be joined by a host of local DJs and DJs .

 The entire audience will be a distinct part of the show for the first time . The response to acts will lie heard over the air over the show .

 For this reason, I propose that emphasis be placed on the ASCC's responsibility to represent the student body in the making of school policy . The ASCC is responsible for representing students in school policy making decisions .
 I feel that this new emphasis can be accomplished in a three step process . I feel it can be achieved in three steps, including a new emphasis .
 First, to investigate problem areas such as curriculum, intra-mural athletics, and the moral code of the college . Second, to look at curriculum, inter-campus athletics and morals .
 Third, to make definite statements to the administration of what we feel to be problems and of the best solutions for these problems . In so doing represent the student body in the forming of school policy .
 The ASCC has failed to give the student body anything to be interested in . CC has an apathetic student body due to the lack of interest in the ASCC .
 The ASCC has not given the student body anything to be interested in is that it has concerned itself exclusively with the totally uninteresting administrative details of supplying student services . It has neglected the more interesting and important function of representing student body in the forming school policy .
 I have proposed not a deemphasis of the services function but rather an added emphasis on the policy function . feel that this emphasis is necessary before CC can ever have an effective student government . feel this is necessary to have a successful student government.

 Their performance was enthusiastically received everywhere . Most places invited to return next year .

 Paul Bechtol is chairman of the Colorado Springs Chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union . He is professor of Business Administration at University of Colorado Springs .
 Other members of the local board include Mr Donald King, head of C.U.'s local extension center, vice-chairman and secretary-treasurer .
 The ACLU was organized forty years ago as an agency for the defense of the central constitutional safeguards of citizen's rights . The ACLU is now an advocacy group for civil liberties in America .
 The Union works in courts, legislative bodies, executive agencies, and the wide field of public opinion in its fight to maintain freedom of inquiry and communication, due process, equal protection of the laws .
 It is a private organization of people who wish to join actively in the continual struggle for each man's right to be free, within the democratic framework of government .

 AWS Shows New Directions by Ann Armstrong . TIGER article informing students of the newly elected AWS executive officers .
 The end of this article suggested that the new members of AWS wanted to make some changes and hoped that they would be able to do so .
 Until this year, all cases of dorm residents staying 'out over night were handled quietly and consistently by the administration . This year, the administration handled the cases of students staying over night .
 The standard policy has been that such a dorm infraction means dismissal from school for a period of time . Students are not allowed to leave the school for dorm infractions .
 If there have been any cases where this policy has not been followed, the administration, not the Judicial Board, has been called upon to use its discretion . The administration has been asked to use their discretion in the past .
 The result was a minimum of discussion about the cases and confusion about policy . The result of the policy is that there is no confusion about the policy .
 This year, the burden of the decision was thrown to a group of 20 students on Judicial Board . This year's decision was made by students on the Judicial Board, instead of the students .
 Judicial Board has a definite function and efficacy which has never been really seriously questioned . Judicial Board's effectiveness has never really been seriously questioned, it has been said .
 It has been quite effective in handling minor dorm infractions, milking decision on dorm policy and setting hours . It has also been used to handle minor infractions .
 Judicial Board's responsibility did not extend into the areas of extreme dormitory infra tions . Judicial Board did not feel slighted because it did not have responsibility .
 Most areas of student life should, even at the expense of efficiency and consistency, be handled by the students . Students should be responsible for student life, even if it's not the most efficient and consistent .
 Questions which concern dorm violations should be handled by the school administration . Students involved in dorm violations traditionally punished by dismissal from school .
 Ruth Snodgrass is a full-time student of English at Colorado College, with a rather uncertain future . She writes to the editors of this article .
 Dr, Ross seems to imply that high school ""creative writing"" classes have little or no merit . The study of literature in college offers a panacea for creative writers, Ross says .
 A study of literature is essential for creative writing but so is the actual attempt at being creative with the ideas aroused by this study . The study is an attempt to be creative with these ideas .
 This attempt is far better made in high school than on a first college term paper . This is a far better attempt than a term paper made in college . This attempt was far better .
 Themes on my pet dog or past vacations may not be original, or they may be juvenile fiction material . They may be subject to criticism or criticism .
 These classes provide a chance for a student so inclined to express himself, usually lost in the pressures of the college cosmos . Whatever, these classes .
 I too would be horrified at students forever rewriting Milton and Keats, although I've no doubt they could improve them . I'm equally horrified that students have to write critical term papers on Eliot or Faulkner with no other background than college literature class .
 No one will argue that "creative writers do not spring from the brow of Jove" but neither do they spring from freshmen college classes in Greek Literature or even Twentieth Century Literature .
 Boss paradoxically deplores in students and praises in Eliot, do not belong in a critical paper, which is probably why most critical papers are pendantically insufferable . Boss deplores students in students but praises Eliot in Eliot .

 The minutes of the Advisory Council will be posted in Rastall for all of those interested in finding out what happens there .
 The immediate concerns of the council are three of its annua) projects and a newly initiated one . The council is concerned about three of the projects and one new one .
 The Senior Honors dinner is given each year for all senior women who are graduating in June . The dinner is held for seniors graduating from high school .
 This year on May 11 in Bemis dining room some of the senior women will receive certificates of recognition for outstanding contributions to Colorado College . Colorado College's senior women are among many other honors to iced at this time .
 The Welcomer-Welcomee Program is also provided by AWS . It involves assigning those girls who volunteer the names of several incoming freshmen with whom to correspond this summer .
 The third annual project of AWS in the planning stage is the Tradein which holds a sale of articles for the dorm rooms like lamps and bedspreads in the fall .
 These articles are collected in the spring from any girl who wishes to sell them after she marks the price at which she wants to sell the article . The article is collected from girls who wish to sell it in spring .
 The new project is a handbook which will contain information of interest to women students only . The handbook will be sent only to the entering freshmen women .
 Suggestions under consideration include campus fashion, ideas of decorating rooms and laundry facilities . Suggestions include a detailed report on laundry facilities, to mention only a few .
 There are two major items of interest in this area right at the moment . The area is in the midst of a major redevelopment .
 The beginning of the counselor and dorm president selections for next year are being made . The dorm president and counselor president are also being selected .
 The Counselor's Workshop will be held on May 13 and one day in the fall . It will be one day before freshmen women arrive .
 There have been several innovations in these policies under the new AWS officers . There have also been innovations in the policy of the new officers .
 Instead of having an over-all president of Loomis and then a president and counselors for each floor, there will be one hall council consisting of one president and seven counselors . The new hall council will have one president, seven counselors and one president each .
 The other item is an investigation of the dorm honor system and the rules it should be upholding . The investigation will look at the dorm's honor system . The dorm's rules should be upheld .
 This is in preparation for a statement of policy and of rules which have been unclear at times in the past . This is being prepared for the first time in a long history .
 Miss Betsy Foote, who is heading this committee, would appreciate any constructive suggestions, because these are two areas which concern men students as well .
 Any group of new officers has ideas and plans for improvement, and enthusiasm is quite high at the beginning of the start of the new career .
 Both men and women students need the support and contributions of both students to achieve as much as they can . However, they will also need to support each other if they are to begin to accomplish .
 Two extra sessions of the All-Coll^ Conference were held in two sorority houses . Lines of Authority and Social Policy Discussed were discussed Sunday, April 16 .
 The last of the All-College Conference discussions will be heid at the Kappa Alpha Theta Lodge, Sunday, April 23, at 2:3|j The topic, judicial organizations and lines of authority] will be led by Mr Stew Ritchie .
 Everyone interested or con nected with judicial organizations of any kind is invited to attend . The event will be held in New York City .
 Discussion held on social policy led by Mr Tim Moe led by Tim Moe . It was decided that a definite but flexible social policy should be adapted to the UK .
 ASCC social chairman will take charge of organizing and trying to pass a new social policy before the end of this semester . The social chairman for ASCC will try to pass the new policy before end of semester .
 Working under him will be S3ven committees dealing with major social problems on the campus . The committee will be dealing with social problems .
 Sunday afternoon from 2:30 until 4:45 Mr Chris Girffiths led a group of about twenty students in an enthusiastic discussion on the lines of authority .
 The object of the meeting was to arouse the student's interest in college regulation and to define, more or less, the limits between student government and college administration .
 It was agreed that the amount of discipline necessary and good for maturing college students is hard to establish because of the variation in maturity of students, the expectations of different parents and the standards of Colorado Springs in relation to other areas .
 Policies must be explicit, yet they must be flexible; and must be understood by all . Policies should be explicit yet flexible, yet not always clear, but flexible .

 A smatl group competition has been added to the annual Song Fest performance . The group competition is designed for groups of eight or less singers . The event will be held in New York City .

 Large groups will sing only one song, and the smaller group will sing the other song . With this year's program, the large groups will only sing one song . The smaller groups will also sing the second song .

 Let's All Vote, Cha, Cha . Another election and another proportionately high student turnout . Print Fridays by PEERLESS PRINTING CO., Colorado Springs, Colorado .
 We wonder if this is a trend or if the energy inspired by the presidential election is just slowly dissipating back to lethargy . The energy of the election has been dissipating in recent weeks .
 This year's sopomores and juniors have ""decided"" not to have public speeches outlining their platforms . We wonder because last Monday at the weekly ASCC meeting, the fact came out that this year's students have "decided" not to speak .
 It seems that almost nobody turned out for the speeches given this last week by the candidates for ASCC vice-president .
 Miss Cogswell pointed out a fact we would have thought gratuitous, but was, nonetheless, accepted by most of those at the meeting as important .
 Each candidate must spend a good amount of time thinking, thinking about why he is running and what he wants to accomplish by gaining the office .
 Most seemed to agree that this would be a good thing, but after all, three days would not be enough time to prepare and publicize the speeches this year, would they; better wait til next year .
 Freshmen and upperclassmen left out of the discussion since they still plan to have their speeches . Upperclassmen don't seem to realize that an honest decision to vote for a candidate rests on the fact of the voter's having some idea of why he is voting for a certain candidate
 We admit there can be an election where one votes for a certain candidate because he knows that candidate's personally or belongs to the same fraternity, sorority, or clique . We admit it can be difficult to say yes or no, but it's a good idea to vote for a
 "We think there are better ways to show this kind of friendship, and these ways have nothing to do with politics," says CNN.com .
 As far as there not being ""enough time,"" we feel that most of the interest in the presidential election was generated in the last couple of days . We feel that there is not enough time to prepare for the election .
 We thought that it was a trite rale of politics that if the candidate wanted the votes, he reached out toward the voter and did not wait for the voter to come to him . We thought it was that it would be trite of politics .
 So, admire the clever posters, learn from a ""brother"" or ""sister"" which candidate is ""our kind of people" and next week let's all vote, cha, cha .
 Mr Griffiths promised a dynamic leadership for ASCC during his term . He has promised to lead ASCC through the next five years .
 In view of what we said, we wonder if Mr Griffiths is not being too optimistic in so far as what he thinks of the group he is to lead next year .
 It seems that much of the trouble with past and present councils is that they are largely comprised of jaded deadwood, students who ran for and gained office with an attitude based on ego .
 If Mr Griffiths hopes to put his policies into effect, it would seem to us that it would be wise if the incoming president reviewed the candidates for the different class positions .

 Dior dresses are for Jacqueline Kennedy and German philosophy students don't come to Paris . Great was my disillusion when I realized pink poodles aren't practical, Dior .
 "We had expected crowds of French people flocking around us, asking questions about America, our government policies, college life, etc. etc. We had expected people to ask questions, but we had expected them to ask about America's policies, government policies .
 Parisians have learned to accept as a necessary evil . Now all of us are just one of the 30,000 other American whom the Parisians accept .
 The student's Paris is a Paris of smelly crowded metros, of rainy days and rushing people, of long waits in the lunchline at Restaurant Universitaire .

 If this first step, that of warning the student, is taken, the individual may find, in some cases, that his suspicions have been allayed by. information acquired in the process, and that it is no longer feasible to report the case to the honor council .
 If the student does wish to report the case, he must contact a member of the council within two school weeks after the observation .
 This honor council member is responsible for submitting a written report to the entire council concerning the details of the case . The honor council is a member of the honor council .
 The student accused is notified of the accusation by a registered letter . If he thinks the accusation is not valid, he must notify the chairman or the secretary of the council within forty-eight hours of the notification . The accusation is automatically recorded as a formal warning .
 When an accusation is contested, a formal hearing of the council is held to determine whether or not it believes the accusation to be valid . A formal hearing will be held to decide if or not the accusation is valid .
 Accused and accuser appear individually before the council to present their testimonies . The accused and accuser are accused and accused of sexual assault .
 The honor council may call as many witnesses as they want . They, as well as the honor council, may call witnesses as many as they desire .
 The proceedings of this hearing are kept secret . The names of those involved in a case of discipline and the evidence in connection with it are never divulged by the members of the honor council .
 At least nine members of the council of 13 members must be present for the hearing . At least a majority vote of those present is necessary in order to issue a warning .
 The procedure for reporting a suspected second violation and the subsequent hearing are the same as that required for a first violation . A 9/13 vote of the council members is necessary to issue a second warning .
 In the event that a verdict of guilty is returned against the accused, the honor council recommends dismissal to the president of the college . The honor council also recommends dismissal of the accused .
 The council also recommends that if a person so dismissed requests a transcript of his college record to be forwarded to another institution that the administrative office take into consideration the L-ecommendations of the honor council .
 An appeal hearing is then conducted in which there is a disinterested presiding officer, a counsel for the accused and for the prosecution, and a jury of students chosen by lot . A jury is then selected by lot of students .
 A description of the proceedings of such a hearing may he found in the constitution of the honor system . The honor system is supposed to be a system of honor system, not a court system .
 Tire jury's penalty is final, but any recommendation the jury chooses to make as to the penalty affixed tn ;< verdict of guilty is advisory in nature only and forwarded to tincouncil for duo consideration .

 Marshall family of Cambridge, Mass., who run the Polaroid Lens Co., went on safari to the Kalahari Desert of South Africa to study the Bushmen who still live extremely primitive lives there .
 Their daughter, Elizabeth, wrote The Harmless People, available at Colburn, about their experiences .
 The son, John, was at the time an undergraduate major in anthropology at Harvard and chose to find out about the Bush life . He chose to speak out about his father's life at Harvard .
 He accompanied Bush hunters on a giraffe hunt taking 4 or 5 days . Fortunately he had good endurance, for at one time he accompanied the Bush hunters .
 They had little to eat during the hunt, and nothing to drink except water which they sucked out of roots . They sucked out roots and drank water from roots .
 Young Marshall shared their privations and had, as well as everything, his equipment . Marshall shared his privations with the family, and had to share everything with them .

 The honor code permits the kind of enynyn onment that a liberal arts college seeks to achieve . But it does more for the individual, in giving him the full restart ion that he is not engaged in a game of trying to outwit his fellow students or faculty .

 Eleanor Jones Water Study done by CS Personnel Dr. Dr. Marcia Moses . Eleanor Jones .
 The most interesting achievement at the present moment is the development of a Water Study Kit designed to provide high school and junior high school teachers with a s^lf-contained unit to study water .
 This is the only unit of its kind in the country, and the patent has been applied for . The patent has recently been applied .
 This kit has an important special feature in its design — it provides the teacher's students with research apparatus so they can design their own investigations with water .
 There is a book of sample exercises designed to stimulate student interest in creating their own experiments .
 These two factors, if taken advantage of, will help the students understand how scientists work .

 Politics of Cuba Aired during WES Coffee Hour Wednesday, April 26 . Discussion by professors William Hochman and Herving Madruga on the situation in Cuba .
 A professor of history at Colorado College gave a twenty-five minute statement of certain aspects of the problem in Cuba, especially with relation to the overall U.S. foreign policy pursuits and aims .
 He began by putting the problem into the context of U.S. foi-eign policy problems in general . He said the problem is a problem in the United States .
 The US's two main centers of concern are the desire to contain international Communism and identify with the interests of the underdeveloped countries of the world, he said .
 Kennedy inherited and continued the policy of the Eisenhower administration of training and giving military and monetary aid to anti-Castro refugees .
 CIA presented intelligence estimate to Kennedy stating that the time was ripe in Cuba for an anti-Castro revolution . CIA presented an intelligence estimate of the time in Cuba was ripe for a revolution .
 The idea was that given the impetus of an armed rebel invasion, the predominantly anti-Castro population of Cuba would join in with the revolt with the result in the overthrow of Castro . The plan was that the majority of the Cuban population would join the revolt .
 Munist intervention into Latin America is an opportunity to indicate to the world that we do not aprove of dictatorship, and a demonstration that underdeveloped nations cannot best achieve their aims through identification with Communism . munist intervention .
 The disadvantages would be that we, in opposing the Castro regime, may be identified with opposing the social revolution as well, which would not help us anywhere in the world in our attempts to identify with the underdeveloped countries of the world .  Some Parental Opinions of Last Weekend's Event . Parents of CC students were entertained in many ways last weekend . CC parents were entertained by the event .
 SongFest was a delightful success in presenting one social aspect of campus life . The open houses and the campus tours proved benafiisid ir-. gettingthem acquainted with ths pliyBl2tl ispect of the school and the SongFest .
 The President's reception was well-attended and the dinner with the students' faculty advisors the next evening was quite instructive as well as fun for the parents . The students' parents were invited to the dinner .
 Most comments about the eventful weekend were made about the chuck wagon breakfast held in the Garden of the Gods . Most comments were about the breakfast held on Saturday morning .
 The parents were especially pleased with the friendly atmosphere and the various kinds of entertainment provided as well as the general aura of the ""Old West"" such an occasion always has . The parents of the children said they were impressed with the entertainment provided .
 A TiGER reporter asked several parents how they would feel about sending their daughters to a school which did not have dormitory hours . The question is provocative and the topic is pertinent .
 The rules are good training, and they like to know that their daughters are keeping certain hours . Two of them said, ""Yes, T'd let my daughter come"" and the other two said, "No""
 The first two parents indicated that hours were good to have because there are many girls, they feel, who need such limitations . The other two parents said hours are good for girls .
 Parents are pleased with what their children are getting out of this school . The other question asked of these parents was quite general and resulted in the fact that on the whole they are pleased .
 The two areas which were criticized were the academic honor system and the social life of the school . Academic honor system was also criticized by the students .

 The Soldier is a mock-up of what the soldier is expected to look like . The Soldier was a mock up of the soldier's face and body .
 There are several features that are yet to be produced and distributed for the Army . All that hasn't been tested will lie in the near future . There are still several features still to be developed and distributed .
 Among this equipment is a propulsion unit on the back of the Soldier's belt . Among the equipment is the propulsion unit that can be used to propel the Soldier .
 This will enable him to jump oyer small obstacles, across small ravines and also to run very fast across open fields . He will also be able to jump across small obstacles and also run very quickly across fields .
 The idea behind the belt is to neutralize' most of the soldier's weight . The belt is designed to 'neutralize' soldiers' weight .
 The vest will stop shrapnel and nil but a direct hit by small fire arms . It is made of alternating layers of tightly woven cloth and fine mesh . The vest stops shrapnel, but will not stop fire from hitting the wearer .
 The soldier's hoots, not shown on the dummy, will be able to withstand ""small nuisance mines"" such as the present anti-personel mines . The hoots are not shown in the dummy .

 Fifteen teams from Colorado and adjoining states have filled six-man entries for the event .
 Houston Uninversity, current NCAA champions, will not be on hand to defend their CC Invitation crown which they won in 1959 and 1960 . A new champion will be crowned; since Houston Un inversity is not on hand .
 The tournament is a 54 hole medal play test, with 36 holes on Friday and 18 holes on Saturday . The tournament takes place on Friday, Saturday and Sunday .
 Each team is nllowed to enter six men, but only the low four men count in the team competition . Only four men are allowed to compete in the competition .

 The fourth annual Abbott Memorial Lecture was given Wednesday, May 9, in Shove Chapel . It was one s:« ngs, Colo., May 19, 1961 Colorado College Abbott Memorial . Lecturer Nevins Advocates Faith in Time of Crisis I .
 Mr Allen Nevins was introduced by Dr. Benezet, Dr. Nevins and Mr Nevins . After a few introductory remarks by President Benezets, Mr Nevin was introduced .
 Louis Geiger, head of the history department, [ v jio gave Mr Nevins full praise for his many achievements j n the fields of history and literature .
 Mr Nevins is a small man, with a quiet speaking voice, and gentle sense of humor .
 His talk went over the heads of many students . Perhaps this is the reason that he spoke over-the-headless .
 Mr Nevins gave the student body a faith to live by, a faith in democracy, he said .
 He stated that democracy is not a static faith, but one that grows stronger as it is exercised . He then went on to prove how this was so in the Civil War and is true now .
 By showing how Lincoln faced this crisis, Nevins demonstrated how we can deal with crisis today . He demonstrated how he faced it the way he did, Mr Nevins said .
 Lincoln referred to Lincoln's belief in ""the common sense of the common people"" as the basis of our democracy . Lincoln believed in the idea of common sense as basis of democracy .
 Lincoln never lost faith in democracy because he had faith in the people, Lincoln said . Lincoln said that he never lost his faith in democratic process . Lincoln was assassinated in 18th century .
 During times of crisis it is useless to analyze and theorize on democracy, but it is vital to practice it, says Julian Zelizer . Democracy is a vital part of democracy, says Zelizer. It's vital for democracy to be practiced, he says .
 Mr Nevins also stated that this democracy needed a strong leader, Democratic or Republican . He said this democracy needs a strong political leader .
 "This leader may make errors and stumble, but as he does, his faith in the democracy he represents will grow, and we will survive," he says . "We will survive. This leader may stumble and stumble," he adds .

 His field of interest is the USSR and its foreign policy, about which he spoke clearly and with much knowledge, he said .
 The thesis of the talk was that it is evident there is a new look in the way that the Soviets, or more particularly Khrushchev, wish to deal with what they call the western camp . The thesis was that there is an obvious new look at the way the Soviets wish to
 The change is most apparent by comparing the contemporary attitude with the policy which Stalin formulated . Stalin formulated a policy which is similar to that of the Soviet Union .
 Stalin outlined the 'old look' in foreign policy such that the world is divided into two camps, that of socialism and that of capitalism . Future would be determined by which camp defeated the other, Stalin said .
 Russia's job was to strengthen socialism (a synonym for communism) in Russia and then use it as a base to spread it by revolution to other countries . Russia's goal was to use socialism as a basis for revolution to spread socialism across the world .
 Russia would strengthen herself by increasing economically by emphasizing henvy industry rather than consumer goods and militarily . Russia would defeat the imperialistic world by playing upon its three inherent contradictions, its labor against its capitalists, the imperialist countries against their colonies .
 Khrushchev has ambitious ideas about socialism, already claiming that the socialistic world is ahead of the capitalistic world . The socialist world is already ahead of capitalistic, Khrushchchev says .
 This comparison is not made on grounds of production but he claims supremacy in this field too in a much shorter time than seems at all likely . This is not only because he is faster than anyone else in the field .
 He appears to .be placing much more importance on the strengthening of Russia and socialism than the weakening of capitalism .
 Russia has introduced light industry in Russia itself, and since the Commnuistic conquest of Red China, seems more aware of Communnist possibilities in Asia, Africa and even South America .
 The liberal arts school is truly the last fortress against the anonymous conformity of bigness . In this area, the college is truly a fortress against anonymous conformity .
 It should be Rastall's role to show that satisfaction and happiness can still be found according to the individual's own designs . One happy family often breeds nothing more than contented, unproductive cows .
 In the final analysis Rastall's most significant contribution to the liberal arts concept can be in breeding discontent, rather than in smothering with a barrage of group therapy activities, he says .

 Mao feels Khrushchev is being too cautious with his dealings of promoting socialism and discrediting and weakening the West . The fact remains that Mao feels . He feels .
 Mao still recognizes Russia, however, as the leader of the socialist camp . Mao recognizes Russia as the head of the communist party .
 Khrushchev has every intention of furthering socialism and fully expects it to succeed . The new look, then, is that he fully expects socialism to succeed in the Soviet Union . He said: 'Krushchev had every intention to further socialism'
 At the same time, he agreed with President Eisenhower that there would be no war, no internal interference and no threats as far as the opposition of the two camps is concerned .
 Khrushchev is not willing to push his relations with the West to nuclear war, but does want an economic and ideological struggle, which he is convinced he will win . The Soviet Union is convinced it will win in ideological struggle against the West .

 Colorado College began its 88th year of classes last Monday with a freshman class boasting the highest achievement in the college's history . The largest new building program ever on the campus is now underway .
 Overall scholastic ability of students at CC is higher this year than ever before in the college's history . This year's results are due to exceptionally high averages posted by the freshmen class on college entrance examinations .
 This year there are some 3S0 freshmen and transfer students, plus a few special foreign students . Students come from 40 states and 15 foreign countries . This year's students will be in attendance at the school .
 Students will be among the approximately 1200 students enrolled in the college .
 More than 30 per cent of the new students are from the state of Colorado . The new students will be students from Colorado .
 The total number of applications for admission for the 1961-62 academic year was the largest ever recorded by the college . Students applied for admission to the college for the first time in their history .
 Officials say applications made this year surpassed last year's by more than 300 . Officials said applications for jobs were more successful this year than last year .
 Under construction at the present time are three fraternity houses, a new library and a new science building . Under construction are three frat houses, three new science buildings, three fraternaternities and a library .
 The §450,000 fraternity house cluster will be completed and occupied this fall . All are scheduled to be completed during the next two years .
 The Kappa Sigma, Phi Gamma Delta and Phi Delta Theta fraternities will be housed in three buildings . Kappa Sigma will be home to Kappa Gamma Delta, Kappa Sigma and Phi Kappa Sigma Theta . Kappa Gamma Theta Theta will be the Kappa Sigma fraternity's first fraternity to
 Each of the twostory and basement houses will provide quarters for more than 36 fraternity members during the school year .

 Mr Schmidt will give an informal talk on the importance of the railroads in today's economy .
 He will discuss the problems railroads will face in the future, such as the use of rockets for carrying mail . He will also discuss using rockets to carry mail .

 Henninu Gertrude Kilgore bus has given Coburn Library a copy of her new book . Coburn has given the book to the library in Coburn .
 Mrs. Rough Houd in the Rockies in one chapter of her novel, she writes of ""floating"" up to receive her coveted diploma from Colorado College in June, 1952, magna cum luude .
 Kilgore's book was published in July by Alan Swallow's Big Mountain Press in Denver, Colorado . It is on sale at tile CC bookstore .
 Rough Houd in the Rockies opens when the writer became a log-cabin wife in the mountains near Denver a quarter of a century ago, and ends with the author in her present position as Dean of Girls at Roy J Wasson High School in Colorado Springs .
 Through the entire book appear a lively wit and a warm philosophy . The author and her husband and later dieir children run the die gamut from experiences in mountain cabin to fox farming, to living in a trailer, to return to formal education .
 Kilgore has published articles in Christian Science Monitor, Empire Magazine, Parents Magazine, and educational and guidance journals .

 Colorado College Debate Club began preparations for the coming season at their first meeting . 14 new members and nine members returning from last year's squad in attendance .
 Students interested in debate should contact Professors Johnson or Rudoff . Max Power, President of the Debate Club, is also interested .
 New members of the team are; Sue Caudill, Jim Cotton, Jim Heckman, Sue Heidel, Jo Heller, Diane Johnston, Crissy Moon, Carol Nelson, Suzy Patterson, Mare Streuli, Pete Trushell, Mike Von Helms and Bob Williams .
