 Any the nts to ce Corps will have another opportunity to qualify by taking examinations on October 7 . The exams will take place in the fall .
 The third round of Peace Corps examinations will begin at 8 :30 m.m. at the Main Post Office of Colorado Springs . The examinations will last for six hours, with an additional hour out for lunch .
 Each person will be given his choice between two types of examinations . Each student will be able to choose between the two exam forms .
 One examination is designed for men and women who would like to be considered for positions as secondary-school or college teachers . The exam is designed to be designed for those interested in teaching at secondary school or college .
 To take one of these tests, you need a bachelor's degree but you do not need to be an accredited teacher . To take these tests you need to take a Bachelor's degree or a teaching degree .
 The other examination is for everyone else who wants to serve in the Peace Corps . The Peace Corps will be open to the public for the first time .
 Results are considered along with such other elements as background, special skills, and character references . Results are based on the results of an online test .
 The Peace Corps hopes to attract a large number of Americans in the agricultural and industrial fields . The tests will take place in October .
 Many of those who will take examinations will be men and women who have sent in a Peace Corps questionnaire since the last testing in July . Many of the tests will be conducted by those who sent in the questionnaire since July .
 The German Research Association (Deutsche Forschungs-Gemeinschaft) presented Colorado College with a collection of German-language history, literature, and art books valued at $400 .
 The gift includes a number of scholarly periodicals dealing with German literature, culture, politics, politics and history .
 Professor Thomas Brandt said collection would be valuable to students taking advanced courses in German .
 Library officials said a selected number of the German books will be placed on exhibit in Coburn library starting October 1 . Library officials say a selection of the books will go on exhibit at Coburn Library .
 The collection will be housed there until the Charles Learning Tutt Library, now under construction, is ready for occupancy next May . The collection is housed in the library's new library .
 Brandt has been in close association with the German Research Association since it first expressed interest in making a gift to the college library . Brandt says he is in close relationship with the association since it expressed interest .
 Bruno Werner, former cultural attache at the German Embassy, Washington, D.C. was instrumental in obtaining the gift for the college . Bruno Werner was the former ambassador to Germany at the U.S. Embassy in Washington, DC .

 Brooks Opens Lecture Series at the University of Columbia University . Brooks: "A world which seems to be controlled not by reason but by fear, stupidity, and irrationality"
 Benezet first pointed out that overwhelming crisis was not new in 1961 . Crisis has existed almost continuously for at least 14 years, he says .
 He illustrated by e\amples from history that reason has never played a dominant role in the activities of men. Furthermore, he illustrated by . e\ samples from . history that . reason has . never been a dominant . role in men's activities .
 Tins all has tended to make the commitment to reason and intellect less tenable . Tins have tended to be made less accessible to the public by their consumption .
 Benezet went on to examine various reactions to the dilema of man as a seemingly non-rational creature . The dilema was the question of whether man is rational or irrational .
 Some react by becoming dogmatic and authoritarian, he said . Others become super-rationalists, holding out for possibility of the possibility of pessimism in the ability to do anything .
 Benezet's own reconciliation of man as rational and as irrational involves none of these extremes . The French writer's reconciliation with man as irrational and irrational involves no extremes .
 Certainly, man is not all rational, but neither is he irrational — that is senseless and completely without contol . That is senseless, but that is not irrational, and it is senseless .
 "He is partly rational and yet moved to a great extent by non-rational elements," he says . "He's partly rational but yet moved a great amount by non -rational elements. He's not rational, but he's moved to an extreme extent," he adds .
 Nonrational elements can be highly productive in terms of artistic creativity, motivation, development of friendships, and the like . But these nonrational elements are not rational and can be productive .
 Glenn Brooks, Assistant Professor of Political Science, will give the first of three fall faculty lectures on October 3, at 8:15m. in Perkins Hall . The first lecture will be held at Perkins Hall, Perkins Hall.
 Brooks will point out the stresses and strains which this swift acceleration has brought to bear on our political institutions . Brooks will also project ways in which we must change or strengthen those institutions if they are to survive .
 Decision making, not only in regard to nuclear war but also in broad social and economic questions, is one of the many aspects of the overall problem of time compression to which Mr Brooks will devote his attention to .
 William Fischer, Professor of Geology, will speak on "The Dimensions of Geologic Time" on October 17 . Fischer will discuss the dimensions of geologic time .
 He is the author of When Governors Convene, a detailed study of the National Governors' Conference . He is also author of the study of governors' conferences .

 Campus publications do exist, but they cannot fulfill their functions without the support of the student bodv . Campus publications need to be supported by the student body to fulfill their function .
 In his three years at CC I have heard numerous complaints about various publications, but few people try to strengthen their complaints with action . In my three years as a CC editor, I've heard many complaints about the publications . I'm not satisfied with the complaints, I'm happy with the
 I think that much of this hesitancy to act is because of a feeling that work in publications requires much experience . I think much of the hesitation to act comes from a feeling of a lack of experience, especially in publications .
 The position of editor requires some experience, but there is no better way of achieving this experience than by working as a staff member . True, the position of editing requires some .
 This year we have many capable freshmen with new ideas that can and should be put to use . Upperclass students have spent from one to three years either complimenting or criticizing the campus publications .
 Now is as good a time as any to offer more than verbal support, not only if you've had experience, but also if you have only an idea or a willingness to learn . Don't forget to offer your support if you want to learn more from your experience .
 If you want campus publications that meet your demands, then you must provide the thought, time, and energy necessary to achieve the quality desired . Students need to provide the time, time and effort necessary to reach the quality they want .

 The Bulletin (in which an application for the test is inserted) should be obtained four to six weeks in advance of the desired testing date from Law School Admission Test, Educational Testing Service, Princeton .
 Completed applications must be .^received at least two weeks before the desired testing date in order to allow ETS time to . complete the necessary testing arrangements for each candidate . ETS will test candidates for a variety of positions .

 About 20 junior high school science teachers from the Colorado Sprincs-Pueblo area attended the opening session of a year-long in-service institute Saturday .
 The day-long sessions will be held on campus each Saturday for 32 weeks during the regular academic year . The sessions will take place during the normal academic year and last 32 weeks .
 The tuition-free course carries eight semester hours of graduate credit for the year term . The course is open to general science teachers, and is tuition free to students .
 Each session will be tailored to introduce junior high school teachers to the broad spectrum of the natural sciences, with an emphasis on basic principles . Richard Beidleman, director of the institute and associate professor of zoology, said each of the sessions will be tailor-made for junior high
 Two sessions of meteorology, seven of chemistry, two of astronomy, two in astronomy, seven in physics, and seven in biology will take place .

 Brooks questioned the ability of tutions to withstand the acceleration of technological and social changes taking place in the world today . Brooks, in the first of tures, questioned how tutions can withstand the changes .
 The political scientist made it clear that there is no immediate danger of machines taking over the decision making functions of government . He said that machines will not be able to take over decision-making decisions .
 He expressed concern about little time our leaders have for making key decisions . But he did express deep concern about the little time leaders have to think about making decisions .
 "The American people will not be consulted," Brooks said . The stakes of war and politics mounting so high, "there will be no time for extensive consultation"
 Brooks noted the problem facing the nation is the need to gather accurate information quickly and to employ it for making split-second decisions . Brooks said the problem is to gather reliable information quickly for the defense .
 I am convinced that we cannot survive if we cannot provide a genuine political reflection . I'm convinced that . We cannot survive . We can't survive if . we cannot . provide . genuine political . reflection .

 Male college seniors or recent graduates preparing for a career in teaching, counseling, or administrative work at the college level . The program is open to male college seniors and recent graduates .
 Applicants may major in any recognized field at the American graduate school of their choice, but should not have already undertaken graduate work . Applicants must also have already completed graduate work at the school they choose .
 Nominees will be judged on intellectual promise, personality, integrity, genuine interest in religion, and potential for effective college teaching . Nomineees will also be judged for intellectual promise and personality .
 Winners will be eligible for up to four years of financial assistance . Annual maximum of $1,500 for single men and $2,000 for married men, plus tuition and fees .
 The winners will be guests of the Foundation at an annual educational conference held on the shores of Lake Michigan .
 Leading scholars lecture, conduct seminars, and come in personal contact with the Fellows . Fellows also conduct seminars and come into contact with scholars .

 His message, ""The Role of Young People in Government and Politics,"" was timely and well received . The role of young people in government and politics was timely .

 The active interest of all citizens would result in a strengthening of both parties, he said . He went on to say that the active interest would result from both parties .

 CC Tigers beat Fort Hays State 14-6 at Washburn Field . CC Tigers erupted for two second quarter touchdowns, then threw up a rugged defense .
 The Tigers contain former teammate Davy Parker . In doing so the Tigers racked up the second victory of the season against one loss .
 Parker, operating at both quarterback and halfback, had four of his attempt with a little over three minutes remaining in the third period .
 The Tiger's first touchdo\vn was set up when quarterback Eddie Kintz picked off an attempted Parker pass on the CC 25 and weaved his way back to the midfield stripe in the first quarter .
 Dan Wright took a reverse handoff, squirmed his way through five Hays defenders and bolted for the touchdown . Hays had a fourth and goal situation from the five, and it was fourth and five .
 Minutes later the Tigers started another scoring drive, but a clipping penalty set them back to the Hays 30. Minutes later, the Tigers were back to their 30th-minute drive . The Tigers started again, but the penalty was set up for a penalty .
 Kintz then hit Wright on a third down pass play moving the ball to the 15, just short of a first down . Wright's hit was enough to move the ball from the 15 to 15 yards .
 The Bengals were unable to move against the big Tiger line, and were forced to punt from deep in their own territory . The Bengals punter was forced to punter from deep into his own territory with a punt .
 The Kintz to Wright aerial combination again clicked on pass plays of 15 and ten yards to keep the Tiger scoring bid alive . The Tiger scored a touchdown in the first quarter .
 The second reception carried to the Hays six and on the next play Holleran breezed into the end-zone for the second CC score . The next reception carried out to the six .
 Half back Pete Pleasant added the extra point to seal a 14-0 half time lead . The Tigers led the Tigers to the dressing room with a 14 -0 half-time lead at half time .
 Hays tackle Mike Pope ejected from the game after being ejected from Haysville . Pope was ejected from game after a Kintz aerial and returned it to the CC 26 .
 Hard running fullback Mike Worley scored the first Hays touchdown from four yards out on the first play of the fourth quarter . From there, Hays ran off consistent gains and scored a fourth quarter touchdown .
 Perker's attempted pass for the two point conversion was deflected from the hands of the intended receiver by Kintz, and the score remained 14-6 . The score was 14-5 .
 Hays threatened twice more, but both scoring bids were squelted by the spirited Tiger defensive line . Hays scored twice more in the first half, but were unable to find the net .
 The Bengals moved from their own 13 to the Tiger 31 before Holleran broke up a fourth down Parker pass and the Tigers took over on downs . Worley pounded the line and halfback Wayne Schumacker skirted the ends .

 Creativity must become for us an ultimate value, if you will, a religious valuer — to which we commit ourselves as we would to the establishment of the Kingdom of Heav . Creativity should be for us to commit ourselves to the values of creativity .

 Political and ideological groups are given freedom to organize and meet . Political groups are allowed to organize, meet with each other in the country .
 Discussions or activities of a controversial nature are accepted, or even encouraged, by the community . Discussions of controversial topics are accepted or encouraged . Disfavor and contempt of the local press and of large segments of the community may be incurred .
 Few students take active part in groups which deal with political and ideological issues . And yet, in this unusually free atmosphere, few students take part in these groups .
 Young Democrat and Republican clubs have very few active, acutely aware members . Young Democrats and Republicans have few active members of their clubs .
 Commitment won the dedication and effort of a few students last spring . Commitment is a campus organization of real note, Commitment .
 Even though CCs administration and faculty do not enforce the ""hygienic concept"" of isolating students from the issues of the outside world, the students enforce that isolation on their own account .
 We at CC have the opportunity not generally afforded college students to face the issues of the day squarely, without fear of banishment by an overly-cautions administration . We are at CC to face our issues, not to fear banishment .
 If we are to make our college experience a valuable one, we must cast aside our own bland acceptance of isolation . But if we're to make it valuable one when it comes to facing complex political and ideological questions in the future, we need to cast aside .
 We must make use of this opportunity — a far more crucial one than we realize . We must use this opportunity to take advantage of the opportunity, says President Obama .

 Colorado College psychology professor awarded a S5000 research grant by the National Institute of Mental Health . Carl L Roberts is associate professor and chairman of the psychology department .
 Roberts has been studying the effect of certain sensory changes on the learning process . Roberts studies sensory changes to learn more about the nature of behavior determinants .
 The CC psychologist has been working on a pilot project of the study for the past two years . CC psychologist is working on the pilot project for two years.
 Roberts joined the faculty in 1957 as an assistant professor . Roberts will be assisted in the initial phases of the project by senior students Jerry Northern and John Clark .
 Other students will be brought into participation in the experimental work . The research will be carried out by students at the university .

 This article is written to acquaint the student with Coburn library . How to Use the Library: Coburn Library . Coburn is located at Coburn College in North Carolina .
 The answer is found in understanding that this library really belongs to Mr Coburn, the author of the book . Coburn's library is in the heart of the nation's history .
 It's all his and he doesn't have to let any of you use it unless he wants to . It's his own and he's not allowed anyone to use it, he says .
 Coburn Library is located in Coburn, Georgia, home to Coburn University . The library's card catalog is used to find out what books are in the library . Coburn is home to the largest library in the world .
 The library has a large collection of periodicals which are available for student use . The library is available for students to use in the summer .
 It is a mistake to ask the librarian for copies of Sun-Bather's Monthly, View or other magazines . It is, however, a mistake for asking for a copy of the magazine .
 You will notice that a librarian will spend all day with her nose buried in a book . You can also notice that she spends a lot of time with a book in the library .
 With hardly any effort on your part you can make her life more enjoyable . With hardly the effort on her part, you can do much more to make your life more fun .
 After about twenty minutes of juggling microfilm cans she will return and begin to put the film in the projector . She juggles microfilm canisters around the room .
 As she leaves a comment such as ""Well, out of sight; out of mind"" will probably give her a chuckle .
 When the librarian finally returns with the correct copy and inserts it into the projector, you turn to the want-ads and look them over for about fifteen seconds . The librarian eventually returns to the library with the right copy of the ads .
 Another method for amusing the librarian takes a bit more effort but I believe that you'll find the rewards make the project worthwhile .
 At this point you dash for the door leaving a trail of books in your wake . At the end of the book, you dash to the door and leave a trail behind .
 It is usually advisable to stay away from the library for a few days after this as the librarians are rather forceful when expressing their gratitude .
 You will rest securely with the knowledge that you have brought some excitement to an otherwise dull life. Of course, you will rest secure with the . knowledge that . you have . brought . some excitement .
 In conclusion, I want you to remember that the library is here for your use . I want to remind you that it's here for you to use . The library is free to use.

 The purpose of Professor Burton's sermon is to examine our lives in the light of Christian faith . The individual may live to the fullest of his power as a child of God, Professor Burton says .

 The National Academy of Sciences — National Research Council has been called upon again to advise the National Science Foundation in the selection of candidates for the Foundation's program of regular graduate and postdoctoral fellowships .
 Committees of outstanding scientists appointed by the Academy Research Council will evaluate applications of all candidates . Committees will also evaluate applications from outstanding scientists .
 Final selection will be made by the Foundation, with awards to be announced on March 15, 1962 . Award winners will be announced in 1962 .
 Fellowships will be awarded for study in the mathematical, physical, medical, biological, and engineering sciences . Also in anthropology, psychology (excluding clinical psychology), geography, geography, economics and economics .
 They are open to college seniors, graduate and post-doctoral students, and others with equivalent training and experience . The event is open to students, graduates, post-graduates and others .
 All applicants must be U.S. citizens of the United States and will be judged solely on the basis of ability . Applicants must be American citizens .
 The Educational Testing Service will give out tests on January 20, 1962, at designated centers throughout the U.S.
 The annual stipend for post doctoral Fellows is $6000 . Limited allowances will also be provided to apply toward tuition, laboratory fees, and travel .
 The deadline for the receipt of applications for postdoctoral fellowships is December 18, 1961, and January 5, 1962 . Applications for regular postdoctoral . fellowships are open for the next year . Applications are open to the public for regular and graduate fellowships .

 The State Department has announced the 1961 examinations for appointment as Foreign Service Officer of Class 8 for December 9, 11.01.01 .
 Denver is one of the centers where the examination will be administered . Denver is among the centers that will take place .
 The application to take the examination must be made on State Department Form DSP-24, which must be received by the Board of Examiners, Department of State, no later than October 23, 1961 .
 In order to be eligible, a person has to be between 21 and 31 years of age, a U.S. citizen of the United States for at least 9 years . A person can be eligible for the program .
 Candidates who are successful in the Written Examination will be required to take the Oral Examination within 9 months after the date of the written examination . Candidates are required to complete the oral examination within nine months of the examination date .
 Government informed of developments abroad, to protect American citizens and interests in foreign countries, and to maintain friendly relations with peoples of other nations .
 Officers may expect to perform a number of functions during the course of their careers . Officers can expect to do many of these functions during their careers.
 Sondermann is a member of the Board of Examiners, Department of State . He is a former member of Congresswoman Barbara Walters .

 A Colorado Springs Army sergeant who aided in protecting the United States Embassy in Ethiopia during the short-lived revolt against Emperor Haile Selassie was decorated by the Army here last Thursday .
 Charles K Morton, 2624 Meadowlark Lane, was awarded the Army Commendation Medal . Morton was awarded a posthumous Army Medal for his service in Afghanistan . Morton served in the U.S. Army in Afghanistan, Afghanistan and Afghanistan .
 He is assigned to the CC Reserve Officers TrainingCorps as instructor and the presentation was made by Lt. Lt. Cpl. Cm. T. G. Gentry . Lt. J. H. Hettler was awarded the Commander of the Armed Forces .
 Morton was with the Army attache group in Rthiopia during the abortive attempt to overthrow the royal government . Morton was involved in the failed coup attempt to oust the king .
 Army and Air Force personnel fought both loyalist and rebel forces in preventing them from storming the embassy compound . The embassy compound was attacked by loyalist forces and rebels .
 There were no American casualties, although some members of the embassy staff suffered minor injuries .
 Morton described the fighting as being particulary heavy on December 13 and 14, first two days of the revolt . Morton described it as "particular heavy" during the fighting . Morton said the fighting was particularly intense on the December 13-14 .
 The revolt, led by an Ethiopian prince, was put down and Haile Selassie retained power . The revolt was led by a prince, but the revolt was eventually put down by the prince .

 The program has resulted in the development of new science teacing methods at the independent liberal arts college . It appears to have encouraged some of the college's top science students to consider teaching .
 The first summer science institute for secondary school teachers was undertaken by The Colorado College through local support in 1956 . Colorado College was supported by local support .
 Since 1957 the institutes have been supported by National Science Foundation funds . The institutes are based in New York and Washington .
 The summer science institutes are encouraging faculty members in some fields of science to de-emphasize formal lectures in favor of a round-table seminar approach to teaching .
 The Colorado College's science institute program is a special threesummer-session graduate program for secondary school science teachers . Colorado College is offering a special summer-summer session program for teachers .
 The rill progra the teachers to obtain a Master of Arts in Teaching degree with emphasis on science subject material, rather than on education courses .
 About 45 teachers, all with at least five years of science teaching experience, currently are involved in the program . The program is being led by teachers from around the world .

 An unusual kind of alumni reunion will be held here Nov 4 when scores of former Colorado College students and seven faculty members gather around a huge seminar table to re-examine their notions of freedom and authority .
 The occasion will be the third annual reunion of alumni of C.C.C.'s Freedom and Authority seminar . The reunion will be held at the end of September .
 Freedom and Authority alumni have been holding reunion discussions at homecoming since 1959 . Alumni have been discussing reunions since 1959 at Freedom homecoming homecoming . Freedom and authority alumni have held reunion discussions since 1959.

 All seven faculty members have taught the Freedom and Authority seminar . The seminar was held at the University of Cambridge .
 Students and faculty aim to understand the nature of freedom and the kinds of authority that restrict it . They regard the course as a joint quest by both students and faculty into freedom .

 First, it is presenting to the non-Christian student a means of exploring Christianity and of determining its relevance and its values .
 "The assumption underlying this program is that ultimate questions are indeed important and meaningful," the program's creator says .
 If they are unanswerable, they nevertheless have great significance, and the religious program is attempting to give the student, be he Christian or not, a way to explore both the significance and some possible answers .

 A woman has been raped, a trial has been held, and a priest and a -wood-cutter are discusssing the happenings at Rashomon gate when the play begins .
 As the three men discuss, flashbacks of the trial and the crime appear on the stage . The three men are shown discussing the case in a new documentary .
 The accused gives his and gives his interpretation of each person's character . The accused and the accused give their interpretations of each other .
 Victim's husband gives her i, and the victim's husband, (through the Medium, Terry Kidhis) Then tim gives the victim the i and the husband's husband . Then Tim gives Tim and Tim's husband the i's .
 Only a fourth interpretaeveals the true situation and the true reactions . Only a third interpretaevesals the truth and the reaction to it .
 For the presentation of this flashback structure some fairly staging has been arranged . For the purposes of this presentation, this is a fairly staging of the story .
 Two sections of the stage, to the far right and the far left, remain unchanged throughout the play . The play is set to be shown in London at the end of the month .
 At stage left one sees Rashomon gate and the three townspeople discussing the case . At stage right one can be seen from the stage left .
 At stage right lies the witness stand where each interpreter gives his story to the court . The witness stand is set up for each interpreter to give his testimony to the jury .
 The flashbacks of the crime' itself take place in the midfile of the stage in which there is a revolving 'set arranged to accomodate the four re-enactments of the . crime'
 All set changes are <W with blackouts, the curtain not lining used at all . All sets changes are set changes with blackout, not using curtain curtain or curtain .

 Peace Corps will work with U.S. agencies, United Nations' agencies, various American universities, and various private groups such as CARE . The Peace Corps has a program of its own, including working with private groups .
 Several projects are underway in Chile, Columbia, East Pakistan, the Phillipines, Ghana, and other areas . Several projects have been started in South America .
 Most of the Peace Corps volunteers are involved in forms of agricultural work; in various teaching positions on the secondary school level; and in areas of technological skills such as electricians, carpenters and draftsmen .
 Eighty-four percent of the present Peace Corps are college graduates . Of these, 19 percent have done graduate work . The Peace Corps is based in Washington, DC .
 A college student in a libei'al arts school would have his best chance for becoming a member of the Peace Corps by trying for a teaching position . A university student would have best chance to become a Peace Corps member .

 A major in education is not necessary in order to attain a teaching position in the Corps. The Corps. is not required to be a major in the education field .

 It also asks about your college background, and what organizations you have participated in . It also includes what you have done in the past .
 The second part is a comprehensive 5% hour examination which covers American history and culture, language apptitude, personal qualities, and one's area of competence . The exam is a 5%-hour examination covering American history, culture and language .

 Mr Alford is a graduate in Fine Arts of the Art Institute of Chicago . He has been responsible for youth work in the Churches of the Chicago Area . At present is serving as a field worker for the National Council of Churches .

 In a pub he meets Doreen, the New Zealand girl destined to drift two-dimensionally through the work, and Charles Street, an unemployed actor . Charles Street is the unemployed actor simultaneously embodying joi de vivre and the freedom of the individual .
 Charles deftly guides Harry through the artsy, aesthetic, accepted and abnormal strata of Soho life . With an acceptable talent for the theatre and an exceptional one for bumming food .
 The portraits of Charles' friends and fans are dryly and adeptly drawn . Charles' portrait is dryly, adeptly and well drawn .
 All subscribe to some form of the ""freedom"" philosophy — freedom of the individual from the oppression of society, freedom both to create and indulge oneself at the same time .
 Harry struggled to "get to grips with the subtlest shades of one's emotional experience" The ultimate in self expression is not to be found in empty coffee cups or sleeping bags on bare floors .

 The consequences of our response to those challenges present some terrifying possibilities . Ck.lo Springs, Colucudo 'Beware the Terrible Simplifiers'
 The way in which we answer the questions of armament, the way we interpret the needs and desires of the masses in underdeveloped areas of the world, will determine whether civilization itself lives or dies . The institutions we construct to keep pace with our technology will .
 It is against this backdrop that the ""terrible simplifiers"" are at their best . The 'terrible simplifiers" are the best of the series .
 Our insecurity and frustration, resulting from our inability to resolve the pressing problems which face us, provide a fertile ground for the seeds of radical panaceas . Our insecurity, frustration, our fear, resulting in the . inability to . resolve the . pressing problems . face us .
 Those who would propose radical solutions to our problems generally simplify matters . Those proposing radical solutions often simplify matters by simplifying matters .
 First they lay the blame for those problems at the feet of some collective demon or another . First they blame the problems on some collective demons or another. Then they blame each other for the problems they face .
 Return to the principles and methods of the past century and strike down anyone who advocates or supports change therefrom . Return to those methods and methods, strike down those who advocate or support change .
 The former, in addition to ignoring the complexity of modern life, forget to tell us who's to take care of the government, of the solution of those complex problems . The former .
 The latter, also ignoring those complexities, fail to explain how removing the changes of a fast-moving century will eliminate the problems which caused the changes .
 The radicals on either hand, moreover, advocate schemes which would stifle individual endeavor and excellence under a strict pall of conformity . The radicals are either side of the issue .
 The examples of the application of these points of view show that they have yet more in common with each other .
 Both for instance, are based on fear and suspicion . Both use secret police tactics to a great extent . Both for example, both use secret tactics to great extent.
 The frightening thing is that radicalism is no longer an academic question for us. Radicalism is not an academic issue for us, says Julian Zelizer . "Radicalism is now no longer academic question," he says .
 A radical revolution of the left now controls our neighbor, Cuba, and evidence of a growing radical right can be found in many parts of our own country . A radical left is now controlling Cuba, with a growing right in the United States .
 This is not to say that conservatives or liberals, in the vague, general meaning we give these terms, are selling America down the river to totalitarianism . It's not the case that liberals or conservatives are selling U.S. down the the river .
 The reasonable conservative and liberal positions which hold basic the longstanding broad concepts of Our Constitution will very likely become harder to maintain . But the reasonable conservative . and liberal . positions which recognize the complexity of the problems . we face will likely become more difficult to maintain.
 As fear and frustration mount, the simple, black-and-white pronouncements of the radicals will have wider appeal . The simple black and white pronouncements will have a wider appeal, says CNN's John Sutter .
 The greatest service we Americans can do is to cast aside our principles in fear and suspicion, the author writes . The author says the greatest service is to do the international Communist conspiracy .
 Freedom is most in danger from those on the far left and the far right who cry loudly that their radical schemes will preserve it . Freedom is in danger because of those who say they want to preserve it, says Julian Zelizer .

 More than half of the freshmen class at CC this fall have a higher scholastic ability than 90 per cent of the average college and university freshmen throughout the United States .
 Dwane Collins is associate professor of education and director of the college's Counseling Center Services . Collins is also a counselor at the University of Columbia .
 Collins based his report on the results of the School and College Ability Tests given on the campus last Sept. to entering freshmen . Collins says the tests were given to students at the University of Columbia .
 The Colorado College freshmen scores were then compared to the results of a normal national sampling of entei'ing freshmen at 99 leading colleges and universities across the nation . Colorado College freshman scores were compared to those of 99 leading universities .
 The scholastic ability of the Colorado College student body is nearly twice as high as it was six years ago . Collins said the national sample of students is twice as good as the national average . Collins: The college has a national student body of nearly 100 percent .
 He attributed this to an admispolicy designed to select colstudents who can profit most from a high level liberal arts and science education .
 In comparing the results of freshmen at the liberal arts college here to the national sampling, Dr. John Sutter compared the national sample to a national sample .
 Collins found that 98. percent scored better on the ability tests than the top 50 per cent of the national average . The study was carried out by the Collins Foundation .
 A review of reports issued over the past years shows that scholastic ability of students at The Colorado College is improving measurably each year .
 Only 54. per cent of entering freshmen in 1954 scored higher on the School and College Ability Tests than the top half of the normal sampling . The current 98.4 per cent test results are higher than those in 1954 .
 The percentage increased from 54. in 1954 to 05. in 1955 and to 83. in 1956 . In 1956, the percentage of people in the United States was 83.7% .

 Our job is providing communications of all kinds, wherever needed . We flash word of possible enemy missile attack, or in your home or college . We're providing communications wherever needed, including in the northern snows .
 When we can't fill a need off the shelf, then we start fresh and create the answer to the problem . We start fresh, create the solution to that problem, says author .
 World's first undersea telephone cables to speed calls between continent's . Then we developed the world's first underwater telephone cables .
 We have started development of an important world-wide communications system employing satellites . And we have started developing an important communications system using satellites .
 Data-Phone can transmit mountains of data at extremely high speeds . Industry and government needed a way to gather huge amounts of coded information from distant points .
 Long Distance service, Direct Distance Dialing, Transistor, Solar Battery- a succession of firsts which goes back to the invention of the telephone itself . And so it goes .
 Universal communications-the finest, most dependable anywhere-are what we deliver . Universal communications are the most reliable, reliable communications anywhere .
 One half of the world's population is caught in the maelstrom of the Twentieth Century . A new force which is destroyingcivilizations and societies which have been stable for hundreds of years is destroying societies and societies . The world is experiencing a new force of destruction .
 Politically these transitional societies are called the ""neutral,"" or ""uncommitted"" countries . Politically they are known as "neutral" or "uncomcommitted" countries . They are transitional societies that are politically neutral .
 What these countries believe, why they believe it, and how we can take account these beliefs in formulating foreign policies are major problems for the U.S. today . The United States needs to understand the beliefs of these countries .
 All of these countries are proud of their new independence and after centuries of colonialism they would like to be left alone to work out their own individual forms of government .
 No money comes wtihout qualifications attached to the money, no money comes with qualifications attached .
 The problems of transition facing the newly independent countries have no historical precedents, says President Obama . The problems facing independent countries are no historical precedent, he says .
 There is no way to evaluate what will happen as the result of an action taken today, and this makes the new nations extremely wary of long-range policies . The idea is to remain flexible, cross the bridges when they come, do not get committed in advance, for the present problem
 Both the East and the West are fighting for their friendship, but the power of the neutrals is magnified . The power of neutrals in the world is often greater than their status would suggest . The West is fighting for the friendship of the two countries .
 While new nations would like to pursue a policy of "flexibility," the major powers of the world want concrete decisions and commitments . The U.S. and its allies do .
 The Soviet block hopes for the same, but it goes about achieving the results more carefully . It hopes to achieve the same success as the Soviet block .
 In order to fight ideological battle with the East, the West must understand the code of operations it fights against . The West needs to understand that the West is fighting a winning ideological battle against the East . In order, to fight the West, it must understand what it is fighting against .
 The Soviet block understands and sympathizes with the neutrals' wish for flexibility . It is content to give huge sums of money to nations it deems important for three-to-five yeai*s .
 In excange, the Soviets hope to tie these new countries to them economically . The Soviets hope they will tie these countries to economic ties .
 The new nations are aware of this underlying motive, and they hope that when the Soviet payments slow down that they will be able to break away and find another benefactor . New nations hope to find a new benefactor when they find another .
 The importance of General Nasser to the countries of Asia and Africa cannot be denied . His prestige as a ""neutrals' neutral" neutral"" is enormous, says Nasser .
 At any rate, he is the only one who has succeeded in taking from both sides without being recolonized . At any . rate, the only . one of those who succeeded in . taking both sides have succeeded in winning .

 If the Market becomes a reality, discriminatory tariffs against non-members will be five or six times those charged to members . Non-members would be five to six times the rate of tariff paid to members, according to experts .
 All former colonies still send their crops to the old colonial paver to be processed, in exchange for European goods . The former colonies are still sending their crops back to the paver .
 Nigerian cocoa beans go to England to be processed and return in tins along with cloth for Nigerian dress, Nigerian hats, shoes and other goods .
 The new nations do not have factories to process their own crops; they must spend their money on schools, hospitals and a higher living standard . New nations must spend the money on hospitals, schools and higher living standards, says President Obama .
 In Africa the Japanese, Israelis and now the Canadians are filling the vacuum . They are attracted by the mineral wealth which is being discovered in these new countries .
 The Soviet bloc hopes to establish economic dependency, simply through lack of competition . But Japan, Israel, and Canada cannot fill the gap alone, and so the Soviet bloc .

 We must realizet hat this is going to happen, with us or without us. And finally, we must realize hat this . This is not only about the future, but also the future of the United States .

 There will be upheavals, most of them peaceful, we hope, a great . many within the next ten years, all of them in the next five after that . The UK has a long history of political upheaval, says David Cameron .
 In most of the underdeveloped countries small political business cliques control the country . Small political cliques play a key role in the development of the country's economy .
 With more and more schools and universities being built and more wealth coming in, this restriction of wealth will have to disappear, as surely as it has whenever and wherever these things happened, says the author of the book .
 Colorado College Debate Team combined experienced debaters with talented freshmen . Colorado Woman's College Invitational Debate Tournament was held in Denver October 27th and 28th .
 Eleven colleges and universities from the Colorado and Wyoming area participated in the meet in which two CC teams narrowly missed taking honors .
 Charles Puckett teamed with freshman Jo Heller in the senior division and lost but a single round of debate . Harris Sherman and Linda Pierce in the junior division also did not win a single debate .
 Only one of the seven teams entered from Colorado College had a losing record . The junior team moved to the senior division in order to gain experience .
 Sue Caudill placed 1st and 2nd in her two rounds of extemporaneous speaking, and Jo Heller took third in tow rounds of original oratory . Jo Heller placed third in her first round of original speech, and second round of speech .
 Max Power, Robert Williams and Pete Trushel also participated in the individual events . Max Power and Robert Williams also took part in individual events.
 In adition to Heller and Puckett in the senior division of debate, Chris Griffiths, Max Power, Robert Thrasher, and David Bitters were entered . In addition to Heller, the other contestants were entered by Max Power and Max Power .
 Sue Caudill, David Furgason, David Helms, Marc Streule, Faith O'Reilly, and Susan Heidel also participated in the junior division . The junior division also took part in the event .

 Freshman Commissioner Sue Caudill said she had heard some complaints that such meetings are dull . She said ASCC does nothing but fill the traditional requirement that there be a student government .
 Perhaps, then, it would be wise for us to explore the current operations of ASCC more closely, perhaps . Perhaps, perhaps, we should look at ASCC's operations closely .
 President Griffiths has expressed his goals frequently, both before and after his election . Griffiths says he is committed to achieving his goals in the future .
 ASCC should be modified to allow future ASCC members to continue such execution without confusion . ASCC's mechanical functions should be executed competently and efficiently . The organization itself should also be modified so that future members may continue such executions without confusion, he says .
 ASCC should deal with substantive issues concerning the student's position on CC's campus . ASCC must also deal with the student position on the campus of CC .
 ASCC can push, on a sound basis, for meaningful, progressive policy changes . If it is, it will push for meaningful policy changes, ASCC says . ASCC is in a position to push for progressive policies .
 President Griffiths is taking a lead from far more important deliberative bodies, he says . Committees can most effectively handle the details, and deliberations about details, of student government .
 The ASCC's Monday meetings are able to deal with fifteen or more areas of student government swiftly and finally . The result is that the meetings can be completed quickly and efficiently . ASCC meetings can also deal with student government issues .
 If these meetings seem dull, then that is the price of effective student government, says student leader . Students should be aware of what is involved in the business conducted, he says .
 The progress of ASCC toward the goals mentioned above has been encouraging, but much, certainly remains to be done . ASCC's progress in the community is encouraging .
 The Constitution Committee has already produced needed amendments to the constitution, and more are forthcoming . Commissioner Bill Greeley has led the hard-working leadership of the committee .
 The Judicial Committee, ably chaired by Bob Kendall, is currently conducting an exhaustive study into the workings and scope of our student judicial bodies .
 The finance committee, chaired by Treasurer Bill Stafford, has studied money requests thoroughly and proposed the budget . The budget will appear in the TIGER today .
 Many other examples could be mentioned here, but it is our hope that they will, by their actions, speak through the news columns of this paper .
 We do not hold that the measure of student government is the length or heatedness of its meetings, the intensity of the publicized controversy among its members or the number of headlines it or its members get for attacks on the school administration . We don't hold that .
 We look rather for its sound and enduring accomplishments, for its hard and honest effort and for the quality of its work, we say . We look forward to the future of the U.S. government .
 ASCC currently compares very favorably with other student governments with which we are familiar with . ASCC is currently ranked higher than any other student government in the world .
 If our student government can continue to set forth accomplishments of quality and lasting value, we shall be content that ASCC has a great deal more meaning than simply the manifestations of a useless tradition . ASCC will be content if it continues to set out accomplishments that have lasting value .
 We recommend to ASCC's critics that they attend its meetings and the meetings of its committees, that they set forth their own ideas . The council has failed to meet its purposes or has wrongly interpreted the issues at hand, we say .
 Criticism of this kind cannot help but make student government more than a bothersome custom . When It's Music It's Millers Miller Music Co. Co.

 Summer jobs in Europe are now available to almost every American college student . Summer jobs are offered in Continental Europe . Summer summer jobs are available in Europe for college students .
 The American Student Information Service, known as ASIS, has more than 3,000 summer jobs in their files awaiting applicants . ASIS is a service that helps students prepare for summer jobs . The summer jobs are in the files of ASIS .
 ASIS has placed thousands of U.S. college students in various summer jobs throughout 11 European countries . In the past four years ASIS students have been placed in various jobs throughout Europe .
 Jobs are mostly unskilled and many do not require a knowledge of a foreign language . Many of the jobs in the United States are unskilled jobs that require a language knowledge .
 Monthly wages range from room and board in Spain to §150 for the highest paid positions in West Germany . Room and board wages in Spain range from $150 to $150 for a position in Germany .
 Jobs include factory work, resort work, construction work, farm work, hospital work and hospital work . Child care, child care, camp counselling positions and many other positions .
 Students will receive the dame wages as the Europeans with whom they are working . Students will also receive the same wages as Europeans with which they work .
 A summer job in Europe can defray the cost of the trip as much as 50 per cent . In addition to an opportunity to personally get to know "the man behind the counter" in Europe, a summer job can also be a great way to get a job .
 ASIS, 22 Avenue de la Liberte, Luxembourg, is a Luxembourg-based organisation . ASIS is a non-profit organisation dedicated to international causes . For more information, visit ASIS.

 Born in the famed Tokay mountains of Hungary, Stephen Kovacs passed the difficult entrance examinations at the Franz Liszt Royal Academy of Music in Budapest at the unprecedented age of five . Kovacs is one of the world's most accomplished musicians .
 Fourteen years later he was graduated from this distinguished music school with the highest honors . He was awarded the highest honor at the school .
 A triumphant debut followed in Berlin where the leading critics compared him with the greatest masters of the keyboard . A triumph in Berlin followed by a triumphant debut in Berlin .

 This enables him to keep 13 complete and formidable concert programs under immediate command . He has a total of 13 programs under his command .
 Mr Kovacs walked on the stage and played it for the first time in April, 1960 . Kovacs played the program in April 1960 .
 The audience will also be handed the complete program of all thirteen recitals to convey the scope of Mr Kovacs' tremendous repertoire .
 Mr Kovacs reportedly is the only artist on the stage today who offers the unique feature of playing any one of thirteen concert programs on a moment's notice .

 Library named in memory of the late jharles Learning Tutt, president of the El Pomar Foundation, who died Vrt'fitiber 1stulti-million dollar building .
 From the bottom up, the new library consists of a garden level opening on one side to a sunken court, a glass-walled main floor, and third and fourth floors walled with pre-cast concrete panels measuring 11 by 22 feet each .
 Two upper stories will be pierced by six-inch wide vertical strip windows . The two upper stories of the building will have six inch wide vertical windows .
 The entire building is supported by 35 eighteen-inch-square concrete pillars . 35 pillars are flared at the top to form a modern version of a colonnade .
 Library will contain seminar rooms, typing rooms, microcard room, special collection room, tape recording rooms, periodicals room, administrative offices, and stacks . Library will provide more than 70,000 square feet of floor space .

 Two Colorado College history professors said last week a permanent organization to promote the study of the history of Western America may be in the making . Plans Emerge for a permanent Western American Historical Society .
 Professors Louis B Geiger and Harvey L Carter said western historians already are taking steps to organize a conference on the history of Western America . The conference will take place in western America .
 Preliminary plans for a permanent western historical organization emerged at a conference of western historians last October 1214 in Santa Fe, New Mexico . Preliminary proposals emerged at the conference in 1214, 1214 at Santa Fe .
 An organization committee will meet in Milwaukee Valley Historiing the Mississippi Valley Historical Association Convention . A formal organizational meeting will be held in Denver next October .

 The Colorado College scientist will discuss colloids, colloids and the modern theories of acids and bases . The scientist will also discuss acidbase reactions .
 Colorado College science professors are visiting high schools throughout the area . The visit is one of a series of science professors making to high schools .
 The trips are co-sponsored by the National Science Foundation and the Colorado Wyoming Academy of Science . The trips will take place in Wyoming and Colorado .
 A cast, made up of faculty and students, has been selected for the Colorado College production of tinGreek drama, ""Oedipus Rex," scheduled to open December 7 for two-evening run in Perkins Hall .
 Eleven members of the faculty and 24 students have been chosen for roles in the 2,500-year-old play by Sophocles .
 It will be under the direction of William E McMillen, associate professor of speech and drama at the University of Cambridge .
 It was used extensively by Aristotle in his analysis of what a tragedy should be and for the requirements of the tragic hero . Aristotle used the tragedy extensively in his theory of tragedy .
 Dr. William R Hochman, associate professor of history, will have the rote of Oedipus . Dr. Dr. Hochmen will have a rote from Oedepus .
 Neale R Reinitz, associate professor of English will play the Priest; John H Lewis, instructor in geology, will play Creon; Dr. Creon . Dr. Neale H Reinitz will play Professor Creon and Dr. Lewis will play Englishman .
 Dr. Wilbur Wright, professor of physics, as the messenger from Corinth . Dr. Dr. Wright was the messenger for Corinth .
 Kenneth Burton, assistant professor of religion and minister at Shove Memorial Chapel, as Choragus . Kenneth Burton is a minister at the chapel .
 Two students, Ethel Six Geary and Mary Pat Hill, double-cast in two roles . Two students have been double-crowned in the roles .
 Each will play the part of Jocasta and the role of the maidservant . The pair will be alternating in the roles on different nights .
 Students cast in supporting roles include Leland Larson, Caspar Benzins, Ann Brooks, Dennis Sauve, Patricia K Dodge, Linda Hamilton, Barbara Blair, Ingrid Swenson, Polly Miller, Sarah Jamison, Caroline Sanborn, and Johanna Waller .
 The chorus, which in Greek plays provides the necessary exposition, includes three faculty members and nine students . The chorus also includes nine students from the university .
 Paul Kutsche, junior, assistant professor of sociology and anthropology; Robin M Rudoff, instructor in history; and Dr. Dr. Paul K. Rudoff is professor of history and sociology at University of Wisconsin .
 Students in the chorus include Vernon Olivier, Ray Boyce, Fred MeKee, Christopher Flower, William B Grabouski, Dale Spall, Ben Lyon, and Carl Chard .

 Colorado College Tiger Honor System Explored by Caroline Creyke . Last spring, a poll was taken of the student body to determine the effectiveness of the system .
 Suggestions to improve the quality of freshman orientation were made by those who felt there was not adequate orientation . The individual professors concept of the system is up to the individual professors .
 64% of students agreed with the present violation system . Support of the system was shown by the* fact that 64% agreed with it .
 15^ felt that penalties should be administered according to the degree of the violation . However, 15^ thought that penalties would be administered based on the severity of a violation .
 In another section of the questionnaire, a student stated that he felt the honor system was somewhat weakened by the fact that many professors don't follow the rules .
 Another commented that it was hard to adjust but was worth it . "Not to the system, itself, but to the fact that my personal integrity was on trial," another said .
 The honor system has great significance as a basis for independent achievement plus integrity, integrity and personal pride . These are the bases of all human relationships, says Dr. Richard Quest .
 Honor Council President Stew Ritchie says he feels the council is working quite well .
 In the past years the H.C. has heard about a fairly consistent percentage of the cheating, and this number has been going down . This number of cheating is going down, says the president of the state .
 Stew stressed the necessity for people to turn in suspected violators and let the H.C. decide whether or not cheating occurred . Stew stressed that people have a responsibility for turning in suspected offenders .
 An honor system offers ""advantages to the individual for further development of his self mastery and self development,"" Stew stated, Ruth Snodgrass, a three year member of the council, feels that the system is only effective in its ideal .
 The honor system, she stated, has to judge a case on the basis of one person's word against another's . She said the honor system has to be based on one word against one's .
 "The minute we have to come in in in an enforcement capacity, we've failed," says the government . "We've failed. We've failed to do so," says President Obama . "The moment we have come in is the moment we fail, we have failed," he says
 Bob Kendall, also a three-year member, says that judging by the surveys and polls, the system is quite effective .
 The honor council can't really tell how much cheating there is, but he's sure that there is some that the council doesn't ever hear about . He says the honor council has no idea how many cheating there are .
 He feels that the public relationships and orientation program of the honor souncil are quite good . The honor council is based in Washington, D.C.
 "If an honor system is not properly operated by those in it, it will fail," he says . He would hate to work in an institution that didn't have a good honor system .
 "The students must report it when they see violators, they must not be hesitant or afraid,"" he stated .

 "Niblet people had changed the entire character of the Green Giant," the author says . "Somebody changed the whole thing of the Giant," he says .
 No longer is the gruff green man who would stalk the corn fields clutching a can of Niblets to his chest . Instead, he's a man who stalked the fields with a can and a can .
 We find the Green Giant sitting on a mountain top with his head resting on his chin and, across his face, a beatific expression . Instead, we find the green giant sitting in front of us, sitting with his hands on his head .
 The picture shows corn stalks in the foreground and a charming little red farm house in the center . The picture was taken at a farm in the middle of a corn field in the country .
 Green Giant is so proud of his corn family that he often sits and watches it grow inch by inch . Folks in Green Giant land say he often watches the corn family grow . The Green Giant often sits in front of the corn to watch it grow .
 The Green Giant doesn't have the time to sit around and watch corn grow inch by inch . "The Green Giant" has no time for sitting around and watching the corn grow .

 Student Guide Service Aids GG Administration . New group formed for the purpose of aiding the school administration .
 The main duty of the group is to show the campus to prospective students and guests of the college .
 The Student Guide Service was started under the leadership of Rastall Center Board, with Lani Markisen in charge . Lani is in charge of the Student Guide Services .
 She worked with Mr Nicholl, the assistant Director of Admissions, in setting up the purposes of the service .
 Each member of the group is expected to know much about the past and future of Colorado College and what this college can offer to the prospective student .
 The guides, the admissions office feels, can answer many questions of the prospective student which do not come up in an interview with the admissions director . The guides can also be used to get a better idea of the school's qualities from the student body .
 The people making up this year's Student Guide Service are Suky Arentz, Suzanne Armstrong, Mary Bardone, Bradford Chase, Betsy Crockett, Polly Franklin, Ann Gourley, Donna Hampton, Walt Hecox, Erv Hinds, Raechel Jensen,
 This group hopes to become independent of Rastall Center and become an honorary club like the Black and Gold and Tigers Clubs, within the next few years .
 Another round of Peace Corps Placement Tests will be given on November 28th and 29th in testing centers throughout the nation . The tests will be held at testing centers across the country .
 The tests will begin at 8:30m. and last for six hours, with one hour out for lunch . The tests are expected to last for up to six hours .
 One is designed for men and women who would like to be considered for positions as secondary school or college teachers . The other is designed to be a secondary teacher .
 Many applicants will be applicants who have sent in a Peace Corps questionnaire since the last round of testing . Many of those who will take the examinations will be those who sent in the questionnaire .
 Both men and women who are interested and who have not yet filled out a Peace Corps questionnaire will also be permitted to take the examinations . The examinations will be open to both men, women and women .
 They will be accommodated on a ""space available"" basis at the testing centers . The testing centers will be on a 'space available' basis .
 The local testing center is the Main Post Office on Nevada and Pikes Peak . It is located on the main road between Nevada and Nevada Peak .
 Lenin and the country he created from Romanoff ruins were on prominent display at 11 o'clock Tuesday morning . ""A Visual Picture of Russia"" was presented as the first of a two part assembly program on the Soviet Union .
 The color slide and film format portrayed four main facets of modern Russia . The film format was shot in a color slide .
 Mr nitz's slides reflected the intense Soviet emphasis on industrial and agricultural success . The slides reflect an intense Soviet focus on industrial success .
 Russia's historical past reflected as Julie Bohlke commented on her slides of Leningrad . Richard Paine gave the audience an inside view of the Kremlin .
 Miss Bohlke pointed out such landmarks of the ""Venice of the North"" as the famous Winter Palace . She also emphasized the great popularity of soda and ice cream stands along Nevsky Boulevard .
 Mr Paine reminded the audience that the inside of the Kremlin is as large as downtown Colorado Springs . The many onion-domed cathedrals and the huge two-hundred ton ""King Bell"" were of particular interest .
 The face of modern Russia was reflected in the conversion of prerevoliition palaces to office buildings and in the stark modern architecture of massive apartment houses .
 Both Reinitz and Soule emphasized the great pride the Russians take in their parks and monuments .
 An excellent example was the fantastically ornate, chandeliered Moscow subway station .
 In portraying the attitudes of the Russian people, Reinitz mentioned that the general public usually appeared somewhat shabby, although it was by no means true that all Russians wore poorly fitting clothes .
 The high cost of clothing ( fifteen dollars for a rayon slip) was emphasized . The high cost of clothing was emphasized in the show .
 Both Miss Bohlke and Mr Soule dwelt on the friendliness of the people, even when communication was limited to sign language . The pair spoke to each other in a sign language interview .
 Mr Alexey Malyshev, who helpfully performed the necessary translations, will participate next Tuesday, November 28, as leader of a panel discussing the impact of the Soviet Union on travelers .
 College teaching and scientific research are two professions requiring training at an academicgraduate school . College teaching and scientific research require training at academicgraduate school .
 Members of the Graduate Fellowship Committee will be at the meeting . Professors Champion, Brooks, Reinitz, and Reinitz will attend .
 The curiosity of the Russian people about all things Western, and especially American, will be one of the subjects taken up at the second assembly program on the U.S.R. next Tuesday morning nt 11:00 .
 Mr Paine, who speaks ■ fluent Russian, engaged in a number of impromptu street-comer conversations .
 Oscar Soule, another panel member, was most interested in the Russian conception of life in the United States, particularly with regard to segregation . The panel was also interested in how the U.S. has dealt with segregation in Russia .
 The attitude of the Russians toward their own government, their own expressions of opinion on such topics as war and peace, and some of their feelings on moral and social questions will be considered at next Tuesday's program .
 Mr Alexey Malyshev, assistant professor of Russian at CC, will contribute his knowledge of the Russian character .
 Janet Cosby has been managing this series of programs for the assembly committee . The assembly committee is meeting in New York City for the first time this week .

 In the past week, the reader has undoubtedly seen greater tributes to the deceased ""Mr Sam"" than we can pen . Mr McCormack's funeral will be attended by his family and friends .
 We feel compelled to add our voice to those of eulogy, and also to look for a moment beyond the fact of Sam Rayburn's death to the state of congressional government . We are compelled to look beyond that fact of his death to state of Congress .
 He served in the House of Representatives from that day until one day a few months ago . He served as a member of Congress from that time to one day ago .
 For one third of his 48 years on Capitol Hill, he served as Speaker of the House . He served as a Democrat for more than 48 years .
 His steady hand guided the House from the New Deal through world war, through the Fair Deal, through McCarthyism, through Modern Republicanism and through Cold War to the New Frontier .
 His guidance was consistent in fairness and firmness, in integrity and respect, in political realism and foresighted statesmanship, he says . He says .
 Sam Rayburn held the respect of four presidents, untold congressmen, and countless Americans in public and private life . Rayburn was the second most powerful man in the land .
 We can add little to the eloquent tributes paid Mr Sam by these people . Mr Sam's funeral will be held in New York City, New York .
 The U.S. has lost one of its greatest incarnations of the ideals of representative government . Yet we do want to say that the United States has lost a great thing .
 We wonder if this statement does not also point up the seriousness of Mr Sam's passing . But we wonder if it does also point to the serious seriousness of his passing .
 "It was unifying a body of individuals who are in a large sense independent of the President, the Speaker, and one another," he said .
 It was using the full force of a great and respected personality, of political compromise and fairness, to meet the crushing demands of world tension and mass society — demands magnified .
 There are many congressmen, unknown outside their districts except to the closest observers, who work and work very hard, year after year, to promote the ideals represented by Rayburn .
 Any one of them could rise to the occasion, and could build quickly, given the pressure of time, build quickly the respect and prestige which served Rayburn as a powerful tool time after time .
 Most likely successor to Rayburn, John McCormack of Massachusetts, is not, in our opinion, one of these men . McCormack is not likely to succeed Rayburn .
 He does not now command sufficient respect among his own party members . Many are dissatisfied with his majority leadership, many are unhappy with him .
 McCormaek's open and publicized break with the President over school aid makes him an unlikely successor to the tradition of conciliation left by Mr Sam . McCormaeks' break with President Obama makes him a likely successor to Mr Sam.
 There is little evidence that Mr McCormack has or can exercise the far-ranging and far-sighted political judgment which characterized Rayburn . McCormack is not likely to exercise the same judgment as Rayburn, writes Andrew Hammond .
 Many of his less-known colleagues, on the other hand, could exercise such judgment . Many of these colleagues could exercise their judgment, too .
 McCormack took the Speaker's chair in the closing weeks of the last session of Congress . McCormack was Speaker of the House of Representatives in the 1990s .
 We believe that the House, in the best interests of itself as an institution and of the nation as a whole, must replace Mr Sam with a man who, if not like him, can at least serve as well .
 Our readers who agree would do well to write their own Congressmen of their concern .
 We wish to help, in what ever way possible, to make representative government a continuing, worthwhile and vital part of our society .
 As a full-time student and a participant in the basic ROTC program, I feel compelled to reply to Mr Trushel's article (""Comment"") in the Tiger .
 Two years ago, faculty voted two to one against compulsory ROTC . Trushel says decision was based on 'mere whim or flight of fancy'
 In regard to this vote (which had no effect on the administration) the following actions were taken by the ROTC department . The vote did not affect the administration, but the actions of the department were taken .
 Trushel's assessment of the value of the ROTC's The Red Menace at Home and Abroad and The Care and Feeding of Your M-lays is worth 2 extra hours .
 I feel that Mr Trushel forgets that his friend is being a ""tine leader"" in an entirely imposed and unnatural circumstance and that he, as a cadet, is obeying out of a fear of punishment .
 Mr Trushel's belief that the ability to observe dirty brass and to say ""two demerits"" is ""True leadership" is what he might call the man who leads others to safety .
 Mr Trushel next tells us that ""the most common gripe"" is that ROTC is compulsory .

 Such programs are valuable additions to CC's already good assortment of extra-curricular programs . CC is a good place for students to take part in extra curricular activities .
 One of the real advantages to be found among these is that a student may choose to take in or to participate in those which have special interest or meaning to him .
 Of course, the pressures of time and conflicts in scheduling often limit a student's involvement in these activities .
 We wonder if most students are aware of the advantages to be found in these organized activities . Yet we wonder if they are not aware of these advantages .

 One might learn about useful physical activity, about faraway lands, about railroad research, about political organization on the precinct level .

 The members of the Executive Council shall take office during the month of May and shall serve one calendar year . They shall be sworn in at the beginning of the year .
 Representatives of the outgoing senior class shall serve until the end of the Spring Semester . Representatives of this class will serve until end of spring semester . Representatives will serve for the remainder of the year .
 The election of freshmen representatives shall be conducted the same as the other class representatives . No change will be made in this article .
 In case of a tie-vote for any ASCC office a run-off election shall be held within a week following the initial election . OMIT No change . ASCC No change.
 All rules pertaining to the initial election will be valid during the run-off election . Run-off elections will take place in the next two weeks .
 The person in each class receiving the highest number of votes in the class commissioner elections shall serve as president of that class . The person with the second highest amount of votes will serve as Secret ary-Treasurer of the class .
 The President of ASCC and the Election Committee shall tabulate the ballots . ASCC is the largest body of the ASCC .
 Written report of the results of the election shall be sent to each candidate by the Chairman of the ASCC Election Committee .
 The Chairman of the ASCC Election Committee will submit a report of the election results to the TIGER within one week following the election . ASCC election results will be submitted by the chairman of the committee .
 The ballots shall be packaged together with a copy of the results and stored in the ASCC files for one calendar year and then destroyed . The ballots will be packaged and stored together in the files .

 The subject of women's dorm hours was considered in last week's ""Comment"" column in preparation for a questionnaire received this week by the women dorm residents .
 The article misrepresented, to some extent, the ideas behind this questionnaire and its immediate purpose . The article was misrepresented by some extent .
 The Hours Committee is investigating the problem of women's hours . The present system seems faulty and is constantly being contested, at least verbally, says the committee .
 It is felt that while the present hours are necessary for freshmen, sophomores, and probably juniors, a senior woman is practically ready to go ""on her own"" and be considered responsible for all her actions .
 As a senior she is still restricted seems a poor preparation for the life after college . The fact that as a senior . as a . senior she . still . still seems to be a poor prepare for the . life after . college .
 The Hours Committee feels that one of the primary purposes of a liberal arts college is to help the student's ability to adjust and carry the responsibility for his studies now, as well as for later life .
 The idea of an honor dorm for senior women is one way of bringing responsibility back to the student . The honor dorm is meant to be a safe haven for women in order to be responsible for their education .
 Each girl would have her own key and would be responsible only to herself . Sign out would still be required for purposes of safety, but signing out is still required .
 Those senior women not interested in the honor dorm would live with underclass women . Underclass women would abide by the existing hours . Senior women would live in honor dorms with younger women .
 A letter will be sent to the parents of this year's junior and senior women to find out their feelings on the subject . If the results of last week's questionnaire seem favorable towards the idea of a senior women's honor dorm, a letter will also be sent .
 We want some people that cai actually paint good pictures, pla) a musical instrument, a short story, and many things — even if their major litical science . We want people that actually paint pictures, and that they can do anything .

 The student may be inclined to wonder just what his money is paying for . How much actually goes for the books, how much for operating costs, and how much is profit for the bookstore .
 Mary C Vickerman, manager of the Colorado College bookstore provided enough room to house the 5000 . Vickerman provided the following information .
 The prices on all books are set by the publishers, not by the bookstore, not the bookstore . The prices of all books will be based on the publishers' prices .
 Five percent of this goes to pay the postage in order to get the books here . Five percent goes to the postage .
 The bookstore takes approximately a 16% margin on which to operate, so actually no profit is made on textbooks . Manager of the bookstore stated that it takes approximately 16%.
 At the end of the year, any profit goes into the general college fund . And, at the end, any profits go to the college fund.
 The taking back and re-selling of used books is handled on a consignment basis . Used books can be taken back and sold on consignment at the store .
 Used books are sold for 75% of their original cost, the student receives 50% of the original cost . Used books can be purchased for up to 75% the cost of the student .
 Vickerman stated that all of this goes to pay for the red tape operations, such as bookkeeping and auditing, involved in the handling of these books . Vickerman: All of the money goes to paying for the bookkeeping, auditing and bookkeeping .
 Vicmentioned that someday she hopes the bookstore will be able to cover the paperback field . Vic mentioned that she hopes to cover paperback books in paperback .
