 Nearly two hundred high school debaters and coaches took part in CC's annual invitational debate tournament last Saturday .
 Palmer took first place in the tournament, with Regis and Denver South taking second and third places . The tournament was directed by Professor Woodson Tyree, Professor Robin Rudolf, Chris Griffiths, Dave Furgason, and Skip Meis .
 Individual victories in the extemporaneous division were Jim Cavalar, Regis, first place; Dave Fisher, Lincoln, second place; and Ken Sandoral, La Junta, third place .
 Bob Knight of Lincoln placed first, Dominic Enrietta of Trinidad placed second, and Mike Albi of Regis took third . Bob Knight placed first in the oratory division .

 Reports have come out of Washington concerning Bowles conduct since Kennedy administration began . Bowles' conduct has been a problem since then .
 He bypassed Secretary Dean Rusk to present his new ideas to the President himself . He often snarls or counteracts the policies of the State Department .
 Conducting foreign policy is a complex day-to-day operation which requires new insights . Conducting our foreign policy requires not only new insights but also responsible, experienced administration. Conducting such a complex operation requires an experienced administration .
 The replacement of Chester Bowles with a proven and experienced administrator from within the State Department is a step forward in creating an effective foreign policy . The replacement is a first step forward to creating a successful foreign policy.
 "Some of these activities are much more valuable than others," says CNN.com . "We believe, at the outset, that some of the activities are very valuable."
 We would argue that a student benefits more from these activities by allotting his time well, and from devoting his extra-curricular efforts to a few substantive activities . Moreover, a student would benefit more from allotting time well by devoting time well .
 One student might believe that certain activities have such value, another not . One student, however, may believe that such activities have value .
 In any case, the point is simply that a value judgment is involved in selecting activities, and a student ought to make that judgment with some thought .
 A second facet of this value judgment is that of the time involved, the author says . The time involved is the time it takes to make a decision .
 We would contend that students suffer in either of two ways by misusing the time they set aside for extra-curricular activities . Students suffer either way of misusing time set aside to take part in extra curricular activities .
 They either give time to so many activities that they can participate fully or effectively in none, or they can get so involved in a single activity that they deprive themselves of any of the benefits of other activities .
 Our extra-curricular activities are an important part of our college experience . We are proud of our students' efforts to participate in extra curricular activities .
 In this class students would be expected to complete a full length book, poetry collection, or any of the other modes of creative writing .
 The only part of the work that would be done in the classroom would be that which the student desired to do; i.e., if a student should have some general or specific writing problem, we would be free to consult his professor at certain specified times; . In fact, the
 At the end of the first semester, the student would turn in his completed work for criticism . If this course was intended to run two semesters, the students working on shorter problems would revise their work . Those working on novels, or other extended assignments would spend the second semester finishing and
 The student enrolled in this course should be allowed complete freedom of choice in his selection of the type of writing he desired to do . However, an attempt should be made to limit the choice to include creative writing at which the professor was particularly proficient in explaining .
 The truly creative student does not need the enticement of credit and possible publication of his work to write . Students should not be enticed into writing, they say .
 Many students would take a course in creative writing feeling it would be a ""snap course,"" and would be in over their heads . Students would take the creative writing course in fear they would be over-over-run .
 It is true that many people are creative without added incentives, but it should not be necessary for a student to sacrifice time that could be used for a credit course in order to write .
 A creative writing class would make it possible for many students to discover talent they were not aware of, or develop a writing hobby into a writing career . Also, a creative writing course would help students discover talent and develop a career .
 "I feel that there are sufficient number of interested students on this campus to make such a course worth the college's time and effort," says Loyoy .

 Your coop eralj J Ttom the Chair by Chris Griffiths . We in college find ourselves in a unique social situation . We are in the midst of a social situation.
 A great deal of confusion arises when we feel that we are expected to act as adults and are treated as children . We are not expected to be treated as adults or children, says the author of the children's book .
 We often do not recognize ourselves as responsible members of a society . We often don't recognize themselves as responsible people, says author .
 Since we are not financially interdependent, we feel no social interdependence . Since we don't feel financial interdependency, we have no social  interdependency . We are not interdependent on each other .
 We live in close contact with one another and yet we do not recognize the need for social order . We live with each other but we don't recognize social order. We do not need social order, we need to be socialized .
 He is watching over us and our only responsibility is to avoid his all powerful hand . Our only responsibility to avoid him is avoiding him. He is looking over us, and we must avoid him .
 We are satisfied to let him run things until his all-powerful hand slaps our patties, the cry of oppression is sounded. We are perfectly satisfied to allow him to run things . We are happy to let them run things, until he slaps his hand on our p
 By recognizing society and by acting as resp oris ble members of it we can bec 0B j our own ""all-powerful" hand .
 The problem with ma these organizations is that many of their cases are refers to them from above that, disciplinary acts have the app ea ance of parental slaps on the ha when they are intended to be . from one of their peers .
 If we are to be treats riday, as adult members of society w Mes tl must become such, says the author . Mestl must be treated as such as children and adults, he says .

 The Newspaper Fund wants to help promising undergraduate members of college newspaper staffs find summer news jobs . Summer news jobs will give them a chance to broaden their experiences .
 Each summer there are u number of attractive jobs for young men on top-quality, medium-sized newspapers .
 The Newspaper Fund offers to help students find the interested editors and will counsel them on how to apply . Students can also apply for the position of editor .
 This opportunity for summer work is primarily planned for sophomores and juniors who may have some interest in newspaper work, but who have not had a chance to make contacts in the newspaper field . This opportunity is intended for students who may be interested in journalism .
 Applications are sought especially from colleges where extensive journalism training has not ben available for the student . Applications for the position are sought . Applications are also sought from colleges with no journalism training available .
 A particular effort is being made to attract individuals who are now working on college newspapers . The effort is aimed at attracting individuals who work for college newspapers.
 The Newspaper Fund is supported by grants from The Wall Street Journal and has the cooperation of a number of newspapers in this effort to find summer newspaper jobs .

 A Colorado College chemistry professor is using a high frequency oscillator to study reactions of certain acids and bases in a long-range research project . The project may provide chemists with new information they can use as a research ""tool"" in such areas as rocket fuel production .
 Eldon Hitchcock, assistant this that professor of chemistry, frequency oscillator to the of chemical problems. Eldon T Hitchcock was assistant this . Hitchcock was a teacher of chemistry at the University of Cambridge .
 The five megacycle frequency oscillator operates much like an FM radio transmitter . The Colorado College scientist uses the device to create a radio signal .
 It enables chemists to study reactions of certain acids and bases that could not be observed by more traditional laboratory methods .
 This electronic equipment is opening up a new field of chemical research, Dr. Dr. John Defterios says . He says the equipment will open up new fields of research .
 The high frequency oscillator enables the scientist to observe how compounds are formed . It helps him better understand the speed of chemical reactions, and aids him in substance analysis .
 Throughout the years, most chemical reactions have been carried out in water, he said . Most of the chemical reactions are carried out using water .
 Hitchcock has been conducting experiments in such liquids as benzene, acetic acid, and acetonitrite . Hitchcock has conducted experiments in benzene and acetetic acid .
 The advantage of these liquids is that they permit certain reactions to occur that could not take place in water . The advantage is that these liquids are liquids that allow certain reactions that can't be made in water, say scientists .
 Colorado College chemistry professor says acid-base reactions in water are limited because of the acidic and basic character of water itself .
 He has been observing the reactions of compounds such as aluminum chloride and stannic . He is attempting to apply the high tudy chloride with alcohols, ethers, and various nitrogen-containing compounds .
 Research chemists are concerned with compounds that can be used in controlling the speed of reactions . He noted that research chemists want to use compounds to control reactions .

 The scholar-teacher program was developed with assistance from the Ford Foundation . The program integrates the study of theoretical concepts, extensive practice in the art of teaching .
 The twelve fields for which the program provides preparation are biology, chemistry, English, French, geography, German, history, mathematics, physics, Russian, Spanish, and social studies .
 Students with good records of preparation in the liberal arts are eligible to be considered . Students with sufficient concentration for graduate study in onL> of the twelve teaching fields are eligible for consideration . Students must also have good records in liberal arts and sufficient concentration in graduate study .
 Criteria for selection includes intellectual capacity, scholarly aptitudes, and assessment of personality and other characteristics relevant to effective teaching . Criteria also include intellectual capacity and scholarly aptitude .

 A maximum fund-raising effort to provide an ice skating rink and a modern tri-level sports building at CC was announced this week .
 The $1,200,000 sports center will be located to the west of Rastall Center, and to the south of Cossit Hall, CC's halfcentury-old physical education building, to form a unified recreation complex .
 Full-size outdoor rink, with artificial ice surface, will be located on the site of the old Cossit Hall ampitheater . The outdoor rink is located between the college union and the new sports center .
 The rink will afford both recreational skating and a practice rink for freshman and intramural hockey squads from November through March . The rink is expected to be used for both recreational and practice purposes .
 All home varsity hockey games will continue to be played at the Broadmoor World Arena .
 Colorado College has raised $250,000 for construction of new sports facility . Colorado College Campaign program has top priority in the coming year . $250k has already been raised .
 A keystone gift was made by Gerald Sehlessman, class of '17, and members of his family . Gerald L Sehelessman was a member of the class of class '17 .
 In addition to the ice rink, the sports center will contain an indoor swimming pool, a regulation varsity basketball court with a seating capacity of 3,000, a gymnastic area, a wrestlingboxing area, locker rooms, classrooms, and offices .
 For education in the sixties we now have superb facilities on their way in the Tutt Library, the Olin Science Hall and the renovations going on in other class buildings . We now have a superb library, science hall and science hall .
 The new sports building features a multi-valt roof . Colorado Springs is being designed by Colorado Springs architects Lusk and Wallace .
 The Olympic-sized, glass-enclosed swimming pool will be at the east end, near the outdoor ice rink . The pool is expected to be Olympic-size at the end of the Olympic swimming pool .
 Memorial gifts will be emphasized throughout the fund-raising campaign . Memorial gifts are being offered in support of the family .
 Names of contributors of more than one thousand dollars will be displayed on a special plaque in the sports center foyer .
 His literary sensitiviey was wittily expressed as he spoke of the attributes of various authors . He maintained that a true writer does not feel fulfilled unless he writes a little every day .
 The Irish author and critic's Thursday night lecture was entertaining, informative, and a welcome relief from the slightly aging onslaught of the New Criticism .
 Mr O'Faolain said his actual subject would be the role of pleasure as a critical tool, particularly in reference to the noval . While titling his talk ""Trial by Pleasure,"" or ""It's Good if You Like It,""
 He maintained that the arts were originally created from an impulse whose satisfaction gave the creator a sense of delight . The arts were created from a impulse that satisfied the creator's satisfaction .
 He then examined the extreme subjectivity which essentially limits this sense of delight . He said he then examined how it is possible to have a sense of joy .
 Just as one projects one's self into a painting, the reader ""dives"" into a novel to become immersed in a vicarious existence . Thus, just as one . projects one’s self into . a painting . The reader "dives" into a . novel to
 The experience is contained in ""a number of black dots on a white page,"" yet may become, for the moment, actual, actual . The fact that the experience is . contained in a number of . black dots is indicative of the illusory nature of art and the .
 Mr O'Faolain suggested that the modern reader, properly indoctrinated by analytic handbooks, judges a novel bifocally . The modern reader is unwilling to lay aside his rationalistic shield to let the work communicate emotionally .
 In order to project Ids ideas, the author must break through this ""filter"" composed of traditional concepts, .moral values, and religious and political ideas . Ids must also break through traditional concepts and moral values, to project ideas .
 O'Faolain accused the New Criticism of fostering this filter by attempting to impose the ""pure light of reason"" on emotional Impact . O' Faolain said the New Critical Criticism attempts to impose a filter on emotional impact .
 When the novel is placed on the dissecting table, the sum of its parts often does not equal tinwhole . The sum of the parts of the novel does not always equal tin whole .
 French novelists led the list of works which Mr O'Faolain felt pierced the filter . French novelistists were also included in the list .
 Malraux' Man's Fate, Provost's Munon Lescaut, and Laelos' Leu Liuisonw Dangereux . Included were The Red and the Black, Man the Black and Man the Fate, and The Man of the Black .
 James Joyce's Portrait of the Artist, by James Joyce, Maughm's Of Human Bondage, and Turgenev's Torrents of Spring comprised the remainder of the list .
 Mr O'Faolain later admitted that literary criticism is relevant and necessary, at least until one develops an inherent critical faculty . While seemingly denying the functional need of one facet of his profession, he later admitted to the need for literary criticism .
 Since comparisons are inevitable, the reader is advised to make his own . The reader is asked to share his own thoughts of the book .
 We would rather like to pose some serious questions to those who pause to read these columns . We ask: What do you think of the world's most powerful people?
 The real meaning of Christmas lies far deeper than just the event of Jesus' birth . The real Christmas is not just the birth of Jesus, it's the meaning of the Christmas Day itself .
 It lies in the panorama of human experience — joy, sadness, tragedy, tragedy and despair, despair, bitterness, and hope — through which Christ moved in the thirty-three years following the first Christmas . Christ moved through this panorama, through which he moved through the years following
 Christ and Christmas are meaningless unless the reality of human experience and the well-spring of hope, both inseparable part of the life, death, and rising of Jesus, are taken into account . Jesus' life and death are inseparable parts of his life, his death and his rise
 We suggest that the 'Christmas Spirit,' to the Christian, should not be manifested in a diversionary or abstract joy, but in reflection upon the whole meaning of Christ's coming .
 It should be rooted in the quiet hope of Bethlehem's winter night and of a certain dawn, some thirty-three years later, when three mourning women came to an empty tomb .
 Even if one doesn't accept the theology of Jesus' coming, he can still find, in the life and death of the carpenter from Galilee, much to ponder . The carpenter's life and the death of Jesus is a life of a carpenter .
 For that life and that death were not abstracted fairy-tale style to take place somewhere in the clouds, they were for that life . For that, for that, they would not have been abstracted .
 Jesus lived among men and shared their common experiences, dealing with them as a man . Jesus lived with men and dealt with them in a unique way of living with them .
 We might suggest to Christians and non-Christians alike that they explore the ""Christmas Spirit"" among men to see if there is within it some good, some enduring quality which offers hope .
 We seek only to pose questions here, not answers, in the hope that those who ponder these questions may find real meaning in this Christmas season . We seek to ask questions not answers but to seek real meaning .
 Proposed changes to Student Conduct Committee's constitution represent a sound achievement on the part of student government and a step forward in student-administration relations .
 First, they resolve the ambiguities and confusion over jurisdiction which have plagued CC's judicial system in the past . They resolve the ambiguity and confusion that have plagued the judicial system . The first step is to clear up the ambiguity of jurisdiction in the case .
 First, they give students more of a voice, accompanied by more responsibility, in handling disciplinary problems . Second, they also give students a voice in dealing with disciplinary problems. Third, they say students have a voice and responsibility for disciplinary issues .
 First, they take a realistic account of the powers, prerogatives, and qualifications of the college administration . Second, they say the college's powers should be taken into account .
 The changes, by being realistic and flexible, ought to serve the college community well for many years . Finally, the changes should serve the community well, as well as many others .
 We congratulate Commissioner Bob Kendall and his Judicial Committee, to the Student Conduct Committee and the Committee on Undergraduate Life . President Griffiths and the ASCC Executive Council also congratulate the Commissioner .
 All have made major contributions to these proposals, and the proposals represent a major contribution to better student government . All of the proposals have been made by students at the university .

 The meal hours continue to be weird; breakfast when you get up, lunch any time after two and dinner after ten . Breakfast is breakfast when the person gets up, and lunch when the time is after two .
 There is a 2-3 hour break for lunch for the working people, and although it has been tried many times to put them on an ""American schedule,"" they continue stubbornly to be Spanish . The favorite pastime for the men continues to be going to the local barf
 Sometimes the problems of the world consist of playing dominoes or shooting dice . Sometimes the world consists of playing a domino or playing a dice game . Sometimes, the world's problems are solved by shooting dice and dominoing .
 The big day for the children is Epiphany, when the Three Kings come with their gifts . The Three Kings will come with gifts to the children at the age of 12 .
 Twelfth Night also has a special cake, with trinkets baked in, and if you get one, it's good luck . If you get a cake baked in it, it will be good luck for the rest of the year .
 New Year's Eve parties are where you eat twelve grapes at every stroke of midnight . The best ones are the private ones with small groups of friends . Then there are the best ones with private parties .
 Today is Assumption, a very important holiday in Spain, and because it preceeds a weekend which precedes a very short week before vacation, the students ""make a bridge,"" and go home now .
 The sixth year medical students were threatened with being flunked if they went home now — yes, they went . The sixth-year medical students went home after being threatened with flunking if they didn't .

 Sophocles' Tragedy Chosen As CC's First ""Guinea Pig"" by James H Fox . The rise and fall of the proud, dynamic heir to the curse on the House of Labdacus .
 Sohpocles is a simple production of Purcell's opera, but simplicity of production is the rule . The opera is set in a simple setting, with no extras and costumes .
 The backdrop sacrificed taste on the altar of artiness . The backdrop's glaring symbolism sacrificed taste for artiness.
 William Hochman almost redeemed his failure to fully express the title role's driving curiosity and enormous compassion and vanity . The film is set in New York, New York .
 He received a respectful applause from his fellow actors and the audience for creating an Oedipus of stature and intelligence .
 At least half of the chorus didn't understand what they were saying, nor that they were on stage during their periods of silence . I have mixed feelings about the chorus, including some who were not on stage .
 Donald Jenkins, dividing his voices into tenors and baritones, occasionally achieved striking effects, particularly in Ode II, "Let us all be reverent in the ways of right,"" before the entrance of the Corinthian Messenger. the production's impressi' climax.
 Roberts pushed his blocking dangerously close to overacting, but his energy and control kept the audience engrossed .
 In the bitter, ironic scene between Oedipus and Tiresias, Paul Barnard's blind prophet, powerful in vision, was delightfully human in fear, anger, and finally pity for the doomed ruler .
 John Lewis was only superficially Creon, a simple, direct, basically good man, who has no desire for the responsibilities of power . Although sufficiently logical and conservative, he was sufficiently conservative and conservative .
 She possessed the voice and appearance, but lacked sensitivity, as did the wooden, weak.gestured Priest, who almost suffocated the play's kick-off, and the nervous, flippant Palace Messenger .
 Kenneth Burton, as Choragus, for beautifully expressing devotion and some understanding of the protagonist's suffering . Laurels go to Kenneth Burton for beautifully, simply expressing devotion .
 David Hand's lighting design and well-proportioned and playable steps, pillars, and platforms added technical strength to the show . David Hand’s lighting design, delicately working from dawn to sunset, worked from dusk to sunset .
 Tocos & Pizza CC Greek Production Rated As ""Admirable"" Wednesday, Thursday and Friday of last week, CC witnessed a production of Sophocles' tragedy Oedipus Rex .
 Sophocles' powerful presentation of the workings of fate . Those who concentrated on the lines, the essence of the Greek drama, could not miss the play .
 The modern audience is oriented to the reality of action, not long dialogue, says CNN.com's John Sutter.com .
 The audience tended to become inattentive and thus lose much of the play's significance in spite of the good articulating of both actors and chorus . Therefore, especially during the choric odes, the audience tends to become distracted during the play .
 The translation itself was generally inferior and even ludicrous at times in its attempt to modernize the script . The play as a whole weakened the play as well as the translation itself . Also the fact that the translated itself was . generally inferior .
 Another factor which weakened this production was the cluttered appearance of the stage . The production was also criticised for being too cluttered .
 The general set design and lighting were very good, but there were too many people on the stage for its size . The set design was very good but there was too much room for the stage .
 Most easily dispensed with would have been the suppliants, whose floating and hovering about was very distracting and added nothing but confusion and clutter . Most easily . dispensed . from would have had to be removed from the scene .
 Dr. Hochman made a tragically imposing Oedipus (although he seemed .much older than his mother) The film was directed by Gene Seymour Seymour, who directed it in New York .
 Bernard was convincing at Tiresias the blind prophet; and Reverend Burton made a forceful Choragus . Reverend Burton also played a forceful role in the play . St. Bernard made a convincing performance at Tireias .
 The weakest character appeared at the end in the person of Dr. Dr. Martin . Unfortunately, the weakest character in the film was Dr. Jan .
 His FlashGordon appearance and excited delivery detracted from the double tragedy of Jocasta's death and Oedipus' selfbinding .
 The productio was a success, for it had the power to move those who understood it and appreciated it for what it was . Nevertheless, the productio a success .

 Colorado College has received grants totalling $170,000 from the National Science Foundation for three science institutes to be conducted next summer for high school teachers . NSF Grants $ 170,000 For Summer Institute .
 This the second such series of grants the college has received from the foundation . This is the second time the foundation has given the college grants .
 The faculty development grant is designed to encourage additional professional development of individual teachers at Colorado College . Colorado College will use the grant to help develop individual teachers .
 The grant to the three science departments is designed to "recognize the critical importance of teachers of engineering, mathematics, and the physical sciences,"" Upchurch said .

 The violinist, Giorgio Ciompi, is well known to Colorado College and the community . He has been a member of the artist faculty in the last three Tryouts Arranged .
 Field Biology Insti,ute will be given at Aspen in cooperation with the Aspen Institute ■if Humanistic Studies . The field biology Insti.ute will also be given in cooperation .
 The institutes are designed to keep high school science teachers posted on recent dvelopments in the i i' fields and to help them improve classroom effectiveness .
 $88,000 was earmarked for the Institute in Science and Mathematics . About 70 high school teachers will be enrolled in the eight week course .
 Two-thirds of students will be participating in the college's three-summer program leading toward a master of arts ""> teaching degree . The students will study in the summer program .
 The Institute is open to qualified science and mathematics teachfl ^ in junior and senior high schools and in junior colleges . This Program is under the direction of Or, Beidleman .
 The National Science Foundation set aside $40,300 for a Chemistry Institute . The Chemistry Institute will be held on the campus of the University of Washington .
 The six-week-long Chemistry Institute is designed to provide chemistry teachers with new insights that will enable them to present chemistry from a fresh point of view when they return to their classrooms .
 40 high school chemistry teachers are scheduled to take the course . Lester A Michel, professor and chairman of the chemistry department, said 40 teachers will attend .
 Beidleman and Robert B Lewis co-directors of the new eight week Institute in Field Biology . NSF has appropriated $42,500 for the new institute .
 The program is open to 32 high school biology teachers with at least three years of experience on the high school level . The program includes 32 biology teachers at 32 high schools .

 Alien Registration Deadline Revealed . Aliens in the United States will be required to report their addresses to the Attorney General within the near future .
 All aliens in the United States on January 1 each year must report their addresses by the end of the month . All aliens, with few exceptions, who are in the U.S. on New Year's Day must do so .
 Forms with which to make tinreport can be obtained from any Post Office or Immigration Office .
 The law provides penalties for failure to comply with the reporting requirement . Summer school sessions are required to take part in summer school sessions .

 Official Colorado College Student Publication STAFF; Heather Kirk. Jim Dunlor. Heather Kirk . Heather Kirk is a junior at Colorado College and a senior at the University of Colorado College . Jim Dunor is a senior member of the Colorado College College of Education .
 The columns of the TIGER were responsible for awakening again the belabored, and at that time dormant, issue of ROTC on CC's campus . The columns were responsible .
 In the first place, an issue of this sort, in a community such as this with a very rapid turnover in its population, is never settled . In the second place, the issue is never finally settled, says the mayor .
 The issue must, it seems, be reassessed by eveiy passing college ""generation,"" and this is probably a good thing . The issue will be re-evaluated by the passing college "generation"
 A new insight has come out of columns, letters to the editor, student comments, and student comments which have appeared in these pages recently . But more importantly, a new insight, or perhaps a new emphasis, has come from the columns and letters .
 The realization has emerged that the question of ROTC is related to the larger questions which face our society . The realization of the question has emerged is that it is related .
 The United States is today faced with the necessity of maintaining a massive military establishment . The U.S. faces the need to maintain a military presence .
 Throughout history, the existence of such a military establishment has proven itself incompatible with constitutional democracy . The presence of such an armed military establishment is incompatible with democracy, it has said .
 Standing armies have always been kept at a size less than military thinking would term adequate . Those who developed our government in the U.S. have long recognized this to be true, he says .
 The mainstay of our defenses has been the reserves — the citizen-soldiers . The nation's defense has been in the hands of its citizens, the president says .
 The purpose of the ROTC program is to train officers for these reserves . The purpose is to prepare officers for the reserves .
 It's not aimed at shaping career officers, but rather at training men who can, after college, take time out from their civilian pursuits to help maintain our defense system .
 The alternative to reserve officers, trained in an arts and sciences background, is the leadership of all our armed forces by academy-trained, professional soldiers . Academy-trained soldiers should be trained in arts and science backgrounds .
 One need only look at the present situation in France, among others, to see how dangerous this can be to constitutional democracy . The situation is particularly dangerous for constitutional democracy, writes Andrew Hammond .
 College-trained citizenofficers over against a professional, elite officer corps, we see little choice . Given these two alternatives, college-trained citizens over against elite officers, it's little choice.
 The Department of the Army would not, under present regulations, maintain the ROTC program on our campus unless a certain number of students were guaranteed for the program . The program would not be maintained under regulations, according to the Army .
 The only way, at present, is to meet that guarantee is to make basic ROTC compulsory . It is not the only way to meet this guarantee .
 If ROTC continues on a compulsory basis, male students will be deprived of their ""academic freedom" to some degree, and they will be subjected to some unpleasantness, says Simon Tisdall .
 If the program is discontinued, those who want to serve as reserve officers will be deprived of their means to do so . The Army will lose a source of well-and liberally-educated officers .
 This kind of program is disturbing to most students at an institution where freedom is supposed to be maximized and distracting unpleasantness minimized . Students at the University of Columbia University say it's disturbing .
 The ROTC program has more value than the charges against it can overbalance, says the U.S. Army .
 This is not to say that there are not severe shortcomings in the ROTC program . The program has been criticized for its lack of oversight by the Army .
 We will soon offer some constructive criticisms and suggestions . We believe there are there are, and we hope there will be constructive criticisms .

 Colorado College Tiger 12, \1b1 CC Students Often Enter Professorships . Students at CC stand a better than average chance of becoming college or university professors, survey shows .
 Colorado College is one of two, and the only private college, in the entire eight-state Rocky Mountain region ranking amoung the nation's top fifty institutions in the production of college teachers . The college is ranked in the top fifty schools in the nation .
 An average of more than twenty-four out of every 1,000 students at Colorado College will become college or university teachers . The report shows that an average of 24 out of 1,100 students at the college will become teachers .

 Fred A Sondermann, associate professor of political science, is trying to answer through a carefully designed two-part research project . The project is believed to be the first of its kind in the Rocky Mountain region . It is based on research conducted by a professor at the University of
 Sondermann is measuring the amount of foreign news stories appearing in four locally-read newspapers . He is interviewing a cross-section of the city's population to get the results .
 Two Denver newspapers, the Post and the Rocky Mountain News, and two Colorado Springs newspapers, are trying to determine how much of the total news space is devoted to foreign news . For the first phase of the project, he is trying to find out how much foreign news is covered by the
 Student measures the quantity of news copy, photographs and captions, and headlines dealing with not only the quantity, but also the foreign news developments . Assisted by a number of undergraduate political science majors, he is measuring the amount of copy copy, photos, captions .

 Colorado Spri ROTC — II: "We expressed the belief that the basic principles of the program and the alternatives to maintaining that program dictate that we continue it here at Colorado College" i Mnnamr.
 We believe that although compulsory ROTC may infringe on a student's academic freedom, it is not inconsistent with the classical concept of liberal education . We believe . that, although compulsory . ROTc may infringue on student's . academic freedom .
 In fact, this classical concept of liberal arts may often stand in conflict with a student's freedom of choice . The concept of a broad education may often conflict with students' freedom to choose . Students should be able to choose their own education, not just a liberal arts .
 It should strive to clear up misunderstandings which plague it and win the respect necessary for its proper and continued performance . Course material in ROTC classes should be carefully organized to better orient the student, to more adequately deal with the relation of the citizen to the military .
 We realize that these are general, unrevolutionary, and for the most part unintriguing comments, but we hope that they will cause some serious thought on the part of the college community and some serious re-evaluation .
 We see no reason why, given the opportunity, the ROTC program cannot evolve as a means for broadening the liberal base of a liberal education . The program provides future citizens with an insight into a military system over which they must retain ultimate control, we say .

 Commitment Panel Debates United States Civil Defense Needs . Panel discussed morality and practicality of civil defense . Panel of five Colorado College professors debated the morality of the law .
 The discussion, sponsored by Commitment, was held in the WES room of Rastall Center . It drew a considerable number of people interested in this timely dilemma of whether the current emphasis (not to mention expense) on civil defense is an aid or detriment to national security .
 Commitment presents all factors concerning the*current national crises to those who will listen . Commitment aims to present all factors in the hope that better informed, they may be able to make intelligent decisions .
 The panel presented both sides of the Civil Defense question . The panel was evenly divided, pro and con .
 Dr. Wilbur Wright, professor of physics, serving as moderator, opened the discussion by stating that the theme was to be the morality and practicality of Civil Defense . He then turned the matter to Dr. Wright .
 In a nuclear war, the effectiveness of a shelter would be extremely limited . The effectiveness of the shelter in a war would be very limited .
 The money spent negatively on shelter should instead be used positively as aid for the helpless . The money should be spent on shelter instead of sheltering the homeless .
 Civil Defense and arms stockpiling are necessary to show our enemies that we are prepared and that their attack would bring only retaliation . The U.S. should be prepared to face an attack on its enemies .
 "We must show our allies that we are prepared to defend the freedom which we extol," says President Barack Obama .
 Money spent for CD diminishes the probability of attack and so is spent positively . Th money spent on CD reduces the likelihood of attack .
 Dr. David Van Becker, professor of English and Commitment's other unofficial advisor, sided with Dr. Van Becker . Mr Van Becker is a professor at the university .
 Bomb shelters, not fallout shelters, are necessary to survive a nuclear blast, experts say . Bomb shelters are necessary for survival in a nuclear bomb blast, they say .
 Radiation will continue to be dangerous for a month or longer . The recommended two-week food supply is insufficient, as radiation will continue for a longer period . Radiation is still dangerous in the area .
 It is impossible, either humanly or economically, to launch an adequate Civil Defense program as it would take an estimated ten years and a tripled national budget to launch .
 Living in shelters will reduce man to a survival machine in a de-humanized world, says John Sutter . Sutter: "Living in shelters reduces man to be reduced to a surviving machine"
 The fact that we assume war to be inevitable greatly increases its probability greatly increases the likelihood of war . We assume war is inevitable, but we also assume it is inevitable that it will be inevitable .
 Civil Defense is a program for national defense and unless it is taken, no one will be saved . Civil Defense programs are a national defense program . Civil defense is a national security program .
 We should save as many people as possible to carry on the purpose of those who died. We should be able to carry out the purpose that those died. It's a good idea to save as much as possible, he says .
 Wright reiterated the dangers of the number's game, making the point that there are so many indeterminate factors in an offensive attack (i.e., weather, detection, aim) that it is next to impossible to make any kind of a reliable estimate of possible destruction .
 An attempt at survival, even at the expense of dehumanization, is better than total destruction of the human race . An attempt to survive, even if it's better than the destruction of human race, is a good thing for the world .
 A realistic, ""intellectual"" fear is essential to combat complacency, but must not become mass hysteria . Fear is essential, but not mass hysteria, must not be mass hysteria. Fear must be realistic, 'intellectual'
 Money for shelters should go into the founding and operation of an international Peace Council to investigate means of maintaining peaceful co-existence . Money should instead go to the founding of the Peace Council .
 Money should continue to be spent on shelter research, as advanced technology could raise the survival percentage . Money should also be spent to improve the survival chances of animals .
 All panel members seemed to have a clear conception of the distinct possibility, and even probability, of nuclear war . All panelists, as well as members of the audience who participated in the open discussion following the panel debate, seemed to be aware of the possibility of war .
 They held that there was a middle ground between annihilation and Communist domination upon which we now stand and may continue to stand indefinitely if only we follow the correct path . But at the same time they held that . They held . that there is a . middle ground .

 A Peace Race Committee was set up by Norman Cousins, editor of theSaturday Review .
 The purpose of the Peace Race Committee is to support Kennedy for the ideals he has so well expressed . The committee is to encourage strong public response to the president's proposals for the developing of United States peace-exploratory agencies .
 Peace Race Committee is to procure several million signatures on a letter congratulating President Kennedy's expressed desires for peace, disarmament under effective international control, and United Nations strengthening . The goal for the Peace Race committee is .
 The letter reflects the everincreasing concern of responsible U.S. citizens to the danger of continued arms buildup .
 The letter urges the president to strong action in his search for possible alternatives to world conflict . The letter does not represent pacifist attitudes alone, but rather urges strong action .
 Those interested in signing the letter are encouraged to see Herving Madruga . The letter is available to sign by emailing the author .

 Dr. Shearn Explores Environment, Nerves . EDDIE MACKS GARAGE 3l7l/ 2 N Tejon Dr. Dr. Tejon .
 Donald Shearn, assistant professor of psychology, is trying to determine how enviroment — such as the morning alarm clock, the sun's glare, or soft music — produces changes by recording variations in the electrical resistance of the skin .
 Professor Shearn conducts the program on a $2,000 grant from the U.S. Health, Education and Welfare Department's Public Health Service .
 The first phase of the research probably will be completed by midsummer . He said the first phase will probably be complete by mid-June .
 Electrodes are attached to the surface of the volunteer subject's skin to pick up' the electrical changes . Electrodes were attached to . the skin to monitor electrical changes in the skin .
 The electrodes lead to a meter which measures the amount of electricity passing through the skin . The electrodes are electrodes which lead to an electricity meter .
 During one experiment, the subject will listen to nervous system to activate the a noise . The subject will also listen to a noise that activates the nervous system .
 This may cause the central sweat glands, which in turn cause a marked reading on the meter . This may also cause the body temperature to rise .
 If this experiment is repeated often enough, the skin may become conditioned to change its resistance rapidly to stop an unpleasant noise . The skin may be conditioned to become conditioned by the noise .
 Shearn said he is attempting to control reactions by making certain events, such as sounds, occur as a consequence of, or as a reward for these changes in the nervous system . Shearn says he is trying to control reaction by making sounds occur as consequence of or as reward .
 Some fifty students, many of them psychology majors at CC have volunteered to serve as subjects during the experiments . The experiments will be conducted by students at CC .

 Year in and .year out it has .been the honor system that has . placed the school in its distinguished position in American education . Year in . and year out it . has . been the honor . system .
 It is the honor system that has made possible much of the characteristic life of the college community . The honor system is a model of community life at the University of Cambridge .
 It is the honor system that has helped create an environment in which serious intellectual pursuits are possible and in which excellence is respected . The honor system has helped to create a serious intellectual pursuit in the U.S.
 It is the honor system that attracts more praise and more interest, among students and educators from New England to California, than anything else can be mentioned about the College .
 Our genuinely effective honor system is the one thing that is shared by only a handful of institutions in the nation . This is so because of all we can boast here, the nation can boast of all that it can boast .
 "We do not sufficiently appreciate the true importance of the honor system," he says . And yet in recent years he has increasingly sensed that we do not fully appreciate the importance of honor system .
 We are prone to regard it with complacency, to accept it as the natural course of things, to consider it as something else here that is old and traditional . We should be careful not to regard the situation as something that is traditional, says David Cameron .
 Too many of us are either unaware or forgetful of what exists were there no honor system . Too many people are unaware of or forget what exists .
 It can create an atmosphere of mutual hostility between faculty and students, and it can demoralize everyone by establishing a mood of cynicism and futility .  A newly formed group on campus devoted to a discussion of current events met for the first time Tuesday . The group meets in the WfiS room in Rastall Center .
 The purpose of the group was to provide a forum for interested students and faculty who wished to discuss current affairs . Fred A Sondermann, Associate Professor of Political Science, explained that the purpose of this group is to provide an opportunity for current affairs.
 He suggested an informal organization that would meet every other Tuesday except durin K exams . He also proposed a time schedule of from 4:00 to 5:15 in the afternoon for the meetings .
 The group then turned to a debate over the proposed sending of two CC students to a peace conference in Washington . The group also discussed the relationship of France and Algeria .
 The discussion was first concerned about the use of ASCC funds for the trip . The discussion began with concerns about how the funds were used .
 This was discussed at length and then a more general interest in the conference itself captured the attention of the group . The group discussed the conference and the future of the conference .
 ASCC met to discuss the financial issue the following day . ASCC seemed iminent from the group's reaction to the decision .
 All interested students and faculty are urged to attend these meetings . The meetings will be open to all interested students .
 Subsequent meetings will be held on February 20, March 6, and April 10, April 24, and May 8 . The first meeting will be February 20 .
 The next meeting will be held at 4m. in the WF.S Lounge of Rastall Center . The meeting will take place at 4pm.
 The topic for discussion will be the pamphlet ""Westeren Values and Total War" The pamphlet is available for 25 cents at the Rastall desk .

 The motion was defeated by a 9-4 vote, but a $100 allocation by the Assemblies Committee and contributions by individual members of the CC will allow these two students to attend the convention as observers .

 An informal committee has been formed to study a proposed constitutional amendment . This need has been recognized by Mr Griffiths, says Griffiths .
 This amendment would give ASCC jurisdiction over requests by political and minority groups . It would allow ASCC a review and allocation power over them which it now does not have . ASCC would be able to review and allocate power over requests .
 Tlie mechanizations of this proposal have not yet been worked out, but a step has been made . The proposal is a step in the right direction, but it's not yet worked out .

 Symposium is tightly packed with panel discussions, lectures, discussion groups, luncheon discussions, and the like . The Symposium will feature three of the foremost authorities on the problems of nuclear war — Dr. Dr. Peter Bergen, Dr. David Cameron and Dr. Paul Wolfson
 All sessions will be pen, free of charge, to interested WEAPON and STRATEGY T students, faculty members, and residents of the area . Students, faculty and faculty members will be able to attend .
 The Symposium, which will deal with the problem of nuclear war and the international power struggle a s time permits, will be of immense intellectual import, according to its director, Dr. Dr. David Cameron . Dr. Cameron: "The Symposium will deal as many and varied aspects

 The three discussion leaders whose views will highlight the Symposium each have impressive backgrounds . The Symposium will be held in New York City, New York .
 Since that time he has held a number of academic positions, including a resident professorship at the National War College . He has also been a resident professor at the War College in London .
 He has served as Special Assistant to the Chief of Staff of the U.S. Air Force . He has also served as technical expert to the United States delegation to the UN Conference at San Francisco .
 He is presently a consultant and writer with the center for the Study of Democratic Institutions . He has published such studies as PERMANENT PEACE and A WORLD WITHOUT WAR under the Center's auspices .
 Morgenthau came to the U.S. in 1937 . He has an extensive background as lawyer and teacher in Europe .
 Morgenthau has taught at Brooklyn College, Kansas City, California, Harvard, Northwestern, Columbia, Yale, and Princeton . He also taught at Harvard, Columbia and Columbia .

 He has been assigned to the Quartermaster Corps . He will enter active duty on February 28, reporting to Ft. Ft. George Washington .
 Exchange Study in Holland is available for junior men .
 Applications are now being received for the student exchange program with the Netherlands College for Representation Abroad . The Foreign Student Committee lias announced that applications are being received .
 The college faculty voted overwhelmingly to replace the present system of reporting all mid-semester grades with a new system for reporting only D and F grades at the mid-term .
 Certain faculty members felt that reoprting grades four times a year puts an undue emphasis on grades as such and tends to perpetuate immaturity rather than to develop maturity .
 Dean Lloyd E Worner: "The wisdom of giving midsemester grades as we now give them has been questioned" "Several times during the past decade the wisdom of . giving mid-semesters grades has been . questioned,"" said Worner . Worner.
 Some faculty members took the view that mid-semester grades often have a harmful effect upon freshmen and their parents when they get a grade after seven weeks .
 It was also felt that the time spent recording all grades might be better spent on careful consideration of the students who appear to be in difficulty .
 The faculty voted to add a course in intermediate Russian and approved a junior year abroad . In other action, the faculty also approved the addition of a year abroad and proposed curriculum changes .
 The intermediate Russian course will be a continuation of the elementary Russian course started last fall . It will be offered in September .
 The course will review srammer and oral practice and reading in Ru; ture, civilization and science . The course is designed to help students with reading comprehension and vocabulary .
 Colorado College students now may participate in Wayne State at Munich and Freiburgh in Germany . Wayne State will conduct the program at Munich, Germany, in addition to Sweetbriar and Smith College .
 Also authorized was the addition of an anthropology course entitled The Cultural Area . Deadline for this information is March 3 .
 Specific questions should be directed to Bob Williams, who attended N.O.I.B. last year, or Ed Kuiper, the Dutch student at CC this year . Specific questions about the program should be answered by Bob Williams .
 A number of Dutch industrialists planned to establish the College . The College was established as a result of the recent war . It is the first college in the Netherlands to be established .
 Young men were trained to follow specific careers at home and abroad . They succeeded in persuading others that there was an urgent need in post-war Holland for young men .
 College opened in 1946 in an old castle, Nijenrode, about 15 miles from Amsterdam . Thanks to generous financial support of companies such as Lever Brothers and Shell, it was possible to open the College .
 Nijenrode is located along one of the oldest rivers of Holland . The castle, with its park, ponds, moats and bridges, was founded in the 13th century . It now serves as the main building in which all lectures are given .
 The stress lies to a great extent on student life . The study program includes many subjects (economics, business science, statistics, law psychology, philosophy, French, German, English, Spanish, Russian, Arabic, sociology, market research, banking, journalism .
 The Student Body, ""Nieuwe Compagnie van Verre,"" is a name commemorative of the old East India Company . The student body is a commemoration of the company . It is the name of the Student Body .
 Students fill a number of responsible positions in the Senate . As members of the Senate and of the various sub-committees, the students fill a variety of positions .
 All-Sun-Tanned teams play in various leagues . Sports also take a major role in the sport .
 B through direct exchanges with American colleges . Besides that, seven other countries are represented in the United States .
 The first throe months you will have trouble in understanding Dutch . Five hourly classes every week and especially the social contacts you make in the ""lounge"" in the castle, which is run by the students .
 All the courses are given in Dutch, but for examinations, special arrangements have been made for American students . Students write the examination either in English or compose a paper on a special subject .
 First, you get a good knowledge of Dutch, which will give you a good base for the study of another foreign language such as German .
 With your knowledge of Dutch you will have a better opportunity to learn more about the Dutch people . Learn Dutch from Dutch to help you understand the language .
 During the Christmas vacation, December 15 — February 5, there is a great opportunity to travel through Europe and see and feel the different atmosphere in every country .

 The books were given to the college in recognition of its efforts in fostering French culture in the U.S. and encouraging mutual friendship between the two nations .

 Mr Richard A Johnson, a senior career Foreign Service Officer, will be on campus on February 23, to meet with the faculty and student body to discuss current information concerning careers in the U.S. Foreign Service .
 Johnson will meet with students in the WES Lounge, Rastall Center, at 3:30 for informal discussion . Mr Johnson will be available to meet students at the end of the evening .
 Mr Johnson entered the Foreign Service as an officer in 1040 . He has served in Naples, London, La Paz, Guadalajara, Cuidad Trujillo and more recently as Counselor for Political Affairs, American Embassy, Madrid .
 The next annual Foreign Service examination will be given September S. S, 1062 .
 Candidates must be at least 21 and under 31 years of age on July 1, 1962 . Candidates for the one-day examination must be 21 and 31 years old . The one day exam will be held on July 31, 1962.
 Those 20 years of age may apply if they are college graduates or if they have completed their junior year . Those 20-year-olds may also be eligible for the program . Applicants must be 20 years old or have completed junior year of college .
 They must have been citizens of the United States for at least nine years . They must be in the U.S. for a minimum nine years.
 Candidates successful in the one day examination will subsequently be examined orally by panels which will meet at regional points throughout the United States . Candidates will then be examined by panels that will meet in regional parts of the country .
 Starting salaries range from $5,625 to $6,755 plus allowances, leave, and other benefits . Starting salaries in the U.S. range between $4,500 and $6.75 .
 The Foreign Service requires officers with training in public and business administration, executive management, economics and related subjects . Officers with major course of study include poltical science, history, language and area studies .
 The completed application form must be received by the Board of Examiners not later than midnight, July 23, 1962 . The application form is required to be submitted by the board of examiners .
 If you are between 20 and 26, between 5'2"" and 5'8"" and single, you may qualify for this challenging and rewarding career .

 Symposium on War and Peace in the 60's irings together at Colorado College . Brodie, Mil lis, Morgenthau Featured in Symposium .
 This unusual college-wide seminar involves students, faculty, and stratify experts in a lively three days of discussion, debate, and lefinitive thought on the issue of survival in the Nuclear Age .
 BerI Brodie, a former Yale Uni.ity professor and an expert, is a missile and air strategy expert . Brodie is a former . Yale University professor .
 He is member of the Rand Corporam, a non-profit organization of ientists, humanists, and other gments of the intellectual, miliry and social community . The Rand Corporationam is engaged in actively seeking both imediate and long-range soluins to
 He is well known for his pragmatic and 'realistic' attitude toward world olitics . He is expected to defend a rather Hugh policy in world affairs .
 Millis of tt be Center for the Study of DemoI ratio Institutions, is a former 01 far correspondent and military ian . He is the author of Permanent Peace and A World flt I'ithout War .
 He is expected to present a thesis of Tactical peace and constructive teal ism. He will be presented at a conference in New York .
 The potentially challenging debate will begin when h speakers 'face-off' on Tuesgy, February 27, at 11:00 o'clock J an All College Assembly in p erkins Hall .
 At this initial lee^e, students will hear three varied statements about the United States and the world situation, and possible solutions to the larger problems . Students will hear a variety of statements about U.S. and world situation .
 55 interested students will be able to eat with lecturers and faculty to discuss the initial propositions . After this initial encounter, there will be a luncheon given in Rastall Center at which interested students can eat .
 Students interested in attending this luncheon should register at the Rastall Desk . Students should register for the luncheon for students at the school .
 The same afternoon, at 4m. in Rastall, small groups of students will be able to discuss their views with the three intellectuals . The event will be held at 4.30pm on Monday .
 Morgenthau will speak on ""Political Consequences of Nuclear Power" at an 8:15 lecture in Shove Chapel . Morgenthua will speak at 8:30pm .
 Dr. Morgenthau will discuss the ideas presented, or go home enraptured or intellectually ruptured to begin to contemplate man's role in the universe .
 At 4.m. there will be further discussion in Rastall Center of the various issues up to that point . At 4m. at 4m . at 4p. at the end of the discussion .
 On the heels of this di will come further debate from Dr. Dr. Mertz, discuss various ideas with the trio of intellectuals in attend .
 NORAD Headquarters is the nerve center of North American Air Defense . Students will be offered the opportunity to tour NORAD headquarters .
 All interested students are urged to register at the Rastall Desk . The tour will commence at 10m, and all interested students should register for the tour .
 The climax of the formal Symposium will be held at 4m. in Taylor Hall where the three antagonists will make concluding statements and resound to questions .
 The conclusion of this discussion will technically end the 1962 Symposium . The discussion was technically the end of the Symposium.
 To prepare students for the Symposium, a monstrous, but easily mastered reading list has been provided and posted in various centers of campus activity . The Symposium will be held at the University of North Carolina .
 A special display of reserve books has been established in the library . The library has also been set up to display reserve books in its collection .
 The real value of this Symposium will come from the dialectical exchanges, and the violent, but logical, arguments advanced by the participants . The symposium will focus on dialectical and violent exchanges between participants .
 The range of topics discussed will not be narrowly confined to technical aspects of nuclear war . The topics will be discussed not only about technical aspects .
 Topics include American Philosophy and Morality as well as world economic and social issues . Topics will allow the thoughtful student to deepen knowledge of the world .
 It is hoped that the Symposium will never really end, and that firm and thoughtful conclusions will only be reached when the participants vote and directly participate in pol itical affairs .

 He has previously appeared at the Greek Week Dance and the Gold Diggers' Ball . He has also appeared at Greek Week dance and Gold Dancer Ball .
 The first discussion groups will begin at 2 in., Saturday, Saturday, and the weekend will end at 4 Sunday .
 All students are urged to spend the night at the camp, if at all possible . We believe that the group spirit will make for more cohesive, intense, ami rewarding discussions .
 The form of these discussions will be that of small panels whose duties will be to make short statements to channel the beginnings of the discussions, after which the meetings will be open to the audience, to arirue. or justify as they see fit .
 The idea of the conference is not to have formal speeches by faculty and students, but rather to have informal, free-wheeling discussions and exchange of ideas . The conference will be held in New York City, New Jersey .
 Are the college's reasons for our attendance (see catalog, 5) applicable to its students? Do we have responsibility only to our selves, or do we have an obligation to share our abilities? Are we have responsibilities only to ourselves, or not to others?

 Bell Telephone System is closer to wiping out the noise that sometimes interferes with telephone conversations . Steve Banks, who just two years ago was an undergraduate engineering student, was an engineering student . Banks is credited with helping to develop the system .
 Steve examined the noise levels that had ""leaked"" into telephone circuits in Colorado . Steve examined how noise levels had leaked into phone circuits .
 His findings shed new light on the source of noise, and on the important methods of measuring it . The findings shed light on how to measure noise .
 Steve Banks of Mountain Slates Telephone & Telegraph Company, and other young engineers like him in Bell Telephone Companies throughout the country, help make your communications service the finest in the world .
 "Meet the Netherlands" is sponsored by the Dutch private and governmental education agencies .
 The program lasted some five days in the beginning of November at a private hotel in the province of Utrecht .
 The schools represented were the Building and Architecture Center and the Economics College, both located in Rotterdam, the Technical School of Delft, the Agricultural School in Wageningen, and The Netherlands Institute for Representation Abroad .
 The program dealt with an introduction to Dutch history, modern architecture and art . It included an excursion to the DAF autoworks in Eindhoven in the south of the country .
 The Netherlands has experienced a great revival in painting since World War II, even greater than that in France . It's surprising for the foreigner to learn that the Dutch has had a great resurgence in painting .
 Dutch paintes are affected to a large extent by the artificial environment created by man in his effort to gain land from the sea . The lecturer at the conference pointed out that Dutch painters are affected .
 There were young men and women present from Argentina, Brazil, Ceylon, Columbia, Cyprus, Germany, Pakistan, Thailand, the USA, and the Netherlands .

 The trouble is that too many of the immigrants here just don't have a ""frontier"" spirit . The White Collar Civil Servant mentality insists upon written guarantees and assured recognition .
 On the whole East Africa is ideal if one can sympathize with the aspirations of the ""new"" African and has conditioned himself to respond to the abnormal . Anyone wanting routine and an ordered life (both mentally and physically) has no business in East Africa .

 Applications are now being accepted for membership on the Rastall Center Board . Applications taken for membership have been accepted .
 Each one of the seven available positions offers a unique opportunity for participation in student affairs . The positions include Chairman, Executive Secretary, Business Manager, Recreation and Special Events .
 The Chairman of the Rastall Board co-ordinates the Center activities as well as presiding at meetings . He is the chairman of the Board .
 Executive Secretary responsible for minutes, files, and correspondence . Executive Secretary is also in charge of display cases .
 Budget house development, and special promotions, are handled by the Business Manager .
 Cultural Affairs Chairman coordinates Rastall art displays and movies, movies, coffee hours, and music . Cultural Affairs chairman coordinates art displays, movies and coffee hours .
 Hospitality is concerned with the Visitors' Service, Rastall decorations, and necessary publications . Hospitality concerns with the visitors' Service and the Visitors Service .
 Recreation Chairman supervises Games Area, Craft Shop and Outings Club programs . Recreation chairman supervises the Games Area and Craft Shop .
 Outdoor activities such as ""Rally for the Keg"" and the annual Bicycle Race also fall under his jurisdiction . Outdoor events such as the annual bicycle race are also under his control .
 Term of office is for one year, and any student not graduating before next June is eligible . Students not graduating from next June will be eligible for the position .
 Applications remain flexible, and need not dictate the Board's eventual choice . Each applicant is asked to state a position preference, but applications remain flexible .
 Solomon Nkiwane, a Christian from Bulawayo in Southern Rhodesia, spoke at the 11m. service in Shove Chapel on the dying influence of the Church in his country .
 He noted that there was no corner of Southern Rhodesia where Christianity has not penetrated . He praised the missionaries for their efforts in achieving this .
 There is political unrest, and soldiers roam the streets and avenues of the African living quarters . There are political unrest in the country .
 The only difference between now and the pre-missionay times, is that instead of spears and clubs we use guns for fighting, and we no longer tolerate missionary interference, meditation, or comments in political disputes .
 He concluded on a note of hope, by suggesting that the church in Southern Rhodesia still has an opportunity to exert considerable influence in bringing about the right solution if it would only commit itself .
 Application forms are available at Rastall Desk, and must be turned in before March ninth . Board will individually interview the applicants, after which they will be individually interviewed .

 AFSG Peace Seminar Discusses Nuclear Age at YMCA camp in Estes Park . Colorado College students attended the seminar at the camp . Ann Armstrong and Alma Cremonesi attended the event .
 The purpose of this meeting was to bring together students interested in the peace movement from various Colorado campuses . The meeting, sponsored by the American Friends Service Committee, was to discuss peace techniques .
 In the opening session of the conference, each of the three areas was discussed by a faculty member .
 After dinner, the group reconvened to hear McClure McCombs, director of the AFSC Work and Study Program of the Chicago Regional Office, speak briefly .
 Two short films were produced by the AFSC concerning peace attitudes and possibilities concluded the Saturday session .
 Participants broke up into three groups to discuss peace education, action projects, and service projects in greater detail . Participants discussed the three areas of peace education .
 In the final afternoon session, each discussion group reported the results of its meeting . The final session of the session ended with a vote of approval .
 Participants decided to keep in contact with each other through two representatives on each campus and to use the AFSC's services when desired . The seminar ended with a decision by the participants to use AFSC services when necessary .

 The United States National delation is a confederation of CC Summer Workshop Studies Human Relations . A workshop in human relations is scheduled for the 1962 summer sesion .
 The three-week session is designed to help teachers, school administrators, industrial workers, community workers and other professional and volunteer personnel develop skill in dealing with problems .
 The study in human relations begins with learning how groups are formed and how they act upon each other .
 This knowledge leads to a concentrated study of misunderstanding between different races and religions in the community and the country as a whole .
 Students realize the bases for prejudice and discrimination between individuals and entire groups . Students learn how to deal with them more effectively .
 Some of the advantages of the NSA program are their inexpensive foreign programs because of its close relation to similar student union programs in Europe and its non-profit basis . The NSA program is based on a student union program in Europe .
 There is a considerable amount of time provided as an integral part of the program . Also there is a lot of time spent on the program as a result .

 The American College Poetry Society is pleased to announce its fifth semesterly anthology of outstanding college poetry is now being compiled for publication in May, 19(12)
 We would be very grateful if you would again alert the interested students on campus to this opportunity to have their work published .
 Contributions must be the original work of the student (who shall retain literary rights to the material), submitted to the undersigned, care of the Society, with the entrant's name, address, and school on each page . Entrant must retain literary right to retain the material .
 Poems, which may reflect any subject, should not exceed 48 linos, nor may any individual submit more than five poems . Poems should not be submitted more than 50 linos or more .
 Entries that are not accepted for publication will be returned if accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope . Entries not returned will be sent to the editor of this week's Daily Mail .
 The Society, this year, will oiler Recognition Awards of Five Dollars each, to the five outstanding college poets . This year, the Society will award five dollars each to the best college poet .
 The poems cannot be otherwise acknowledged, nor can the Society compensate students for work that is published .
 All entries must be postmarked not later than Thursday, April 12, 1962 to be considered .
 We are sincerely appreciative of your past and present cooperation, without which our younger poets could not have received the attention and acclamation that they have received through previous anthologies .

 Three outstanding Denver musicians and prominent members of the Denver Symphony will be presented in the next Perkins Hall Concert which is scheduled for March 4, at 4:00m.
 This musical event will be free to the public as continuation of the Colorado College Winter Concert Series . Under the auspices of the Music Department .
 Richard Joiner, solo clarinetist of Denver Symphony, and his wife, Kathleen, official pianist of the same orchestra, will he the featured artists . The Denver Symphony is the home of the Denver Symphony .
 In the last number of their program, a Trio by Mozart, thev will be assisted by Lee Yeingst, violist of the Denver Symphony . The Denver Symphony will perform the Trio at the end of the program .
 Mr Joiner, a graduate of Eastman, is one of the finest clarinetists in this country today .
 Before coming to Denver in 1946, he was solo clarinetist of the National Svmphony Orchestra in Washington, D.C., and of the Marine Band, also during the war .
 Of his outstanding teachers it may suffice to mention the world-famous Reginald Kell. Kell .
 Pianist and musician of distinguished accomplishments . Joiner is one of the most outstanding graduates of the music department at Colorado College .
 She received her Bachelor of Arts degree here in 1943 and the Master of Master's degree in 1945 .
 In addition to her musical talent, she was sufficiently outstanding academically to become a Phi Beta Kappa . She was a Phi B Kappa Kappa .
 Kathleen is a mother of three healty boys . She teaches at Garland County Day School and is active in several charitable organizations . She also plays the piano at the Denver Symphony .

 The Colorado College chemistry department has received a $5,0(50 grant from the National Science Foundation to conduct its undergraduate science education program . Science Foundation Grants Chemistry Department $5.060 . Colorado College's chemistry department received the grant .
 The program gets under way during the 1962 summer session and continues during the calendar year . The program will be under the direction of Dr. Dr. John Dewey .
 Milton K Snyder, assistant professor and acting chairman of the chemistry department, is a chemistry professor . Milton K. Snyder is also an assistant professor at the University of Columbia .
 The undergraduate science education program is a combination of two older programs of undergraduate research participation and independent study . The program includes undergraduate independent study and research participation .
 Currently the chemistry department is operating a program of independent study under a previous National Science Foundation grant .
 The grant will support two students on research projects at the college during the summer of 19C2 . The new grant will be used to support students on projects at 19 C2 .
 It will provide opportunity for eight students to participate in the summer reading program in chemistry during the summer while away from the campus . It will aid in supporting four students on research projects .
 A number of college juniors, who are chemistry majors, will receive support in the junior independent study course offered by the department in establishing their technical libraries .
 The program is designed to furnish support for able undergraduates capable of becoming creative scientists or engineers . The program, now in its fourth year, is designed for undergraduates .
 The stress in the program is placed upon the need of the student to grow as an independent scholar, through activities characterized by freedom for the student . Students must demonstrate their capacity for creative enterprise with minimal supervision .

 Stephen Spoonamore, '62, has won the award of $50 offered in December to a college student who submitted the best proposal to obtain better cooperation from the student body in the use of the library collections . Stephen's proposal was submitted in December .
 All of the proposals advised the installation of a check point at the main entrance of the library . Books and packages leaving the library would have to be submitted for inspection, to make sure that the books were properly checked out .
 The winner's proposal was superior to the others in its comprehensive analysis of the problem involved and the detailed list of recommendations for solving the problem . The winner of the proposal was selected from a panel of experts .
 The money for this award was contributed by two adult students at the college who wish to remain anonymous . They had become concerned at the large number of books missing from the library collections .
