 Sondermann stated that this year's subject, ""War or Peace in the 60's,"" was selected to provoke ""conscientious thinking"" on a problem affecting the shape and Russiaj but may occm , between duration of our lives .
 Brodie propositioned that no one consciously wants war, neither we nor the Russians . However, man's unpredictable nature is such that it may occur regardless, regardless .
 No one knows how much depends upon the internal motivations of individual esteem of individuals . Not only that, there is no way of finding out since it's impossible to tell .
 Red China, which does not have the means to wage a nuclear war, could possibly involve us with Russia . Another unknown factor is Red China which could involve us in nuclear war .
 2. Protection of retaliatory forces, which will lessen the inducement of a trigger-happy attack, and . Protection of retaliation forces, . which will . lessen the inducedment of an attack, 2.2.3 .
 Brodie stated that we must recognize that war is possible, and that it is not immoral to use all feasible methods to save lives . Brodie: War is possible and that all feasible means are used to save people's lives .
 Morgenthau enumerated the three current schools of thought concerning nuclear war and tried to find other elements to counter their pessimistic tendencies . Morgenthalau tried to counter the pessimistic tendencies of the current nuclear war schools .
 The current problems concerning Berlin and Germany are so insolvable that nuclear war is highly probable within this decade . Nuclear war is likely to be highly likely within the next decade, says Dr. Peter Bergen .
 The attack will not come within 10 years, but with growing technological and psychological problems, the possibility becomes acute each year . The threat of a terrorist attack is not likely to come within ten years .
 Neither the Soviets nor the Red Chinese have .short-range designs to take over the non-Communist world . At present neither . nor . the Red . Chinese have short-range . designs .
 A non-thermonuclear war is impossible between the U.S. and China and Formosa, Taiwan . The United States and China are at odds of a nuclear war .
 Conventional armies have been reduced to a police force useless in nuclear war . Conventional forces are reduced to police forces useless in such a nuclear war, experts say .
 Since war is no longer a part of diplomatic policy, the neutral one-third of the world must be won over by other means . The power balance will remain unchanged, regardless of which way the neutrals swing, the power balance .
 Morgenthau is a member of Mr Millis' first school, believing in the possibility of war within this decade . He believes the war could happen within the next decade .
 He stated that the position of force in foreign policy has changed in the course of history . He said that force has changed the way it has been used in the past few years .
 Once it was the rational means to the ends of foreign policy, the ends justifying the moans . Now it's the end justifying moans, the end justifies moans. Once it's been the end of the foreign policy .
 With the revolution of nuclear power as a means, force become irrational since the ends, not the ends of existing civilzation, would be obliterated . However, force would become irrational if nuclear power were to be used as a weapon .

 Hermann J Muller will deliver the first Harold J Roberts Memorial Lecture at Colorado College on Tuesday, March 6, at 8:15 m.m. in Shove Memorial Chapel . Muller's lecture will take place at 8 a.m., March 6 .
 Muller received the 1946 Nobel Prize in medicine for proving that radiation causes hereditary changes in living cells . Muller was awarded the Nobel Prize for his work on the subject of radiation therapy .
 Columbia awarded him an honorary degree in 1949 and the Alexander Hamilton Medal in 1961 . Columbia also awarded him a posthumous honour from the Hamilton Medal .
 Muller engaged in research and teaching under the late Thomas Hunt Morgan, famous zoologist and specialist in genetics . Muller spent most of his career in teaching under Morgan .
 Muller went to Rice Institute in Huston, Texas, as an instructor in biology, where he remained until 1918 . Muller was a biology instructor at the Rice Institute . Muller died in 1918 .
 From Germany, he went to Russia, where he served as senior geneticist at Institute of Genetics in Moscow .
 During his stay at Amherst, much of his time was spent in research in his chosen field . Much of his stay in the U.S. was spent researching in the field .

 Linda Burtschi, Marcia Irving, Judy Jaccard, Caroline Jacobsen, Kay Knudsen, and Kathy Mcintosh are featured .

 Professor Muller's solution calls for a sperm bank from which parents could select the sperm which they would like to have in their progeny . Parents could select sperm which would produce characteristics which they want in a child .
 The success of this idea pre-supposes a mass education which would awaken a sense of social responsibility to the maintenance of the human race at least at the level of genetic fitness .
 It would pre-suppose a means of genetic redistribution, and further, a program of genetic counseling . The program would also include genetic counseling and genetic redistribution .
 He admits that the incorporation of his program would take some time, but that the sooner something is done, the better . He says he hopes to incorporate his program will be incorporated into his program .

 Professor holds that at least one-fifth of today's civilized population is genetically unfit . Professor says each generation produces a population, one- fifth of which is genetically unsuitable . Professor: At least one fifth of civilized population in each generation is genetically unfit .
 Muller offered several interesting bits of positive evidence, proving that such a solution would not dissolve family ties . Muller: "Such a solution is not a solution to the problem of family relations"

 Artificial insemination has already been experimented with, and the ties of families so produced have shown evidence of being at least as strong as the ""genetic"" families .

 Your military service can pay off handsomely in later life . You will enjoy the pay, the prestige, and the traditional privileges of an officer .

 Mr Brodie closed his comments by noting that the coming of nuclear weapons has given offensive strength .
 Mr Millis first cautioned that we are in error when we assume that there is always one best policy . Speaking on disarmament, he said that we should not assume that always best policy is always best .
 He went on to point out that arms control and disarmament proposals have been contradictory and ineffective .
 Our present policy is to maintain a strong retaliatory force and conventional arms, says Mills Mills .
 If disarmament is achieved, it will be as a result of improved rational relations between the major powers, in which war has a decreasing place . War has decreasing place in the history of the world, writes Andrew Hammond .
 Two broad steps which precede disarmament are the maintenance of a balance of force while outstanding problems are resolved, and the abolition of war as an instrument of policy . The two broad steps to disarmament will be maintenance of the balance, while outstanding issues are resolved .

 Sales and Sales Management Training Program is designed to develop young men for careers in life insurance sales and sales management . The program is available for men in the United States and abroad .
 The training period provides an initial training period of 3 months before the men move into full sales work .

 The pattern we still think of as the American college is "now being frayed at the edges, if not threatened with being cut to shreds,"" President Benezet said .

 At the present time, the primary consideration of the ASCC Finance Committee in its budget hearings is the number of students to be benefited, both directly and indirectly, by an appropriation from the fund . The primary consideration in the committee's budget hearings will be students to benefit from an appropriation .
 ASCC allotment comes directly from fees paid by each individual CC student . This is considered primary since it comes from student fees paid for each individual student .
 The Finance Committee considers the request of other campus organizations, the uses for these proposed appropriations, and their utility to the student body . After this major portion of the budget is budgeted, the Finance Committee will consider the requests of other organizations .
 The only position clarified is the precedent resulting from a recent refusal of the ""Turn Toward Peace"" delegation . The delegation's position has not been clarified .
 Three persons (Bill Stafford, Susan Caudill, and Betsy Gaskill) will attempt to clarify the situation and propose some specific changes . Bill Stafford will be the first person to propose changes to the law .
 "The way in which allotments arise leads to a value judgment which is very hard to make," says David Cameron . "It's very difficult to make. It's the only way to make a value judgement," he says .
 One suggestion that deserves attention is a direct appropriation only to certain key organizations (Nugget, Kinnikinnik, Tiger, Foreign Student Committee, Enthusiasm Committee) and a program fund for all the rest which make requests .
 This fund would be under direct ASCC supervision . It would be used to support activities currently under Citizenship Club, International Relations Club, and others currently in the ASCC budget .
 This proposal would have the merit of including activities currently omitted, although value judgments would still have to be made . The proposal would also include activities that are currently omitted from the list .
 It would also alleviate the practice by organizations currently receiving funds from ASCC, of requesting too much, thereby freezing ASCC resources till the school term ends, then returning the surplus to the Reserve Fund . ASCC funds would also be returned to the reserve fund .

 The preacher will address himself to the concept of sin and evil in the life of the individual man . Mr William Powell will continue to address the concept .
 This concept of sin is one that greatly troubles and also repulses the modem man . This concept is one of sin's greatest problems and repulsiones .
 This is due to a lurid false presentation on the part of certain versions of the Christian faith and also to a misunderstanding of this concept by our censorship contemporaries . This is because of a lack of understanding of the concept by censors, he says .
 It may be true, as one thinker put it, that modern man is no longer troubled by his sins . Modern man may no longer be troubled by sins, but he is troubled by the sins of the past .
 The statistics on mental health and also from reading much modem literature, it would seem seem seem that man is troubled by something . However, judging by the statistics on . mental health, it seems that man seems troubled by . something .
 This vague sense of guilt pervades much of our social life and underlies much of man's attitude towards the world . The Christian attitude towards sin would seem to be much less healthy than that of the Christian attitude to sin .
 The theme of this sermon deals with this morbid quality which seems to possess many people and much literature . It looks at it in the light of the Christian revelation of the love of God toward man as a sinful being .

 At the Fine Arts Center last weekend, eighty-three ""guys and dolls"" provided a refreshing break from increasing academic pressure . Ownoi By James H Fox .
 The musical end of the production was a solid, first rate job . Under the creative direction of Donald Jenkins, Donald Jenkins was the musical end .
 Some of the comic writing clicked, and some was of the ""something funny happened to me on the way to the studio"" type . Some of this comic writing is of the type of comic writing that clicks .
 Frank Loesser's score varies from the sentimental More 1 Can Not Wish You to the spirited, slightly nostalgic title song . The score is never dull, dusty, or unpleasant listening .
 An example of Loesser's imagination is his Fuge for Tinhorns performed competently by a trio of ""guys" The evening's most delightful performance was enjoyed in Lynn Bradley's ""well-known fyancee,"" Adelaide .
 She was at once vulgar and naive, dumb and shrewd, selfpitying and noble in her devotion for good, old, unreliable, fourteen year-old Nathan . Nathan .

 Sky Masterson, the fly-by-night gambler and professional ""doll catcher"" was sung with precision ' and maturity by Ben Lyons . Ben Lyons was born in New York City .
 The leading man's roundness of tone and resonant projection complemented the sharp, sincere expression of Genevieve Vaughn as ""Sister Sahruh"" in their two balladlike duets I'll Know and I've Never Been in Love Before .
 Dale Spall, as Sarah's grandfather, lacked the voice of Mr Lyon's . The More I Can Not Wish You was tenderly expressed and he seemed an appealing old soul saver .
 Norman Cornick's sensual and disciplined choreography was a wild spectacle . The ballet was directed by Cornick and directed by the choreographer .
 His Cubans performed with Latin lust, his Hotbox girls were vivacious, and his crapshooters moved like acrobats . "His Cubans perform with Latin Lust," he said .

 Coblirn Library has received various directories and announcements of summer jobs for 19U2 across the nation and around the world . Coblorn Library received various . directories and . announcements of . summer jobs . for 19.U2 .
 Although most of the group had never participated in a work camp, it proved to be a most interesting and profitable experience for everyone involved . The camp was the first of its kind to take place in the summer .
 The group spent three days working on a reservation Chapter House and school, put new Course Offered At CC Summer Session ting in a lawn and laying flagstone walks with Navajo children .
 One day was spent at the Gallup Indian Community Center, where the group was staying, painting, washing, gardening, and generally cleaning up the whole place .
 The work accomplished was certainly not of earth shaking significance, but the experience with the Navajos and their children was most rewarding .
 The nights were spent in talking with Navajo leaders and learning about some of the many problems that the Indians face in trying to acculturate with the non-Indian societies . Navajo leaders also learned something of their native crafts and culture .
 The group visited Window Rock to see what the U.S. government is doing for the Indians . During the other days the group visited Canyon de Chetley and Window Rock . The group also took a side trip to Canyon deChetley .
 One special adventure was watching the spring fertility dances of the Zuni Indians . The Zuni dancers were part of the annual Zuni Festival .
 Of course, all of the experiences cannot be related here, but there was a general impression of having begun to understand the Navajos and their often misunderstood culture .
 This spring vacation, another work camp for ten students has been arranged through the efforts of John Stickney and Dr. Dr. Martin Stickney . The camp will be held for 10 students .
 Paul Kutsche, professor of Anthropology and Sociology at Colorado College, with the Navajo Indians . Kutsche is a professor of anthropology and sociology .
 The Navajo community of Sawmill is not far north of Gallup on the Navajo Indian Reservation . This year's ceremony will be held in Sawmill, which is located in the Navajo community .
 The proposed projects include improving a rodeo ground, landscaping a reservation Chapter House, and planning and helping prepare a meal for Navajo dignitaries and guests .
 The itinerary will be similar to that of last year, with opportunities to talk with government and Navajo leaders and to visit points of interest in the neighboring region while not participating on the actual work projects .
 Paul Kutsche and his wife have offered to chaperone, and will be of considerable help because of their knowledge and experience with other Indian tribes . Paul K Deutsche and his . wife have also offered to help because they have .
 The students will be asked to pay for part of their travel and board expenses . Students will also have to pay part of the travel costs .

 Mr Stewart is the son of the late Philip B Stewart, who was a member of the college's board of trustees from 1900 to 1954 . He is also a former trustee at the college .
 Philip B Stewart contributed to the development of Washburn Field and coached basketball at the college . Stewart was one of Colorado Springs' leading citizens .
 His library, containing many rare editions, was given to the college after his death . His library contains rare editions .

 CC Mountain Club will attempt a first winter ascent of the Elfingwood Ridge of La Plata Peak . Club to Attempt Climb of LaPlata Peak. Club to attempt first winter climb .
 It is the fourth highest mountain in our state and the sixth highest in the Continental United States, excluding Alaska . The mountain is the tallest mountain in the United States .
 Most of the climbing routes on La Plata are not difficult, but one route, the Ellington Ridge, offers interesting climbing throughout the year . Most of these climbing routes are not very difficult .
 When encrusted with snow, the climbing difficulties are increased . Winter also brings low temperatures, high winds and the ever present avalanche danger .
 There have been frequent attempts to make a winter ascent of La Plata via this ridge . All of them have met with failure because of storms, avalanches, equipment failures and logistical problems .
 Dale Spall, John Kuglin and Ron Bierstedt will try a late-season attempt this weekend . CCMC faculty advisor Ron Biersstedt says it will be the last one of the winter's winter .
 They plan to leave Colorado Springs very early Friday morning . By the time you are reading this article, they should be ascending the first section of the ridge .
 The early start is prompted by the avalance danger which is always present during the first section of the climb . The avalanche danger always present in the first part of the mountain climb .
 Once past the avalance basin, they will proceed to the low point on the ridge where they will erect camp . The group will then move to a low point in order to erect camp at the summit .
 They will attempt the final section of the climb which involves extensive rock climbing . After fidgiting under and inch or so of goose down during the night, they will leave the support party headed by Dan Bemstien and attempt to climb .
 They hope to start back from the summit Saturday afternoon, and may return to the Springs in time for Monday classes . They hope they will start back Saturday afternoon .

 Under the traditional academic calendar students go home for Christmas vacation and return to the campus for what has been termed a two-week ""lame duck"" session before semester final examinations . Students return to campus for two weeks before final exams .
 This is followed by another week of vacation before the opening of the second semester . The second semester will be followed by a week of holiday .

 As a recent alumnus of Colorado College, I cannot leave unchallenged the undocumented aspersions cast at the College by student contributors in the TIGER Letters Section .

 Research grants have been awarded to twelve Colorado College professors in the past two weeks . CC Professors Receive Grants .
 These were announced by Professor Carl Roberts, chairman of the psychology department and the Faculty Research Committee . Professor Roberts announced the findings at the University of Cambridge .
 Professor Paul Bernard plans to go to Vienna to undertake a preliminary study of the reign of the Austrian Emperor Joseph I . He expects this to be the first step in a major long-range research project .
 Research on the nature of the ndreno Middle English poem will take Professor Ross to London, Oxford and Edinburgh .
 Entitled ""On the Evil Times of Edward II,"" the poem exists in three manuscripts in the British Museum, the Bod* leian Library, and the National Library of Scotland .
 Professor Snyder will undertake a study of programmed instruction for college general chemistry . The study will be conducted by Professor Snyder .
 He is also studying the complex compounds formed between ions and tluoglycerol, a new compound which appears to bond strongly to metal ions .
 He is being assisted in the project, which got under way last September, by Max Taylor, a junior .
 Professor Kutsche plans to spend the summer checking over a bibliography of sources on the Eastern Cherokee . The bibliography was amassed by himself and several colleagues .
 Professor Beidleman has been taking motion pictures in the held to analyze the social behavior of birds . For more than a year, he has taken motion pictures to analyze birds' behavior .
 He hopes to colorband members of several species association groups to enable him -to analyze the position of each individual bird in the group and to see if the groups remain together .
 English Professor Van Becker is planning to visit the Huntington Library at San Marino, California, to consult the Larpent Collection of Manuscripts of 18th Century Drama . Van Becker plans to consult a collection of manuscripts from the Huntington library .
 Professor Ornies is studying and mapping the locations of railroad grades in Colorado, eastern Utah and part of New Mexico . Ornies' book on other aspects of the railroad history of Colorado is scheduled for publication in June .

 Burton Sunday, April 15, is the Last Sunday of the Lenten season before the festival of Easter . Palm Sunday is known in the Christian year as Palm Sunday .
 This Sunday commemorates the entry of Jesus with his disciples into Jerusalem for the week of his betrayal and death, culminating in the joy of the resurrection . This Sunday particularly commemorates Jesus' entry of Jerusalem .
 This sermon wishes to tell simply the story of Jesus coming into Jerusalem for the last time during his earthly life . This sermon attempts to look at the significance of this event .
 The sermon will look at the meaning of the original prophecy, Jesus' intention in using it, and its significance for us who worship and inquire about him in the twentieth century .

 Miss Ellen Claydon of the Colorado College Spanish Department came up with some interestingthoughts on theories of literary criticism and literature of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries .
 This approach has been applied chiefly to the Renaissance and que periods in literary hisperiods which formerly were not clearly distinguished . The Renaissance and Queque periods are thought to be the most important periods in literature .
 In Spain, the span of time from 1516 to 1680 was simply called The Golden Age . The span of the time between 1516 and 1680 is known as 'The Golden Age' In Spain it was known as the Golden Age.
 We now see two very different cultural atmospheres iluring the 10th and 17th centuries . We see a very different culture between the two centuries .
 We have now realized that a high degree of ornamentation, lack of clarity, intense contrast and desequilibriconstituted an artistic theory which reflected the taste and feelings of the times . We have . now ■ to realize that . an ornamentation . lack of . clarity
 We in the 20th century are much more capable uf accepting the desirability of this aesthetic as we we have de■eloped tastes similar to those of the 17th century . We are more capable of accepting this aesthetic than those of 17th .
 The classic aesthetic is considered the onl y aesthetic of the Greco-Roman cultures . Critics have been arguing it for centuries — as far back as the Middle Ages and certainly in the k and Roman cultures .
 Let us examine briefly and :ontrast of these two aesthetics on i very schematic level . The two aesthetics are very different and very schematic on a schematic level.
 It proposes that man is perfect, or at least apable of reachingperfection . It proposes man is apable to reach perfection, or to be perfect .
 Even man's body is potentially a perfect, beautiful structure . He s, after all, created after the image of God; he has a divine soul i approximates God's divinity .
 This attitude of acceptance and even ennoblement of man produces a serenity and an optimism . We have only to look at a Renaissance painting to see this dearly. This attitude .
 There is a sense of balance, equilibrium, and serenity in ■ h a painting . The painting was created in the 1930s and 1940s in New York .
 The human figure is nearly perfect and so is the world in which he is pictured . The human figures are nearly perfect, and so are the world around him .
 The artistic technique itself is conceived in the light of perfection, as formulas and theories are developed and written down which pretend to have worked out the perfect art form .
 Weste m man rebels against a rational concept of himself and a restricof his creativity into rigid forms . The Weste man rebeles against a . rational concept .
 In the BatQ quo period, the principal conflict, due to the great religious druggies of the day, became sensuality versus spirituality . The principal conflict was sensuality vs. spirituality .
 It was accepted fact that the only real id important thing in the life of man was the salvation of his ■soul . Yet irrationaly, man could not avoid being sensual being and thus enjoying the world .
 There was intense concern with moral conduct, for while there was an accepted standard, one had only to look around to see that no one adhered to it . There was an intense concern for moral conduct .
 The world was falling apart, for this was the period of the Thirty Years War in Germany in which nearly every European nation was participating and ill .
 Kings and courtiers lived in extreme luxury and selfindulgence while the populace was dying of starvation . Kings and their courtiers . lived in . extreme luxury while the . populace died of starvation while the population was dying .
 Man struggled to avoid viewing himself as an animal or a base being in spite of the reality which would convince him otherwise . He struggled to see himself as a human or a human being .
 Sometimes he succeeded, other times he sank into a bitter cynicism which at least afforded him some defense against despair . Sometimes he failed to succeed, sometimes he did, sometimes his cynicism allowed him to be cynical .
 They manifest themselves in great contrasts among characters — the noble lord and the materialistic, sensula servant — in contrasts of ideals within the character . Love versus loyalty and loyalty are contrasts between tragedy and comedy within the same work .
 'Multiple plots' appear in the form of a multiple plot which produces confusion in the reader or the audience . The same confusion which life produced on those who live in the 17th century .
 The artist may even take refuge from a depressing reality in an attitude of 'art for art's sake' where the content of his art is of no significance, but the art feeds on itself .
 Colorado College will broaden its Russian program in September by adding a course in intermediate Russian language . CC's Russian history course will be extended to two semesters .
 The two courses are not combined into an area study program . The history course will be offered by the history department, the language by the department of German and Russian .
 Alexy N Malyshev, formerly a United States State Department and United Nations interpreter, was formerly an interpreter for the U.S. State Department . He is now a Russian interpreter .
 As the first full time instructor of Russian, Malyshev joined the faculty last fall . He took the first step toward launching its first regular cirriculum in Russian literature and language .
 The college plans to offer a major in Russian within the next few years . Thomas Brandt, chairman of the German and Russian department, says that the college is looking at offering a major .
 The first semester of the history course will trace the development of Russia from its beginnings to World War I . The second semester will deal with prerevolutionary life, the revolution and the establishment of the Soviet regime .

 In this context he examined various proposals for dealing with Russia in the nuclear age . He also examined proposals for how to deal with Russia .

 Application period for three 19H2-G3 European study programs will open April 2 . Institute of European Studies will offer three programs offered by Colorado College .
 The programs, located in Vienna, Austria, Paris, France, an r d Freiburg, West Germany, are limited to undergraduates . The programs are located in Austria, France and West Germany .
 Classes taught in German and English for those without facility in that language . Classes are taught in English and German .
 Three study trips, covering England, France, Belgium, Luxembourg, Switzerland, Austria, Germany, Italy, and Spain, are included .
 The program in Paris is limited to sophomores and juniors with some ability in French . The program is an ""honors program"" limited to students with some French ability .
 Two study trips take students throughout the Low Countries, France and Italy . Intensive language sessions are conducted in Paris before classes open .
 German fluency is required for ""das Deutsche Jahr,"" the Institute's program in Freilburg, Germany .
 Students visit various cities and historical landmarks in West Germany, on an introductory ""field-study" trip . Students visit historical landmarks on the trip .
 The events are timed to occur during the normal vacation periods of European universities . They are timed for when they occur during university holidays .
 While in Europe, students live in private homes and dine either in Institute dining rooms or in student restaurants . Students dine in Institute's private dining rooms .
 Costs include round-trip ocean transportation, tuition, room, board and study trips . Costs range from about .$$2,000 to about $2,5500 .
 The Institute selects applicants for enrollment on the basis of their academic achievement, intellectual and emotional maturity, and recommendations by faculty members of the American college or university . Applicants are selected for enrollment based on academic achievement and intellectual maturity, according to the Institute .
 The Institute is a non-profit educational organization which had been conducting overseas study programs since 15*50 . The Institute has conducted overseas studies programs since the beginning of the century .

 Friday was spent in orientation sessions acquainting us with Navajo ■ustoms and tribal organizations . The Navajo people were introduced to the Navajo people .
 The Navajo Arts and Crafts Guild, Cross Canyon ruins, Canyon de Chelly and White House ruins . The weekend was spent in trips to surrounding places of interest, such as Hubbell's Trading Post and Natural Bridge .
 The major work project of the following week was going to individual homes and installing water storage units . Water storage units were installed in individual homes .
 This consisted of building a stand for the water tank and sink and digging a ditch and large pit for the drainage pipe and barrel . It was built for the sink and sink, and a large pit was dug for drainage .
 The trip was made especially interesting by coinciding with certain events and people . The trip is a very interesting time for the family .
 We were lucky enough to witness a Fire Dance and an all-night ceremonial held in order to cure a sick person . The ceremonial was held in a bid to cure sick people .
 We were invited to a chapter meeting, a community meeting which is open to every member of the community . We were also invited to the chapter meeting .
 This particular meeting proved to be very exciting because of heated debate between the sawmille laborers and its Anglo manager . The meeting was attended by a group of laborers and the manager .
 The girls spent the afternoon in an Indian woman's home learning how to grind corn and how to took traditional Navajo foods such as mush, mutton stew and fry bread .
 All of the people that came into contact with the group were very interested in who we were and what we had come for . The group's mission was to raise awareness of the project and raise money for a charity .
 A Navajo Ranger, Sam Begay, was also indispensable for sacrificing his precious time in order to show us around . Begay was indispensable for showing us around the world .
 Half of the value of the work camp was the satisfaction derived from working as a group together, the campers said . The campers were able to dig, cook, or change a flat tire .
 Anne and Barbara were the unofficial head cooks . Everyone took his part in cooking and cleaning UP . Even Dr. Dr. Barbara was involved in cleaning .
 The meals were all very good — well planned and well prepared, even if put together in the back seat of a car . The meals all were well planned, well prepared .
 We would never have been able to make lunches if it hadn't been for that five pound jar of peanut butter . The peanut butter was the key to making lunches for many of us .
 Group endeavor was always accompanied by singing; and due to foreign student representation, one would be as likely to hear an African chant or an East Tndian song as anything else .
 We realized what a different culture the Navajo have and therefore can more easily see the difficulties that will have to be overcome in order for them to gain a place for themselves in American life . The Navajo have a very different culture .
 The Navajo are not an isolated and stagnant group of sudbued people, but are growing and developing constantly . One of the most important things that we brought back with us is the knowledge that the Navajo people are not isolated and .
 "It's not as easy to determine what we took with us and left at the reservation. It's not easy to figure out what we left with us," says CNN.com's Rob Greene .
 This is due largely to the present trend towards education and consequent respect on the reservation for college students . This is largely due to the fact that the reservation is being given to college students in the state .
 It is hoped that we left with the Indians a recognition of the fact that many young people in America are interested in them and in their welfare . We have contributed in some way, small as it may be, to establishing better relations between their culture and ours.

 The tlii fol session to the 19(12 Symposium on ""War and Peace in the GO's"" was held on March 22nd in the WES Lounge . The final session was held at the end of the Symposium .
 The value of the Symposium was considered in light of what good it did for students beyond an attainment of personal knowledge on the problems and implications of the arms race .
 The discussion was led by a four member panel comprised of Rusty Bastedo, John Levis, Stephanie Row and Stephanie Row . Harris Sherman, moderator, led the discussion .
 The concensus of the meeting seemed to be that students at Colorado College should make an effort to express their serious concern over crucial world problems .
 There was not a unanimous opinion of how this goal was to be achieved . But there were not unanimous opinions of how to achieve it .
 Those in attendance felt one should familiarize himself with the problem and then be prepared to support one view or another .
 There seemed to be a call for more student participation in events such as debates, lectures and demonstrations . Colorado College lags far behind such schools as Antioch, Carleton, Grinnel, Harvard, Yale, and many others .
 Some students pointed to campus issues that need to be accentuated, such as the validity of the KOTC program . Others pointed to the differences of opinion between the Young Democrats and Young Republicans .
 In conclusion, most students felt there was a great need to initiate student group which would solely tackle tlie problem of stirring up interest at the College not only on questions concerning nuclear war .
 Rocky Mountain area college and university students will have a chance to work side by side with the political pros in the coming Colorado election campaign . Area College Students are given opportunity to work in the election .
 The Rocky Mountain Center for Education in Politics is offering six internships worth $500 each . Three internships are offered for each major political party, three each party .
 Students will spend 10 weeks working in state party headquarters or on the campaign trail with candidates . They are for students to work in 10 weeks at state party HQs .
 Two $4,000 fellowships are offered to law students, young instructors, nnd political science graduate students for an eight-month period beginning June 14 . The fellowships will be available for eight months .
 The Center, formerly known as the Rocky Mountain Citizenship Clearing House, is supported by the Ford and Faulk Foundations . The Center is also known as The Rocky Mountain Center for Citizenship .
 Citizenship Clearing House was organized nationally in 1947 and in this region in 1954 . It was organized nationwide in 1947, and in 1954 in the U.S. It was later organized in the United States and Canada .
 Formed strictly on a bi-partisan basis, its goals are to improve understanding of the American political process, encourage participation in political affairs .

 Colorado College nailed down 43% points for the meet, three points above the second-place contender, Colorado State College, with 40% points . The meet was held at Colorado College College in Colorado .
 Adams State College with a final count of 29 and Colorado School of Mines with a 27-point tally . Adams State State College also ran with 29 points . Colorado school of Mines had 27 points .

 Jim Blair of the Tigers sailed 13 feet, one-half inch to take first place in the pole vault . Blair broke the previous fieldhouse record of 12 feet, 8 and one-and-one-half inches set by himself and Jack Schwella of Colorado College .
 Track Coach Frank Flood's crack athlete, Abiodun Afonja, nailed down the first place in the broad jump with a 20 foot, 10 and one half inch leap . Track Coach Flood’s crack athlete took the gold medal .
 Bruce Boyd placed first in the shot put, slinging the iron 45 feet, SVj inches to break the old Colorado College record . Boyd broke the old record of 45 feet and S. inches .
 The eight-lap relay team of Bob Broyles, Dave Krell, Norm Liden and Dale Me Neal made the run in 3 minutes, 45. seconds . Another first place for the Tigers went to the eight lap relay team .

 CC Tour Choir presented a concert of ""Sacred Music for the Easter Season,"" which truly showed depth and insight; into the material being performed . I realize the Easter Program CC Choir Shows Depth and Insight .
 Emphasis was placed where it ought to be — on the thoughtful interpretation of the music rather than on having a polished professional-like performance .
 I'm by no means suggesting that there was anything sloppy about the presentation . Yet I am by no . means that there were any sloppy moments in the presentation. Yet I'm not saying that there is anything sloppy .
 It is a precise alert choir, able to produce a good choral sound which is always fitting to the stylo of tlie music being sung .
 Slow tempo of Thomas Morley's ""Agnus Dei,"" did not drag due to the rich choral sound and the effective use of dynamics . For example, the slow tempo of the slow . tempo of "Agnas Dei" was not dragged .
 Mr Jenkins managed to manipulate these dynamics and sounds to fit in with every element of the piece as they came, resulting in a beautiful performance which was over quickly .
 "Babylon,"" by Darius Milhaud, whose difficult and almost encophonus harmonies were ably handeled by Mr Jenkins and the choir . Another high spot was ""Babylyla,"" which was a difficult piece by the composer . The choir was
 The words, telling of the fall of the majestic city of Babylon, are well suited to the musical style . The choir showed that it was well aware of this relationship in its majestice and convicted approach .
 This pice showed the depth and sensitivity of Mr Jenkins' approach and the responsiveness of the choir to understand their conductor . It was the first time the choir had ever heard a performance of such a performance .
 The only unfortunate part of the concert was that the largest and most ambitous effort of the choir had to be sung from the choir loft for technical reasons, and some of the magnificense of the work was lost .
 The choir did not demonstrate the strong conviction of the choir as did the rest of the program, probably due to the difficulty of projecting focused and delicate choral sound from the loft .
 There is no more satisfying artistic experience than hearing a group of musicians dedicated to expressing the meaningful essence of the music being performed rather than appearing polished .
 CC Tour Choir projected sensitively a very meaningful program . The latter often leads to brash impersonal results, while the latter often results impersonal .

 CU French Department Presents Rhinoceros by Jay Hemingway . Inesco's RHINOCEROS is a difficult play to perform .
 C.U.'s attempt at the production is maddening to an infant making an effort to articulate . For that reason I am sympathetic with C.A.U.’s attempt to stage the production .
 C.C.U.'s Berenger fostered an inflexible pathetic' drone, author says . "Even in the final act when relief from his overbearing timidity is planned, he remained encrusted in effeminacy"
 Perhaps he confused timidity with naivety, perhaps the factor above all others that could have distinguished him from those who succumbed, and redeemed him from their fate . "Authenticite" may have been the key to distinguishing him from the others .
 Despite all of Berenger's pathetic qualities and the absurdity of the setting, one does, as does Ionesco, sympathize with his agony, his awareness of bis incompatibility with the environment, and with the incontrolability of the evolutionary trend .
 Mr Neely barely suggested the tragic authenticity; let Berenger ride as monotonous and ridiculous pathos . The film is set in New York City, New York .
 Jean Jean, Daisy, Le Vieux, Le Logician, and M Papillon should likewise be complimented . Le Logicians, Le Vignon, and Le Vieaux are also complimented for their work .
 Le Logicien dominated the scene through little if any fault of his own, since the part asks to be overplayed . The role was overplayed, but it was not his fault .
 Instead of balancing his majestic hamuiiness with rapid conversation, Jean and Berenger seemed to be hesitantly awaiting their cues, as if unsure what was to come .
 Richard M Pearl of the Colorado College geology department has had his latest book published . Pearl is a geologist at Colorado College .
 The distinctive fea'ture of this book is that, in addition to telling about various rocks and minerals, it is the only book that describes three incidents of children making important discoveries in this field .
 Thirteen of these books fall under the heading of tradebooks written for the general public . Thirteen tradebooks are written in the form of trade books for the public .
 He did his graduate work at Harvard and has been teaching at Harvard for 16 years . He did not graduate at Harvard but has taught at Harvard since 2000 .
 Current Events Disi group will deal with the topic of President Kennedy's program for medical care for the aged at its next meeting Tuesday, April 24th at 4m. in Rastall Center .
 This issue, which is now before Congress, envisages a program to help defray medical expenses, which will be handled through the present Social Security program, by raising the Social Security rates somewhat . This issue is now .
 The American Medical Association is vigorously opposed to it . It is a very controversial program, the AMA says . The program is a controversial program .
 It is hoped that at next Tuesday's discussion, both the pro and con points of view will be represented . All interested students and faculty members are cordially invited to attend .

 Colorado Springs Symphony I mJ # I * * Conduct Committee Nominates Candidates . Conduct Committee is conducting a symphony orchestra in Colorado Springs .
 Were it not for his high pitched scratchy voice Le Vieux Monsieur would have been more successful . The French singer's voice was more successful in France than the UK .
 Besides Berenger's ineptness, this unnaturalness inhibited and slowed down the play . Berengers' ineptness inhibited the play, but also slowed down play .
 RHINOCEROS is spottily successful; that in itself being erroneous . Though avoided by the laudable efforts of M Papillon, Daisy, and Duard C.U.'S. U.C.U.’s RHINocEROS .
 The setting for Act I was refreshing in a quaint, unpressed Chagalian way . The quilted setting for the play was refreshingly unpressressed .
 The sets for Acts II and III were, if anything, simple and functional . Though as with a sigh of accomplishment the set designer's efforts ended there .
 The costumes were neither spectacular nor inoffensive, and properly so . The costumes are neither spectacular or inoffensive .
 The Logicien may have appeared more absurd had his dress conformed with that of Le Vieux Monsieur . The only exception was the Logicien .
 Le Vieux Monsieur and Jean was either crude or too damn casual . The make-up on the other hand, of the pair was either too casual or crude .
 Jean's metamorphosis while it could have been visually hysterical, it seemed unnecessarily reserved and awkwardly allusive . Jean's transformation was awkward, awkward and awkward .
 Poor timing between the two pianos hampered the somewhat romanticized second movement, and it was not until Babin rallied with some exceptionally clean-cut counterpoint in the third movement fugue .
 The strings performed their simple tasks adequately throughout the concerto . The strings did not disappoint .
 The first of the four movements spent most of its time passing out solos all around the orchestra to a simple string accompaniment . The first movement of the symphony was played by the orchestra in four movements .
 The whole effect was somewhat disjointed and monotonous due to the many repetitions of the melodic material . The sound of the album was somewhat monotonial .
 The second movement held together a little better because of the persistent beat in the background . It ran into troubles with the orchestra stumbling over itself in the attempt to hang onto the tortuous rhythm .
 The short nocturnal third movement attempted to relv on orchestral color for its appeal . It would have become tedious if it had been any longer .
 The fourth movement began with some busy-sounding but fairly obvious counterpoint . The piece was composed of four pieces .
 An attempt toward the end to blend in some material from the third movement was rough and flared rather badly . An attempt to blend into the music was rough, flared badly .
 The writing for the two pianos was somewhat more interesting than most of the rest . Throughout the concerto the writing was more interesting .
 Airline played a Brazilian Dance by Milhaud and an Italian Polka by Rachmaninoff . The video was sent to the Denver airport in Colorado .
 The former is a stupid little piece with Latin rhythms and a melody, of sorts, in octaves . The former was a bit of a staid little piece .
 The Rachmaninoff sounded like bad ragtime, with an oom-pah bass and melody in thirds . It was like bad Ragtime with a bass bass and a melody of thirds .
 The orchestra alone then played New Dance by Wallingford Riegger and Vienna Life by Johann Strauss . The orchestra then played the two pieces by Strauss .
 The usual sore of concert humdrum was well performed except for some ragged entrances in the strings . It was well-performed but some of the strings were ragged .
 This performance was remarkably good on the whole, but suffered from occasional slippiness in the woodwind ensemble, unevenness in some of the string dynamics, and too fast a tempo .

 April 20, 1962 College Young Republican Convention Held at CSU . CSU's small delegation to the convention .
 The delegates were jlax Power, who has acted as chairman of the League for the past year, Bill Hunter, Kay Anderson; and Marta Phipps, candidate [or secretary] Marta .
 After a short intermission, the delegations headed for a dinin one of CSU's tremendous banquet halls . The delegations went to a banquet hall .
 We were very privileged to have as speaker Mr Peter Dominick, Republican hopeful for United States Senate . Dominick is a former Republican candidate for the Senate .
 After brief discussions with candidates for State and National offices, the delegations returned to the motel, where they began holding caucuses .
 It was a late night, and most of us didn't get to bed until 4:00 or later . The caucuses seemed very successful, so none of us really minded the late hour . Most of us got to bed .
 Feeling little worse for the wear, began the following morning with coffee, centrated campaigning, and re coffee .

 Colorado College's 1962 Tournament of Cycles will be held April 28 at the Garden of the Gods . The event will have several new features that should make it even greater spectacle than last year's .
 Tournament of Cycles to include all bicycles with three-speeds or less . First race for junkies, second race for bikes with three speeds or less, while final event for all bicycles is open to all .
 The first two events will be one-lap races over the two and one-half mile course . The third will be a three-lap, seven and a half mile race . The first race will be three-laps over a two-and-one-half-mile course
 Beginning this year, the first two races will begin with special LeMans starts . The cyclists will dash across the width of the road to their bicycles and begin the race .
 Campus organization or group of people may enter one or more three-man teams . Overall team prize will be added to the individual winner's trophies .
 The winning team will be the team with the lowest number of points, and the points are the sum of the numerical position in which each team member finishes . The points will be summed up by the team's numerical position each player finishes .
 Before each race, team members must identify themselves as such to the race registrars .
 Each competitor should pay the 50 cent entry fee to the race registrar when the bicycle are lined up before an event . The fee should be paid by the registrar at the start of the event .
 The first race begins at 1:30 m. A truck to carry competitors' bicycles to and from the Garden of the Gods will leave in front of Rastall at 12:30 a.m.
 Some transportation will be furnished for spectators and competitors to and from the event . Also, some transportation is provided .
 The course will be described at the meeting for all competitors scheduled for 7:30 m„ April 24, in the WES room .
 Those who plan to participate in the tournament are advised to register at the Rastall Center desk as soon as possible . Competitors in the first two races will be lined in the order of their registration .

 Shove Chapel Parents' Weekend Su day, April 29 'Mary — the Blessed Serm> Blessed Mother' Shove chapel parents' weekend .
 There will be a Parents' Weekend Service in Shove Chapel this coming Sunday morning .
 The triumphant events of Easter are past, and the church has celebrated the victory over sin and death wrought by Jesus Christ . This Easter is a time to celebrate the victory of sin over sin .
 In the figure of Mary, the mother of Jesus, we see an example of one who humbly lived by the Word of God spoken to her through her own Son . We see a example of a humbly humbled woman who lived by her own Word .
 On this Parents' Weekend, and with Mothers' Day fast approaching, it was thought appropriate to speak about the mother of Christ .
 It appears to the preacher that certain serctions of the church have over-emphasized the importance of Mary, and that other sections of church have not given her enough attention and importance .
 She is an example to us of one who put first things first and of one . One who acted as an agent of the will of God in the world, she said .
 He was appointed for a one-year term at the 13th annual meeting of the conference held in Chicago .
 He was a teacher and public school administrator in Illinois and San Francisco . He joined the faculty at Colorado College as an assistant professor in 1951 .

 Twenty Colorado College students conduct a survey of the political history and attitude toward politics of elected county officials, state representatives, and county party chairmen in eight Colorado counties .
 CC students are interviewing officials in El Paso, Lincoln, Otero, Huerfano, Custer, Crowley, Teller, and Pueblo counties . The students are working under the direction of political science professor Glenn E Brooks .
 Colorado College is one of five colleges and universities in the state conducting the state-wide survey . The Rocky Mountain Center for Education in Politics is conducting the survey .
 The survey is designed to provide political scientists with raw material for possible research, and to give the students experience in the field of practiced politics . The survey was designed to give political scientists the raw material to possible research .
 Colorado College students participating in the semester-long project are members of Professor Brooks' course in State and Local Goverment .
 Results of the survey will be reported by Professor Brooks at the May 5 meeting of the Rocky Mountain Social Science Association at Ft. Ft. Mesa .
 Students are asking questions concerning education, income, how interest in politics was developed, offices held, extent of political party activity, and future in politics . The students are asking for answers concerning education and income .
 The Colorado College students are working together in four and five-man teams . The students are at Colorado College in Colorado .
 Students in Custer and Crowley Counties are Jane Dawson, Gerald Dorsey, DeCourcey Graham, William B Greeley, II, and Traer Sulley . Students in Crowley and Custer Counties will be students in the fall .
 In Otero and Huerfano Counties are Mary C Bardone, Nan B Burroughs, Sylvia J Buffam, and Mary E Jones . Nan Burrough, Sylvia Buffam and Mary J Jones are also in the county .
 Five students carrying out the study in Teller and Pueblo Counties are John Bluck, Rebecca Dunbar, Ann T Herlihy, William J Hybl, and John G Levity .

 International Settlements Through International Law by Max S Power . Dr. Power: "International Settlements through International Law"
 His talk was liberally interspersed with specific examples and even Biblical references . His talk began by distinguishing two kinds of disputes .
 Law is the "practical translation of the morals, customs, and experiences of human beings" into workable principles, Dr. Dr. John Defterios says .
 A dispute involving both political and legal questions can be much more easily solved if the legal issues are settled first by legal means and the political issues are then solved by political means . He went on to say that such a dispute can be easily solved by both legal and political issues .
 Larson contended that there are at least four reasons why this approach can be more effective . Larson: There are four reasons that this approach is more effective. Larson: It's a good idea to use the same approach as the other .
 The second reason is that a party certain of its legal rights in a dispute is not going to give in to political attempts to take away those rights . The parties are certain of their legal rights and will not give in on political efforts to take them away .
 The parties realize that if the negotiations fail there will be an authoritative decision on the merits . The third reason is that negotiations over present rights will be more serious and productive .
 Larson went on to point out that we now have the building blocks of an international legal system . Larson: We now have a building block of a global legal system. Larson: It's a good step forward for the future of the world .
 The last of these is currently the object of much research on the part of Dr. Dr. John Defterios of the U.S.
 The second basis for international law is the machinery to apply that law . The machinery is the basis for applying that law, the second basis is the law itself .
 Larson said the International Court of Justice at the Hague presently provides that machinery . Larson said that the Hague is providing that machinery. Larson said he hopes the court will be able to hear the case .
 It has 15 distinguished jurists, including many of the world's leading international lawyers .
 Larson assured the audience that the influx of Communists on the court is negligible . Larson: "The influx of Communist Communists is negligible"
 He contended that this is entirely possible and pointed to a number of historical examples to back up his statement .
 Many nations have not accepted the jurisdiction of the world court, Larson said .
 Larson launched on a convincing argument for the repeal of our Connally Ammendment . Larson says the amendment was repealed by a repeal of the law . Larson: "It's a good idea to repeal the law"
 Larson says all treaties should include "compromissory clauses" in which parties to the treaty agree that disputes about the treaty will be referred to the World Court . Larson: All treaties should have 'compromisory clauses' in which the parties agree they will refer disputes to the

 Barney Barney, a member of the class of 1920, is president of the Colorado Springs National Bank . Barney is a class member of 1920 class . He is now president of Colorado Springs national bank .
 He was secretary-treasurer of the Colorado School for the Deaf and Blind for 15 years . He has served in Colorado for more than 30 years .

 Spurgeon earned a bachelor of arts degree in history at Colorado College in 1926 . Spurgeon is now a Colorado Springs lawyer .

 There are no dictation or words-a-minute objectives, and the course is not designed to train stenographers .

 Teachers will be able to earn credit hours in general science for one semester . The teachers will earn the credit hours for one year .

 National Science Foundation-sponged project studying the effects of various social conditions upon the distribution of energy in the mouse . Dr. John Sutter was working on a project studying effects of social conditions .
 Robert Z grown of the Colorado College zoology department observed many parallels between the social organization of mice and lien ■s . These include eating, sleeping, fighting (or raising families for females) and building shelters, grooming, and snooping .
 By fighting see who dominates the group . They solve iheir social problems . By fighting . See who dominates a group .
 Mice have a pyramidal social [fracture] with one boss as the top, few middle-class straw-bosses jelow him, and below them a vast rde of common mice .
 The males have nothing to do nth the rearing of the young. [hat is a completely feminine [unction]. Male males are not responsible for rearing the young .
 Brown observed that when new groups are formed in his pens ■e is continual strife for about hours as they decide who is the leader . aggressiveness, rather than size, usually is the most important factor in determining who becomes the leader, he said .
 "Those who lose the fight, but ■scape with their lives become 'straw-bosses'" or peasants. Those who fail to win the fight become "straw bosses" or "peasant" or peasants .
 The 'straw-bosses"" like middle class aecutives, live in constant tur . Most of them are either on ;heir way up or on their way town,"" Brown said .
 He feeds them well with a purpose, for he is trying to determine how they spend the energy they take into their bodies . Their diet consists of a specially-prepared, nutritionally balanced pellet made specifically for He feeds .
 Energy is used for producing work, gaining weight, or is passed off as waste . Basically the energy is used to produce work, gain weight or to pass on waste .
 Brown noted that the mouse who is destined to become the chief of his clan may have a lower metabolism than other mice . Brown said the mouse's metabolism may be lower than that of other mice.
 He thinks this is because the potentially superior mouse has a more efficient body . He thinks that the mouse body is more efficient than the mouse's .
 He hopes to find out how much energy each mouse burns under various kinds of conditions . Each mouse has a unique body shape and energy capacity .
 A mouse is placed in a sealed chamber in which ordinary air is pumped at normal pressure . The oxygen consumed is measured by placing a mouse in the same chamber .
 He measures the air passing out of the chamber to see how much oxygen has been burned up by the mouse . The air passing through the chamber is measured by the amount of oxygen it burns up .

 Maurice Maeterlinck wrote the play, Pelleas and Melisande . The play is based on the works of the same name .
 He imposed a web of symbolism on a romantic theme, but rose above Romanticism . The author rose above the literary movement, which often swoons in its own delight .
 Maeterlinck's tone and mood it creates alienate the action from time, and external events need not be relevant to appreciate the universality of the play .
 This other-world atmosphere offers a stubborn challenge to a prospective producer . However, it is a strong atmosphere that offers a strong challenge to producers .
 Maeterlinck utiliz ed the famous Paolo-Francesca narrative from The Divine Comedy . If you devotes close attention to the play, explicit parallels are visible .
 As Pelleas and Melisande opens the possibility of a disastrous love takes birth, and continually deepens until the final climax ia reached . The final climax is reached .
 Pelleas and his siBter-in-law, Melisande, are driven towards each other, and all consideration for his brother, Golaud, is ignored .
 Their common source of love and light is symbolized by the sea, but already the water is gloomy . The sea symbolizes a source of light and love for the couple .
 Pelleas envisons their destiny when he speaks of the storm that comes in at the end of each day . Presently the sea is calm, but the storm comes in each day. Presently it is calm .
 The play comes to its climax at ""Blind Man's Springs,"" where ""reason"" is shattered, clouds drift over the path of life, and living becomes a blind proposition .
 The defeat of Pelleas is final but not tragic, says Martin Samuel . The defeat is not tragic for the Welshman, says Samuel Samuel . Samuel Samuel was inspired by whimsical impulses .
 As the dramatic narrative concludes, Golaud, an iron man of great physical stature, and Melisande, a young girl that might ""give God lessons in innocence,"" are unable to save themselves from tragedy .
 Students watched gangs of Slocum Hall men punching, tackling, and o-ouging each other while trying to move a pregnant-looking white canvas ball across manure-laden fields . Last week students had the unusual opportunity ot watching gangs .
 The technical name of this new sport is ""pushball,"" latest attempt by intramural manager Jim Hanks to revive Slocum Hall athletic competition . Pushball is the latest attempt to revive the moribund athletic competition.
 The wild game, played by six men representing their respective wings, consists of moving the paunchy white ball toward the opponent's goal in an attempt to actually enter his goal, or cross his goal line and score two points .
 Theoretically, the sport has rules and referees; in actual practice, however, the law of the jungle prevails, especially in the immediate vicinity of the ball . Normally docile associates are suddenly transformed into rough-housing gorillas .
 The most successful maneuver has been to deploy half of the team in pushing the ball toward the goal while the other half pulls opponents from the ball . Successful teams have won by keeping the ball in the air, and on the ground .
 All strategy, however, must be reinforced by a hustling group that is willing to lose, says CNN.com's John Sutter .
 The demanding game enervates even the best athletes — and these are few and far between in Slocum's intramural competition . The demands of the game are too much to bear for the best .

 Three advanced piano students, two string; groups; groups, and a woodwind ensemble will be featured on this program . The program includes students from advanced piano to two string students .
 Jane Humphrey, a freshman from Mullen, Nebraska, will perform two Intermezzi and one Capriccio by Brahms . Barbara Couey, a sophomore from Trinidad, Colorado, will be heard in the first movement of Schumann's Piano Concerto in A minor .
 With the exception of Miss Perry, the string and woodwind ensembles are made up entirely of non-music students .
 The first string group will open the program wtih the first movement of Haydn's quartet in G Major, op. op. The program will also feature a piece from the composer's first symphony piece . The program includes a selection of the Haydn quartet .

 On May 17, the Annual Honor Council Nominating Assembly will be held in Taylor Dining Hall, at 4:15 . The importance of these elections of new Honor Council members is vital to the well-being of the Honor System .
 The method of election tries to combine the greatest possible democratic choice in permitting the nominations of anyone in the student body and in the two votes taken at the assembly to narrow the field of candidates to twice the number of vacancies .
 The members of the old Honor Council choose the new members from the final field . Then, in order to eliminate any aspects of a ""popularity contest,"" and to provide the most judicious choices, the members . The new members will be chosen from a final field, rather than

 Mr Cassius De Flon's pro-eugenics letter in the Tiger of May gratulates the Tiger on raising the proportion of news it has consistently printed since the first few issues .
 It also gives me the opportunity to offer your readers some criticisms of the eugenics position, as none have appeared so far in your pages . It gives me a chance to offer some criticisms, but none so far so far .
 The version of his argument to which we were treated in the Roberts Lecture was eugenics at its most reckless, with none of the reservations added . It was 'eugenics' at its 'most reckless' with no reservations added, he says .
 The fallacy of the eugenics argument is that it makes deductions about human evolution from data derived solely from the biological sciences . Muller and De Flon present it as a fallacy . The fallacy is that the argument is based on data derived from purely biological data .
 Muller uses the terms ""culture"" and ""cultural evolution,"" he shows little awareness that human socio-cultural life is more complex than the existence of other animal species . Muller has little awareness of the complex nature of human life .
 On the face of it, the list of genetically ""good"" traits looks so desirable that to attack it would be like attacking mother-love .
 Anthropologists would be more enthusiastic about selection in favor of them if psychologists could tell us more about their dynamics . Geneticists can tell us about their genetic makeup, anthropologists say . But anthropologists would like to know more about the dynamics of selection .
 Muller fears that without selective breeding, human beings will eventually be able to 'prop up their own feebleness' Muller says that human beings 'will eventually do no more than . do nothing more than prop up themselves' Muller fears selective breeding will allow humans to 'do no more
 Some physical conditions are apparently being selected against by modern cultural conditions which were neutral before the industrial revolution, just an instant ago in evolutionary time . As I said on the 24th, this prediction ignores the fact that some physical conditions .
 It assumes that we have had accurate statistics on the incidence of specific diseases over long periods of time . It also assumes that the statistics are accurate and accurate .
 Phenylketonuria, for instance, is now well diagnosed now but was not always . Phenylkonuria is a form of kidney disease that causes kidney failure in some cases .
 One school of thought among physicians believes that the increase in statistics on this disease is an artifact of better diagnosis and better record-keeping .
 The definition and even the desirability of a healthy body are ""more parochial than the eugenists apparently suspect," says Dr. Andrew Hammond .
 In mid-twentieth century America we enjoy a cult of health, youth, and suppleness which is by no means shared in other parts of the world, not in Euro-American culture at other times .
 A modern physician might well regard one of Titian's or Rubens' models as overweight . Rubens, Titian and Titian models were likely to be overweight. Rubens was a painter of the 16th century .
 A Hottentot male wants a female with a pot belly, swayed back, and fantastic eccumulations of fat on the buttocks . A female with pot belly and swayed back .
 There is good evidence that in paleolithic times men were selected for keen senses, fleetness, and grace . In the neolithic sheer strength had better survival value .
 In eighteenth century Europe, the tendency toward tuberculosis was fashionable . The tendency to develop tuberculosis was also fashionable in Europe .
 Selection for the modern American concept of good health would violate norms of other times and other places . Selection would violate the norms of others times, and we have no guarantee that this concept will last longer than any other .
 Muller's and his even more inflammatory term ""genetic deterioration"" appear to ignore the problem of measurement . Muller's fear of Muller's, and his inflammatory term "genetic deterioration" appear to be ignoring the problem .
 Evolutionary theory has no measure of genetic goodness except natural selection . If selection does not operate against a genetic factor, that factor can hardly be considered harmful . Selection is not necessary to be harmful, but it can be beneficial .
 Muller says cultural existence is an ""artificial"" way of life . Muller: Culture is an "artificial way of life" Muller: "Culture is an artificial way to live"
 Culture is a survival device, a part of nature no more ""artificial"" than the hide of the rhinoceros or the claws of the lion . Culture is not a "survival device" but a "part of nature" that is no more "artificial"
 I shall not argue that the tendency toward disease is actually of use to our species, though such an argument might be made . Instead, I shall argue that such a thing might be useful to the human species .
 Mr De Flon seems to understand well enough the position of some geneticists on human genetics .
 A sound knowledge of Homo sapiens, however, requires that one take a broad view of human behavior . The interaction between genetics and culture is an intricate interaction, says author .

 Mountaineer's Weekend is an annual gathering of college mountain clubs from the Rocky Mountain region . The Colorado College Mountain Club is sponsoring the event .
 The weekend will begin Friday as the visiting clubs arrive and register in Rastall Center . The visiting clubs will register at the weekend .
 Registration will continue into the early part of Saturday morning to accommodate clubs coming from as far as Salt Lake City . Registration will also continue into early Saturday morning for clubs from all over the country .
 After 10m. registration will move from the main desk to the club headquarters in the Berg Heil room . The club's main desk will now be located at the club's headquarters . The new registration system will be in place of 10m registration .
 Any interested students invited to come to the registration desk for information and are invited to participate in the weekend activities .
 Of greatest interest to spectators will be rock climbing in the Garden of the Gods and North Cheyenne Canyon . Rock climbing will be a highlight for visitors to the Grand Canyon .
 There will be climbers on many spectacular routes easily seen from the roads . CCMC members will be available to answer questions about the routes .

 Traditionally this party has been one of the social highlights of the climbing season .
 There are no formal activities planned for Sunday as clubs from Wyoming and Utah will have to leave early . Climbing will probably continue through much of the day, but climbing is likely to continue .
 The first Mountaineer's Weekend was held at Laramie in May 1957 in the rain . Only four CCMC members participated in the event .
 Oskasita Hosts Annual Gymkhana held last Sunday in Penrose Stadium . CC Gymkhanas were held in the Penrose stadium in the city .
 Events were enhanced by an unusually large turnout and beautiful weather . Events were interesting, as well as often hysterical to watch .
 The most amusing of the events was Goat Tying, in which contestants had to ride out to the middle of the arena, dismount, throw and tie a goat tied to a stake .
 Although one could not help feeling sorry for the unfortunate animal, one also could not laugh at the antics of the contestants . The animal was injured in the incident .
 Donna Story won the event with an amazingly good time of 24 seconds . The event was won by Donna Story with an amazing 24-second time .
 Out of the nine classes, only three were really serious, the barrel racing and freshman and upperclass equitation . The barrel racing was the only serious class .
 Sue Thompson won the barrel racing with a time of 17. seconds — extremely good for a college event . Sue Thompson was the only person to win a barrel racing event in college .
 The ""fun"" events included musical tires, water relay, walk and lead race, walk, trot, and canter relay and egg and spoon race .
 All these classes were just what they were billed to be — fun, not only for the riders, but also for the spectators . All of these classes are just what it was billed as .
 The judge for all the events was Beverly Bryant, a young lady who is well known all over the state for her English and western riding .
