 The fifth annual Abbot Lecture was given last Monday night by Dr. Dr. John Sutter . Dr. Sutter delivered the lecture at the University of Cambridge .
 Dr. Shoulu describes the general hanges that shoulu can be effected in the American political system . Dr. J. Shoolu describes how the political system should be affected by the American government .
 Kossiter described the three polititraditions from which the united States has drawn . The United States is divided into three political parties .
 He spoke the Conservatism of Edmund Burke, generally associated with the British System, which was asciated with negative conceptions of progress and social welfare . He spoke out against the British system .
 The American people have rejected this conservatism with the violence that they have rejected the radicalism of Marx, Rosseau. and Paine. The U.S. has rejected the conservatism of the American people with violence, the president says .
 Instead of following either reactionary or radical paths, the American people had bhosen, according to the professor . The American people have a tradition of liberalism, or hopeful optimism, he says .
 The Cornell professor then began to list characteristics of our liberal tradition, including our populism, constitutionalism, and our skepticism of political power and its uses .
 He added that we have incorporated into our body oi philosophy belief in God, an optimistic view of history working in our favor, and a dynamic and progressive spirit of growth . Along wih these ""narrow"" definitions of liberal doctrine, he said .
 Rossiter then pointed out the dangers which can arise from having unreal or unrealizable ideals . Rossiter said the dangers of unreal ideals can arise when people have unreal or unrealistic ideals .
 Although ideals should be more advanced than the eality they describe, they should not be so advanced as to be imiractical, giving us a misleading onception of what our aims are in times of crisis .
 Calls this disparity between ■deals and reality the ""ideal gap,"" he went on to declare that we should correct at least three errors that are handicapping our progress today .
 Dssiter declared that modern government demanded a greater sponsibility for our leaders and that with this responsibility must be corresponding political and personal power, still within the confines of democracy . Modern government demands a greater sponsorship of our leaders .
 He pointed out that we must modify our present inhibitions against such increases of personal power . He said that we need to modify our current inhibitions .
 Professor Rossiter went on to say that we must lose our reluctance to use our political power for our own good, both foreign and domestic . He said we must use our power for the good of our country both abroad and domestically .
 Cornell professor says political power is less dangerous than political vacuum . Political vacuum is more dangerous than a political vacuum, he says . Cornell professor: In the modern world political power less dangerous .
 His final point was that we must modify our blind faith in individualism . He said that individualism is not a matter of individualism but individualism must be modified .
 We must realize that the most effective action is performed by and for groups . That is, we must realize, that the best action should be done by groups, not individuals .
 Rossiter appealed once more to the notion that all he had suggested had been previously suggested by other Americans in times past . Rossiter: "All of the things he suggested had previously been suggested by others"
 It almost seemed as though this argument cast a holy light on all his statements and made them ""homegrown"" and hence good . The argument almost seemed like this argument made it seem like it was 'homegrown' and therefore good .
 In spite of this one ""irrational" appeal, what the scholarly Abbot lecturer had to say was timely and articulate . The Abbot was a scholar of the Abbot .
 Rossiter admitted his proposals were far-reaching, but declared that they were consistent with the liberal tradition . Rossiter said they were essential to the success of our nation and our ideals in the twentieth century .
 Nicole Antuszewicz, special piano student of Max Lanner, will give a Young Artist recital on May 22nd .
 At 16, she was admitted to the Ecole Normale de Musique de Paris, founded by the famous pianist, Alfred Cortot . She studied at the famous piano school founded by Cortot in Paris .
 She won the school's first prize in piano in her second year at the Conservatoire National de Music de Versailles . From there, she graduated into the Conservatoriès National de Muschey de Music .
 She continued her work at the Musig Hochsehule in Munich under Professor Koebel, and then again in Paris under Jean Micault . She continued to work in Munich, Germany and Paris .
 This year, while in Colorado Springs, she has been studying with Max Lanner, preparing herself for an important competition in France . She will enter the competition upon her return next season .

 We have seen two very stimulating and thought provoking letters appear in The Tiger . During the past two weeks, we have seen a very stimulating, thought provoking letter .
 Both pro and con arguments about artificial selection have been presented . Both pro or con arguments against artificial selection are presented .
 He has implied that good health is only a matter of fashion, geography, or culture . He has also implied that it is only matter of style, geography or culture.
 Mr De Flon bases his argument for artificial selection on the fact that there is a buildup of detrimental mutations occurring in mankind's genetic reservoir .
 These mutations result in the inability of the organism to carry out vital metabolic processes, or to resist disease . These mutations are known as 'mutation mutations' and 'mutations'
 Mr Kutsche bases his argument on the hope that culture will counteract the pernicious effect of mutations .
 The examples Mr Kutsche cites of control by culture are rather easily counteracted lethal or sublethal mutations . The examples he cites are of control of culture by culture .
 When the buildup of genetic defects has reached a certain point, humans will appear who carry a series of these defects, and control by medical means will become increasingly impossible . Control will become impossible by the end of the day .
 Def defects which are not now selected against due to cultural knowledge can readily be considered harmful . Thus, defects which were not now considered harmful can be readily considered harmful.
 A Hottentot male wants a female with a potbelly and a swayed back . He doesn't seem to realize that it is precisely because of natural selection that a female has a pot belly .
 It also does not follow that because people once felt that tuberculosis was fashionable, it is good health in a purely objective sense, it does not mean tuberculosis is fashionable .
 On a statistical basis alone, I would object to the feasibility of this undertaking . On the statistical basis, this is not a good idea for the project .
 There is also the fact that new deleterious mutations would arise in each successive generation . Some of these would not be detected for several generations until an appropriate mating resulting in a homogenote occurred .
 Until our knowledge of genetics has increased sufficiently to provide us with an exacting method of genetic analysis in vitro, rather than a phenotypic analysis in vivo, the reduction of deleterious mutations by artifiicial selection would be impractical .

 If we then decide to select against it, we would have to stop most of the African population from breeding in areas where malaria had been at all prevalent in times past . We would then have to choose against it .
 "It would seem much more appropriate to talk in terms of what we do know than what we don't," he says .
 From even the most superficial study of genetics, one finds certain things that stand out . From even a superficial study, genetics can reveal certain things .
 All genetic structures exhibit a certain tendency to change, i.e. to mutate . Genetic structures have a tendency to do so, and mutate, say experts .
 This tendency might be called the base mutation rate for that organism . This tendency may be the "base mutation rate" of an organism .
 This base rate may be raised by the presence of mutagenic agents such as ionizing radiations of various kinds . Second, this base rate is raised by mutagenation agents .
 That most mutations have a pernicious effect on the organism involved . Last, that most mutations . have a negative effect on . organism involved in the experiment .
 It would appear that, if we wish to do something about this problem, we should try to prevent the rise of our base mutation rate .
 "This, at present, seems to be the most realistic answer to this question," he says . "It seems to present to me, this is the best answer," he adds .

 Colorado College scientist thinks he may have the as chemistry stuthis may be appl j ed ^h pron t,"" dents are concerned .
 The system is actually a series of six to eight books designed to help students r the harder spots of freshman chemistry . Professor Snyder is developing the system .
 On the first page, the student reads a short body of text and then answers a series of multiple-choice questions . The student answers the questions based on a list of answers to each other .
 Each of the multiple-choice answers requires i to turn to a different page in the book . The answers must be turned to different pages in each of the answers .
 If he makes the correct answer, he continues on to the next body of text . If he corrects the question, he goes on to answer it . He then repeats the question if he is correct .
 If he gives the wrong iwer, he will turn to a page where he will find an explanation how and why his answer was wrong . He will then turn to the page to find out what he gave wrong .
 If it is answered correctly this time, the student will be able to continue to the second question . If the student answers correctly, he can continue to answer the other question .
 "The idea is to allow the student to make a few mistakes but then capitalize on the mistakes to show him where he went wrong,"" e continued .
 Programmed instruction might bridge the gap between theoretical concepts and practical practice . Programmed teaching might also give students some excellent practice in applying theoretical concepts to more practical situations .

 Miss Cogswell is a student of modern diplomatic history . She hopes to continue graduate work toward an advanced degree in modern European history of international relations .
 She is preparing herself for a career of translating foreign scientific papers into English . She hopes to become a translator of scientific papers in English .
 She will study conditions of the Slovenian minority in the province of Carinthia .

 Colorado College physics department has received assistance totaling nearly $60,000 for instructional equipment . The money will help implement a new physics curriculum .
 The physics department has embarked upon a completely revised curriculum designed to assist students in the crucial process of self-education in physics . Under the direction of Professoi Howard M Olson, the physics department .
 The new program was made possible by a grant of $24,500 from the National Science Foundation, matched by the college, in support of the program .
 The new curriculum was designed to meet the needs of four kinds of physics majors, including those who plan to teach physics at the secondary school level . Students who expect to go into industry immediately upon graduation will be able to use the curriculum .
 The new physics program is built around a course structure which consists of a solid core foursemester sequence of basic physics required of all majors in the field .
 These courses are followed by progressively more sophisticated courses, not all of which are required for graduation . These courses include courses not required for most of the time .
 A prospective Ph.D. candidate would probably take all of the offerings in the physics department . For example, the student who plans to tench high school physics might elect to take only some of the junior courses .

 The purpose of a place like this would be to promote informal gatherings, with or without dates . "The purpose of this place is to promote gatherings," the author says .
 A questionnaire was submitted to the student body and faculty to obtain their views on this subject . The student body was asked to respond to the question .
 Some of the effects on campus life would be; Increased social drinking rather than excessive, give the freshmen a place to go, increase school unity, and cut down on drinking and driving would be cut down .

 Colorado College Tiger's position in intercollegiate sports might be described as the old minstrel joke involving the man accosted by the udge for deserting his wiife . The position of the Tiger is the same as that of the Udge .
 Big-time athletics leaves them, as it becomes more and more of a business, supportable only by large receipts . Big time athletics is a big business, but it's not a big enough to support it, says the sports world .
 This is a fortunate thing for small colleges, since economic pressures make them do what they ought to be doing anyway for educational reasons . Small colleges are doing what they need to do anyway for education reasons .
 In hockey Colorado College has its one so-called big time sport; and the relentless build-up among our much larger Western League competitors over the past five years has been hard on us .
 It is still possible that by pinpointed selection of hockey-playing students who artable and discriminating enough to desire the kind of educational experience Colorado College affords d by achieving our own ice rink for practice .
 In football, as in other sports, 'e are moving toward teams more cpresentative of the normal student athlete who elects to come to Colorado College, and the kino, of competition our kind of college ought to be playing . Colorado College is moving toward becoming more competitive in
 Despite geoaphical limitations, we see progss in these trends, mainly among lieges in the Great Plains . Despite geophical limitations we see prossions in this region .
 Colorado College expects to keep broad program of intercollegiate sports so long as student body will engage in them enthusiastically . College will manage the whole program without curbing commitment to a first-rate instructional program and a closeknit campus community .
 If students should become indifferent to sports attendance, or disinclined to stay out for the sake of the sport itself, we would have no reason to continue the program . If students were indifferent to attendance attendance, they would not have a reason to support a team .
 Student expressions of interest in intercollegiate sports are the most important element in our planning . It is important also to keep in mind the natural limitations imposed upon us, and the order of priorities which a college must keep in order to succeed .

 Spring Springs' House of WHEELS SCHWINn and RALEIGH BICYCLES PEAK AVENUE . And somehow you a million or so hours of panicked studying .
 You griped and complained every inch of the way, somehow loving and cherishing every one of those damn inches . And you griped, complained, but somehow still loved and cherished every inch .
 "Now it's almost all over and you stand there barefooted, pushing your big toe in the sand and grinning sheepishly— trying to find someone to thank for those wonderful, gorgeous years," she says .
 You say thanks to your parents and marvel at the vastness of their understanding . You say "thank you" to them, you marvel at their kindness .
 You say thanks to the professors who pushed and shoved you and you're just a little bit embarrased by the many curses you flung at them for imagined injustices . You say "thank you" to the professor who pushes and pushes you .
 You thank your friends for all the laughs, the mutual advice, and the companionship and you're very sad because you must leave them . You're very very sad .
 "You realize the inadequacev and the smallness of those ""thanks,"" so you keep your mouth shut and hope they'll understand . "And, of course, they do. And suddenly you realize . Suddenly you realize the . inadequacevev . And the . small
 "You stand up, look around for the final time, and force out a choked ""good-bye"" and, believe it or not, there's a little tear in your eye. Then you stand up and say 'good-by' to everyone you know .
 You whisper to yourself, ""Je ne regrette rien,"" and you start the next four years . You whisper, "Je ne regrets rien"

 Introduction to Digital Computing is designed to teach students how to work complicated mathematical problems with an electric . The course was approved by the college faculty at its regular monthly meeting Monday .
 Two years of college level mathematics courses, involving analytic geometry and calculus, will be required to gain admission to the year-long course carrying two credit hours each semester . Two credit hours are required for the course .
 Course will deal with logical and mechanical characterizations of a computer . Number systems and computing codes; coding, mathematical models, numerical analysis, and numerical analysis; and automatic programming systems .
 The new course was approved by the mathematics department, the division of natural sciences, and the committee on instruction at the independent college .
 In other action, the college faculty voted to reorganize the geography program .
 The result was four new geography courses to replace three differently structured courses . The result of the change was four different geography courses .
 Each of the new geography courses, to be given during the coming academic year, will carry three hours of credit . Each course will carry a total of three hours per student .
 Physical Geography is a study of the physical elements of geography, including the earth and its representation, the nature and distributinon of climate, soils, vegetation, and landforms . The study of physical geography includes the earth, soils and vegetation .
 Cultural Geography is a general introduction to the ways in which man has modified and used the landscapes of the world . The book is based on the works of cultural geography .
 The cultural, physical and economic geography of the United States and Canada, considered in historical perspective . Geography of North America . The cultural and physical geography of U.S. and Canada . Canada .

 He joined the telephone company in 1923 and within two years was advanced to traffic superintendent at Pueblo . Within two years he became traffic superintendent . He was promoted to Traffic Superintendent at the company's headquarters .
 During the following 20 years he was Denver traffic chief, general sales manager, Salt Lake City commercial supervisor, and Denver commercial supervisor . He has also worked in Denver, Utah and Denver, Colorado .
 In 1945 he was promoted to general commercial manager and vice president . In 1949 he was named vice president of the company .
 He is also vice-president of the Metropolitan Safety Council, Colorado civilian aide to the secretary of the army, and past president of the Denver Chamber of Commerce .
